big_ocr: BRAHAM,3;;} | ee‘  Braham, a 23—year—old nearly white mullatto, was a native of Jeffer— son County, Ala, From childhood, he and Minnie Crenwhaw had been sweethearts, They attended a black university together in Selmnap Ala,, and, after their graduation returned to Jefferson Countty where Miss Crenshaw obtained a posktion £s a shhool teacher at Adamsville,. Unable to find other employment in spite of his educa— tion, Braham begame a miner in the FXX mines at Pratt City. Indus— trious, hard=working and thrifty, Braham rapidly earned the respect of his fellow miners and all others Wm with whom he came into con— tact, Even though the two lovers were separated, they continued their courtship by correspondence, In the fall of 1903, Miss Cren— shaw visited him in Pratt City and they went for a walk in the woods during the course of which Braham asked her to marry him.  She replied that though she loved him, their stations in life were too far apart for her to consider marriage,. He became enraged ,X drew a pistol and shot her in the head three times, killing her  stantl. immediégely went to the police and surrendered éﬁaéiﬂg zﬁatEES L4 not care to live himselft After he had been _ tried, convicted and sentenced to die, he changed his mind and his attorneys carried his case to the State Supreme Gourt which upheld the verdict of the lower courts, There was considerable sympathy for him, and a number of persons sought executive clemency, but this, too,was denied and on March 10, 1905, he mounted the gallows in the Jefferson County Jail yard at Birmingham, Ala., with a ‘smile and was hanged. His neck was broken by the fall and he died instantly.  Birmingham NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama 3—10—1905  13 Abana $8, (ee Se At 1‘ 7.

big_ocr: COBB, Phillip black  Cobb, a 2l;—year=old/resident of Montgomery Co., Ala., had shot and killed his wife with a pistol in 1946. At his trial, he maintained that the pistol had discharged accidentally while he struggled with another man,. However, the other man denied this and the physical evidence disproved it so he was convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to die. After the Alabama Supreme Court upheld the convic— tion, the Governor commuted the sentence to life imprisonment and Cobb was moved from death row into a csll in Kilby Prison which he shared with another black prisoner named Jesse Porter, Both men were assigned to work in the prison cotton mill and one morning in 1918 Cobb walked from where he was working in the mill to the spot where Porter was working, grabbed him by the shoulder and turned him around , and stabbed him in the neck inflicting a mortal wound. Cobb confessed to officers that he and Porter had been having a homosexual affair which, the night before, Porter had XKKSXXXKSX threatened to discontin— ue and that for this reason Cobb had killed him, At his trial he de» nied having said this and stated that Porter had threatened to kill him on the night before because he had refused to lend Porter money  with which to buy dope. He claimed that Porter had been accidentally stabbedin a struggle for possession of the knife during a fight which had been started by Portel. Convicted and senter nced to die under an Alabama Statute that provided the death penalty for any prisoner serving a life sentence who committed murder, the convic— tion was upheld by the Alabama Supreme Court and Cobb was electro— cuted at the Alavama State Prison on March 11, 19219 12 3 20 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 713. c a ag j= 38 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 279 257 ﬁg}? ra 4?” T #8.

big_ocr: " ABRANT, Elmer N. ( "Shorty") & —/ ‘7’f’/ I2  Arrant, a 3}—year—old white man, had a record of mental instability and at one time had been a patient in a private sanitarlum. He had lived in Fort Deposit, Ala., for five years where he was a respected — and prominent member of the community, being employed as the local manager for tne of the major utility companies, He was some ting of a local celebrity as the star of an amateur baseball team. He convinced himself that his wife had been having an affair with one of their friends, John E. Norman, On the night of June 20, 1935, he telsphoned Norman and asked him to step over to his house, Mrs, Nor— man accompanied her husband after they came on his property, Arrant, who was hiding in ambush behind a vine, shot and killed them both, His plea was one of insanity and there was testimony on both sides as to his mental condition. The trial, which lasted for two days during which Arrant did not take the stard in his own behalf, re— sulted in a conviction and he was given the death sentence, The case was taken to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed the con— viction, A stﬂghjpffort was made to have the Governor commute the sentence on the grounds of his mental condition and, in refusing to do so, the Governor conceded that Arrant was insane but said that he had been in that condition for years and was still accepted as a leader of his community, He was electrocuted at Kilby Prison on June 19, ‘1936. He was murmering a prayer as the electricity was applied. f  167 SOUTHERN REPORTER 540. f Birmingham NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, June 19, 1936.  33 3. Ge ba 2

big_ocr: AVERY, Lonnie  Avery, a 26—year—old black resident of Bibb Co., Ala., and his wife wore separated in Dec., 1933, and were living apart, In Febraary, 193h, he went to the house where she was stay» ing and, in the presence of three witnesses shot her twice in the back. She turned towards him and then fell on her face. He then walked over, fired two mora shots in her back and a final one into her head. Avery fled and went to Pennsylvania. He was not captured until March, 1938, and at that time he denied his true identi ty and maintained that he had never been in Bibb County. Returned to stand trial, he maintained that his wife had been carrying the pistol in her sweater and that it accidentally discharged when he __ struggled with her after she had drawn it. This testimony was dis» puted by the witnesses to the murder, all three of whom testified for the State and he was convicted and sentenced to die. His case was appealed to the Alabama Suprme by his two attorneys, They had been appointed on March 21, 1938, and the case called for trial on March 24 after their motion for a continuance had been denied. The court affirmed the confiction and Avery was electrocuted at Kilby  Prison on March 15, 1940. # B (794ng yl Via/f )F ( B T H-a‘“ f SWT C THE MONTGCMERY ADVERTISER » Montgomery, Alabama 3—15—19}0  188 SOUTHERN REPORTER 292  A I7 P4ab l gay ins suo ;  ds ser #9 ¢ 2 f

big_ocr: BRANDON, Willie James  Brandon, a 23—year—old black Coffee Co., Ala., farm laborer, had served a term in Kilby Prison for grand larceny, One afternoon in January, 190, he wont to the farm house of a prominent young house wife in the Wesley Chapel. community and raped her after brutally beating her into submission and knocking several teeth out. Bran» don‘s father revealed his hiding place which was about three miles from the scene of the crime to law officers and he was arrested.  TIried, convicted‘and sentenced to die in May, he was elsctrocuted at | Kilby Prison on August 9, 1940.  The ENTERPRISE LEDGER, Enterprise, Alabama Jane 12, 1940 and May 21}, 1940,

big_ocr: CARPENTER, John  Carpenter, a Tuscaloosa Co,, Ala., black man, was employed as a laborer on the Stewart Plantation about six miles from Tusc3loos23, He became enraged wihempodmt with jealousy when the Plantation over» seer, Stewart Champion, took the keys to the barn and other out buildings from him and was heard to utter threats against Champions On the night of April 10, 1905, he crept up on the Champion porch with a shotgm loaded with squirrel shot and fired a charge into Champion‘s leg which severed an artery and the overseer bled to deaths As Champion was holding his baby in his arms at the time that he was shot, it was believed that Carpenter had aimed his sun low to avoid hitting the child, Nonetheless, a few of the shot  did strike the child in the fo rer was trailed by dogs and captured shortly afterwardse( He confessed, was tried, convicted and sentenced to die. H; was \hanged at Tuscaloosa on June 23, 1905,         BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, June 25, XXRK 1905.  r—-—————-—--

big_ocr: BROWN, Jimmie  Brown, alias Adolph Brown, a 25=year=—old Jefferson Cor, Ala., black man, had served a prison term for attempted rape, Around 9 o‘clock one night in 1938, he met a young whittwoman on the strset and, holding a pistol at her side forced her to accompany him into a wooded area several blocks away where he pushed her to the ground and raped her. Afterwards, as they were walking back towards the street, he took her purse, removed three dollars, and returned it to her, He then told her to walk on to the street alone and that i6 she made any attempt to runktowards a house or give an Rtymeyy alarm, he would kill her, The woman reported the assault and when srown was taken into custody, she positively identifiedfhim, He sought to establish an alibi with the testimony of his #ife, but he  prisornment,. Both sentences Xkk® were appealed to the Alabama Supreme  Court which affirmed both and he was electrocuted at Kilby Prison on November 25, 1938, Brown never confessed and maintained his inno— 183 SOUTHERN REPORTER 412 and 183 SOUTHERN REPORTER 41h The Dothan EAGLE, Dothan, Ala., Nove 25 3 1938  A ply |. big_ocr: ~ BROWMN, Richard " ear 7YI  Brown, born in 1926 at Demopolis, Ala., was a black youth who was sentenced to the Alabama State Reformatory in 1942 for horse theft, He served two years and when he was released on parole, he obtained a job on the cattle ranch owned by 63—ysar—old Jack T. Walton in Hale County,. He and a fellow worker, Ernest Johnson, had discussed killing Walton before and on the morning of Feb, 8, 1915, they broke into his house while he had gone tn town and stole a shotgun, a pis— tol, some shells and bullets, When Walton returned and started to unlock his door, Brown, who was hid at the side of the house, shot him with the shotgun. When they went over the check the body, they noticed a movement of* Walton‘s hand and Johnson told Brown to shoot him again, Brown then shot him with the pistol,. They hauled the body to the bank of ths Warrior River on a wagon, weighted it with  a tractor wheel and hub and sank it in the river on a skiff," The two young men stole $64 and several bags of cattle feed which they shared with Johnson‘s uncle who they told about the crime. When Wal= ton was discovered to be missing, nis employees became suspects and on March 5 both Brown and Johnson were taken into custody for ques— tioning. The both confessed and showed officers where to drags the river and Walton‘s body was discovered on March 6, At first Brown maintained that Jopnson had XXEXHXLXXKX shot Walton but finally admitted that he was the gunman,. His plea was one of insanity and the superin— tendent of the reform school and his assistant both testified that he «had been dull in his studies and inattentive to his work, but no evi— dence of insanity was presented. Johnson‘s uncle received a 30=year sentence for having shared in the proceeds of the murder while both Johnson and Brown were sentenced to die, Both cases wore appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court. In Brown‘s appeal his attorney claimed that he was only 16 years old at the time of the crime, but it was shown bhat he was born in 1929 by a production of his Family‘!s Bible which indicated his birth day as July 11, 1926 and his draft records which indlceated his birth day as April 25, 1926. Johnson was slectro— cuted first and one week later, on Fob. 1, 1946, Brown followed him to the electric chair.at the Alabama State Prisons  See also:. big_ocr: , f BURCHFIELD, John  ‘ C:inaie Ot la/z'r/I 746  Burchfield (also spelled Birchfield), was a 25—year—=old white resi~— dent of Chambers Co.,, Ala., where he was known as an expert fiddler, Around sundown one Monday afternoon in the Fall of 1927, he inter— cepted 15—year—old Howard Dudley just after the boy had left his school bus 4 mile fram his home and forced him to accompany him for 15 miles to a creek bank where he shot him through the body and killedghim, Burchfield then hitched a ride to his sister‘s home in Roanoke and the next day went to Sandy Rock where he offered to sell his pistol to some men for $6.00, He told them that he kad used it to kill a man with whom he had a grudge for several months. He also said that he had planned to throw his victim into a creek with a trace chain that he had taken along but that he had changed his mind and made him lie down on the ground where he shot him, Howard‘s bo had been found that morning and a trace chain was a few feet aways witnesses stated that they had seen Burchfield and the boy crossing some open fields on the preceding afterroon and a search began for hime Be was found hiding in a loft and confesskd, citing his grudge as a motive and as the boy had no money and had  not been sexucally assaulted, it must be assumed that was the motive even though Burchfield never stated the reason for the grudge. At trial he pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity but he was con—  victed and sentenced to die, His attorneys appealed the verdict  and sentencextto the Alabama Supreme Court which upheld both and on _ March 9, 1928, he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison,  THE BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, March 9, 1928.  EBHX 115 Southorh Reportar 297, Convicted on Nov, 17. en asked if he had anything to say, replied: "Judge, I didn‘t have my right mind when I did that, and its not right for me to be hanged for this," "I have had something wrong with my WK&X head for six months," Wept, but soon regained composure, Was only emotion shown during trial, Jury deliberated 3 hours, His father and other reaatives also cried when Judge sentenced to die, State cont en— ded he had killed boy because he thought he had reported for bootlegg— ing activities. BIRMINGHAM NEW, 11—17—1926,  Before final write=up, see notes in Alabama—not written up.

ocr_text: | BURTON, Andrew . "Anniston, AL, 9-9=1904k-=Andrew Burton, negro, was hanged here today at 11;50 o'clock for the killing of William  i  4  Richardson in January at Frances Station on the Seaboard -  Rir Line, The trouble was over a dice game, His wife, mother and sister came over from Birmingham to witness the execution, He talked for twenty minutes from the jail window, warning everybody from the use of whiskey, saying that was the cause of his trouble, He expressed himself to all that he had made his peace with his maker and hoped to meet them all in heaven, This is the first hanging in Anniston and the third in Calhoun County.  There was never such nerve seen, not a quiver in his voicd  nor tear shed, He never weakened," JOURNAL, Atlanta, GA Sept. 9, 1904 (3:2.) Mentioned in B'ham NEWS, 9-9-1904, but nothing additional, 37 SOUTHERN 435 (1h1l AJABAMA 32)
i Hannged Jefferson Co. Jail, Ala,. 1/8/1895  J a \ See 1a rge card / WW  k BYARS , ~Eugene  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., 2-8-1895  Lis whao¥ fren... Ple [105 [WPatba ca 3)
big_ocr: Pay gg//f; g  Byars, a 33—year—old white native of Jefferson Co., Ala., had served as a Birmingham policeman and was one of the deputies on the roof of the court house who fired into the crowd that was attempting to storm the jail in an effort to lynch the wife murderer, Richard Hawes, who was subsequently executed,. In spite of the fact that he was known as a dangerous man when crossed, Byars became a deputy U., S, Marshall and was very active in the tracking down and arrest of moonshiners in the rural Counties around Jefferson, En, May, 1888, he and another Marshal, John Roblnson got into an argument over who should receive credit for an important arrest, They were in a hotel . room in Russellville, Ala ., and both drew pistols with the result that Byars shot and killed Robinson, He was acquitted on the grounds of self—df@fense, He was subsequently tried and acquitted of killing a black man who had testified against him in a minor court case and in 1893 h€ fought a duel with and almost killed a man named Wes  Garner, a former city policeman, in the Parlor Bar in Birmingham,  Late on the afternoon of Jan. , 1894, Byars‘! third cousin, Eugene  Walker, arrived in Wirmingham on his way home to Walker County following five years service in the Army, < Walker had saved his _ money and had over $1,000,00 in new bills from an Omaha, Nebr., bank in his possession,. He checked into a hotel, planning to catch a trai to his home town the next morning,. Byars heard that he was in town and went to his room at 1 o‘clock on the morning of Jan. 5 and got him out of bed to make the rounds of the various bars in Birmingham, With Walker footing the bill, the two cousins caroused until that afternoon when Walker, who had already missed several trains, ox— pressed the deteminatlon to catch one at 10 o‘clock than night, Byars convinced him to catch a street car out to Behrens Park and walk through the woods to the home of Byars! father and visit him before catching the train, Prior to their catching a street cal, Byars went to a store and purchased a pistol, While they were walk= ing through the woods, he shot and killed Walker, stealing the money. That night, he made various purchases in the City, paying for all of . them with newsbills on an Omaha bank, When Walker‘s body was dis—~ covered the next morning, Byars was notified as the nearest relative in tovm. He was found in a house of ill—=repute and when told of his  cousin‘s death, he swore vengeance against the killer and then sent _a wire to Walker s fa ther, Shortly afterwards, officers learned ___  that he had gone to the park with Walker and he was arrested and  charged with the Irmrder. , Byars never admitted his guilt but main= _ ”Gained that. he was innocent. However, the evidence against him, though conclusive and he was convicted and sentenced to hang, . At his request, a white hood was placed over his head instead of the traditional black one. ‘He stated that this would signify his innocence. He was hanged in the Jefferson County Jail on 8, 1895, before a small crowd of witnesses which 1mluded Wesk Garner, the man with whom he had fought a duel two years previogxsly, Byars spoke for twenty mimites reaffirming his innocence and stating that the only man who he had every killed was his fellow Marsh@l, Robinsons He met his death calmly and without any visible signs of emotion,. His last words, spoken after the white hood had been placed over his head, were: "Well, all right, if it mst be," }  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama Feb, 8, 1895.

big_ocr: " CATINELL, Edger T. _  Caldwell, a black native of Detroit, Mich.,, was a U,. S. Army Sergeant, stationed at Camp McClellan, Calhoun Co,, Ala., where he was assigned to the 157th Depot Brigade, On December 1h}, 1918, he boarded an  . Anniston street car and attempted to sit in a section reserved for white passenger, He was promptly ejected by conductor Cecil L&nten and as quickly as he reached the ground he drew a pistol and shot Linten twice, killing him instantly.. When motorman Kelsie Morrason went to Linten‘s sesistance, he shot him also, inflicting a serious but not mortal wund, Caldwell immediately fled to the mountains where he was taken into custody the next night by a detachment of military police, His conviction for the murder was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court and affirmed and then his attorneys asked  the U, S. District Court to set aside the verdict, contending that  he should have been tried by Court Martial, Their refusal to do so was appealed to the United States Supreme Court which held that the state courts were supreme except at the actual scene of war, A strong effort for clemency was made with Attorney General A, Mitchell Palmer,  who contended that he had not received a fair trial, and President Woodrow Wilson both asking for clemency from the Alabama Governor, The Governor also received numerousp@itions from Anniston, including the city‘s leading clergymen and the dead man‘s widow, demanding that ﬂyﬁhé law be allowed to take its course, He finally refused to commute the sentence and ah noon on July 30, 1920, he was hanged in the yard o the Calhoun County Jail in the presence of the widow of the man he had killed held an infant daughter, born after her father‘s death, in her arms, Beffre the execution, he was, allowed to address the ' 2,500 persons assembled in front of the jail, He read the 23rd Psalm, sang two hymns and delivered a proxyter bafore the‘crowd. Afterwards, he spoke briefly urging them to beware of smoking, drinking, gambling and gaccying pistols, The audience was touched by his sincerkty and many wept as he spoke, He then marched to his death with no display of fan“ '  wou  / P — Mis , * "s { é 81 Southern 272; h0O Supreme Court 388; Zkijffﬂié;jaggt A y’;éiy> BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Dec, 16, 1918; Dec, 20, 1918; — — (2: BIRMINGHAM AGE HERALD, "ay 22, 1920; July 10, 1920; July 31, 1920;  July 30, 1920;  Account, nothing new, AKRON BEACON JOURNAL, Ohio, JUly931’ 1920. big_ocr: CALHOUN, George  Calhoun, a Montgomery, Ala,, black man, and his wife, Annie, had been separated for some time. On Christmas day, 1903, he went to the house where she was living and asked her to step outside,  She noticed that he was carrying a double—barreled shotgun and re— fused to do so. He then assured her that he meant her no harm but only wanted to talk and she stepped to the door, He fired one load into her body and then walked over and emptied the other  into her breast, Tried, convicted and sentenced to die, his death was delayed by appeals and applications for a commutation of sen—~ tence, but he was finally hanged at the Montgomery County Jail on March 214, 19050  THE BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., March 24, 1905.  29, TT Hai

big_ocr: ,/ f “if/£72;  Carter, a black Wilcox Co., Ala., tenant farmer, had been married and divorced twice before he married Xxk his third wits, Julia, They farmed on a plantation near Tilden and finally he filed suit against her for a divorce, The divorce was granted, but they con— tinued to live together and farm the crop together, On the morning of June 23, 1891, they were working in the field near some other tenants who observed Julia leave about ten o‘clock after saying that she had to go to a funeral. Shortly afterwards, they saw Robert leave and walk in the samedirection that she had taken, — Hg returned about two hours later and then went to his house. Julia Carter‘s body was found later that evening, She had been shot through the head and her husband was arrested, tried and convicted of the murder, He was hanged before a large crowd in Camden on Jan. 22, 1992, He was allowed to make a speech prior to his execug  CARTER» Robert  tion and he confessed that he had killed his wife and stated that ho was ready to die. After ho finished the crowd rendered him a song which he seemed to appreciate and then he was hanged.  ks BIRMINCHAM DAILY Birmingham, Als, Tafe 23, 1892,

big_ocr: CHAMBERS, Jim and SHAW, Lon  Shaw, a Crenshaw County, Ala., black man, had an altercation with another black, Williamson Champion, in Shaw‘s house on March 28, 1903, over Champion‘s alleged attentions to Shaw‘s wife, Shaw bludgeoned him unconscious with an ax and Chambers, also black, who had arrived during the argument, fired two shots into Champion‘s back. Two of their friends assisted them in carrying the body to a creck which had beensswollen by excessive rain, They weighted the body down with a huge stone weighing almost fifty pounds, but it was discovered when the rains subsided and the creek returned to its normal state. The two friends were taken into custody KEXK first and they con— fessed, claiming that their only involvement was in helping to dispose of the body, The grand jury indicted all four. One of the MEéXE accom— plices was acquitted and the case against the other was KSXHES nol prossed in return for their testifying against Chambers and Shaw. Chambers maintained that he was innocent, but both he and Shaw were convicted and sentenced to hang. They were ridden on a wagonette , seated on their coffins, to the gallows outside of Iuverne on Oct, 30, 1903, and both men sang and prayed all of the way from the jil  to the site of execution where some 5,000 witnesses had gathered. A company of militia was present to maintain order, Shaw spoke first from the gallows, ddmltblng that he had killed Champlon but saying that he had done so in a field and not in his thome as the witnesses had testified, He said that Chambers was totally innocent and should not be hanged, Chambers, in his farewell address, maintained that he was innocent but was not afraid to die. — When the trap fell, Shaw‘s neck was broken, but Chambers strangled to death over a period of 13 minutes»  Birmingham NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., 10—30—1903  M<?WM27 AW / —3/[— / Je3

big_ocr: CHARLZSSTON s Taylor  Charleston, a 33—year—old black man with a high degree of. i ntelllgence was a laborer in Birmingham, Ala, At one time, he had some difficulty with another black man named Will Hardy and a definite enmity afmted between them. In the Fall of 1901, they met on First avenue in Pirmingham and Charleston drew a revolver and emptied it in Hardy‘s body. Hardy, who was one-legged, made an unsuccessful attempt to es— cape but was hindered in doing so by his infirmity, After the killing Charleston made the statement that he wished that Hardy had another life so that he could kill him again, His defense was self—defense as he claimed that Hardy had threatened to kill him on a number of occasions, but when it was shown that the murdered man was unarmed, Charleston was convicted and sentenced to die, He was hanged before a large crowd in the Jefferson County Yail Yard at Birmingham on Sept. 5; 1902 fFrior to his executlon, he made a rather eloquent address from the scaffold which he closed with a prayer. April 28, 1995 CLISBY, Willie  Willie Clisby, black, 47, electrocuted Alabama State Prison (Jefferson) April 28, 1995. A cemetery employee, he had axed to death Fletcher Handley, 58, a former co- worker, who had become disabled as the result of an accident. Motive was robbery and loot was six silver- certificates with a face value of $80.00. Date of crjme was Nov. 7, 1979. He had killed his landlady earlier and was sentenced to 27 years on 2nd degree conviction in that case; no last words. Clisby & Handley had worked together at Elmwood Cembtery in B'ham. Drew near this place, ' was hanged today, The gallows was erccted half a mile from the court-house and inclosed, Several hundred were present, but thehanging was witnessed only by officers and representatives of thepress,. Having eaten heartily  \  and taken a drink of whisky, he lit a cigar, and, surroun- ded by guards, took his seat on his coffin and was driven to the gallows, Be confessed his sgullt in a firm voice, and besought the negroes to regard the whites as their best friends, etc, The trap was sprung at 1;20, He was dead in fifteen mlnuteo. COLEMAN, Calvin _ ' "Montgomery, Ala., July 26, 1907-Sheriff Beiser fooled theﬁ | mobld citl;ens who had sought admission to the hanging of ‘Calvin #Coleman, a negro, today, by pulling off the execu- tion shortly after six o'clock before more than fifty, specially invited, came down town, Before 7 o'clock the body had been sent out, Coleman died for the murder of  J, A, Finley, a white man, who was first killed and then whittled into mincemeat with a big knife, On the scaffold  he implicated a white saloon man and another negro, saying the white man killed Finley and he helped cart off the body,"  BIRMINGhAMZNEhB Blrmlngham Alabama, July 26, 1907  1/007me
big_ocr: ylation etl w‘,“ Aae ceo ere armel peroneal oie fren ce to tut-MA;  | Black, hanged, Montgomery, Als., on July 26, 1907, .  | "Montgomery, July 26 = Calvin Coleman, the negro condemned for the  _ murder of J. A, Finley, a white man, met his death on the gallows this morning at 61/12 a clock,. The negro met death calmly, and mounted the platform on which the trap was set with steps that neither laggared nor fatlered, His last confession was spoken in a clear voice, with= out the slightest tremor, and was heard distinctly by all present .in the room in which the execution took place, In his confession, he said: ‘Gentlemen: I want to tell you all I am not the gullty one,!‘ Then he spke some words implicating in the crime ? white men, one of whom is at present in the city, Continuing, he saidi !I beliove I am going home to rest where you can‘t hang men any more, There won‘ t be ény hanging over there, I hope to meet you all in heaven,.‘ The trap was sprung by the sheriff and the negro s body shot into spaces Death wags caused from strangulation, his neck not having been braken.' by the fall, It mas L3 minutes from the time of his fall before the doctor pronounced him dead, A touching incident of the execgzégﬁwmas- when Calvin Coleman s father, the Rev, Anderson Coleman, asc he  gallows to bid his son goodbye, Throwing his arms about his neckk . the aged father kissed his son upon his lips and f#ifbke a few words into his ear, Shen, with a Last grasp of his son‘s‘ hand, and with eyes dimmed with tears, the fatgher descended the steps and waited outside of the room until the And," JOURNAL, Atlanta, Georsis, July | P6, t907 — (1Ll11l,) . a  ‘7’6’W/f5/ CLS ( Maia)

big_ocr: John ard OIT] Hover . / _//—/gn %,  Collier and Smith, Morgam Co., Ala,, black men, were in the Decatur clothing store omed by a Mr, Bloodwoth late on the afternoon of Jane 12, 1905, when Bloodworth‘s daughter, Miss Belle Bloodworth, brought him his suppere They heard Miss Bloodworth telephone her mother and state that she would be home shortly» When she left the store, they followed her, leaving behind Smith‘s fourteen—year—old son who was accompanying theme Mrs& Bloodworth did not arrive at home and that night a search party was formed which found her body in x®xy a back alley» She had been raped and then bludgeoned and stabbed to death, Collier and Smith were arrested and charged with the crime several days later when Smith‘s son told authorities that they had followed her from the store and that XXEEK his father had returned home late that night, Later he heard his father and Collier arguing and each accused the other of the crimes» Because of the intensity of local feeling, they were carried to the Jeffer— son County Jail in Birmingham for safekeeping and when they were re— turned to Decatur for their trial and later for their execution they were accompanied and guarded by National Guardsmen» Bothjrrere hanged in Decatur on June 16, 1905, and both protested their cence until their deaths, The rope on Smith‘s neck slipped and he fell to the ground exclaiming: "I am free Yest Yes.!" He was promptly taken back to the top of the gallows and hanged again.  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, June 16, 1905/

big_ocr: COLLINS ;, Roosevelt  Collins, a 3l—year—old black man, lived in rural Calhoun Co, , Ala. On July 13, 1936, he crept up behind a white farmer‘s wife as she worked in ‘&Ahe Alexandria Community, threw a coat over her head and dragged her intokthe woods where he raped her. Afterwards, perhaps in atonement, he offered her a signet ring which she refused. The woman positively identified Collins and he confessed the assault. Because of the intensity of the local feeling, he was held at Kilby Prison until his trial, His attorneys requested a change of venue because of this feeling and the local newspaper publicity and, when this was refused, they requested a continuance until the atmosphere would be more conducive to an impartial trial but this also was re— fused,. After Collins had been convicted and sentenced to die, these refusals and the fact that no blacks were on the trial jury were the basis of an appeal to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed the conviction unanimously, Collins was electrocuted at Kilby Prison on June ll, 1937. 4  DOTHAN EAGLE, Dothan, Alabama, ¥KI¥XX June 11, 1937. 174 SOUTHERN REPORTER 296  ‘" P 2. ¢ a C Z Arrested on July 1h, 1936, Victim was 25—years=old, Was spirited out of town while 1,500 mettering citizens pa ked a 10—bhlock area surrounding jail, Hustled into highway patrol car and rushed to Kilby Prison, Victim the mother of 3 children, Argest came after streets of Anniston had surged with restless men for 2 hrs, while manhunters prowled through tangled vegetation of a woodland swamp in search,. After attacking woman, Collins wounded a posseman with a shotgun blast, From Montgomery} Gov, Graves ordered 50 more troops to Anniston to augment the 200 already on duty, Victim sent to Birminghan hospital, Evidence linking him was a pair of water=soaked trousers, rolled into a ball and wrapped in an overcoat; a ring; a pair of shoes and other articles of clothing. Waman overpowered on 7—13 as she was setting out tomato plants in garden of home,. Warning her he would kill her if she scremmed, he covered head with an over— coat and dragged into a nearby thicket, Attack witnessed by neighbor woman who ran $ mile down road to shout an alarm into a farm telephone  circuit. . $ } CHARLESTON NEWS AND COURIER, Charleston, S. C., July 15, 1936 «

big_ocr: f LPs / F779 COOu ., a  Cook, a 23—year—old black man, lived in the Avondale section of Birmingham, Ala, He had been arrested on several occasions and  had served terms both on the City‘s streets and in the mines, On the night of May 14, 1898, he was in the process of robbing a  store in the Avordale section near the Cain Statlon of the East Lake electric line when his movements were overheard by John Black— burn and John Evans, conductors for the line, who were walking home to their boarding house. Thev summoned the proprietor of the busli= ness and the three men altered and took Cook into custody,. They performed a casual search but overlooked a razor—~sharp knife that Cook had in his possession,. As they were walking Cook to a tele phone to summon a policeman, Cook pu'L'Lnd the knife, stabbed Black— burn through the heart and ran, When the Sheriff arrived, he bought dogs and they traced Cook to his home about one—half mile away wheres they : found him in bed pretending to be asleep. Cook de—  nwci that he had been the bur glar who had murdered Blackburn but both Evans and the store owner positively identified him, He was  4  tried, convicted and sentenced to death and , following a valiant fight by his attorneys to save his life, he was hanged in the  u64r“”5ﬂ?(buﬁb”<jhl.aﬁ Birmingham on June 30, 18699. From the gallows Cook, who had been an active Church member, swore for the last time that he was innocent of the crime and expressed his willingness to die for the crime of another EXXKEKXXKE even as Jesus had been innocently put to death,  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, BIRMINGHAM, Alabama ; June 30, Lt

Crime committed in 1876, Caldwell also black - and married to woman with whom Cook was having an affair, _ Caldwell found about and they had words, Shortly fater- wards, Cook shot and killed Caldwell and then severed his head from his body, This article datelined Tuscum- 5131 Ala,, but says execution took place in Greenville, _ _so 1 am carrying as a Butler Co, execution, Found no - - appeal., 22'M53kun --NATIONAL POLICE GAZETTE, 2=1-18 79, page ten, Col, one -

big_ocr: COOPER, Alfred (Alf)  Cooper, a 23—year—old black man, was born and raised in Montgomery, Alabama, and subsequently lived for xkk%® awhils in Pensacola, Fla., where he was suspected of having killed a man though it was never proved, He then moved to Birmingham, 4la., where, in FSD:  18894, he and his friend, Jeff Googer, got into an argument at Cooper‘; holuse in Ens ey over some furniture that both claimed to own,. Goo ger opened his shirt, bared his breast, and dared Cooper to shoot  him,. Cooper picked up a revolver and shot him through the chest, killing him instantly, He then fled Birmingham and was not captured untill April when he was taken into custody in Brewton, Ala, Convicted  il  and sentenced to death, he was hanged at She Jefferson County Jail  in irmingham on July 11, 1890. His last words were! "Farewell, world, you ain‘t no.friend of mine,." His neck was not broken and  he died of strangulation, A detective from Montgomery who witnessed the execution described him as a bad and desperate character and said that he had been arrested numerous times in Montgomery for crimes ranging from crap shooting and burglary to rape and murdst s.     BIR MINGHAM DAILY NWS, Birmingham, Ala., 7—10—1890 and 7—11+1890 According to Sexton‘s Ledger for Southside Cemetery, Birmingham, Cooper —was—25 at time —of death —Ltr. dtd. 2=7—1985 from SHariiyn  Davis Bahn Barefield, 1108 28th South Street, Apre 1, Birmingham, Al 35205

big_ocr: CURRY, Elbert  Curry, a young Talladega, Ala., black man, was seen leaving the downtown section of Talladega with James Pincknsy Dobbins, a well» to—do white man who was, at the time, intoxlcated on the evening of Feb, 1, 1900, ostensibly to show Dobbins where a friend of Curryds lived. Early the next morning some students at Talledega College discovered Dobbins! completely nude body, mutilated by eleven.cuts and stabs, any one of which might have proved Jatal. An officer who remembered having seen Curry and Dobbins tog gether on the preceding night, checked and found a nearby house whnrm Curry had changed his bloodv pants and also left Dobklné coat, the dead man‘s other clothlng being found near his body. Curry was arrested.—at the home of his grandmother and not only con— fessed the slaying, but gave the arresting officers a notebook whau had belonged to Dobbins,. He refused to give any reason for the murder, claiming that both he and Dobbins had been drunk at the [13.13.63 bu Wai To £ 8 i bor ~s Dobbins was hfnégn tg ﬁi§iegégséfggdhlbolgéjgﬁ gﬁe Effhgzéiqﬁ .S  death. Curry received a speedy trial xxusx where he was conviated ang sentenced to hang. He seemed indifferent to his fate and the ministers who spent his last few days with him ascribed this to the fact that he was XXKSXSKXE ignorant and had always mixed with the lowest type people and roamed the streets,. During religious ser— vices SWXXKE immediately prior to his execution, he sang a song  that he had composed the night before entitled"The Lord Hath Answered Prayer." He made no sta tement from the gallows, hut he did ask the jaller to remove the bouquet from his coat and he gave him ten cents for sach of the ministers who had been with him throughﬁis ordeals He was hanged in the Talladega County Jail on May 18, 1900.  e  Birmingham NEWS, Birmingham, Ala, May 18, 1900

big_ocr: DANIELS, Henry, Jr., and ROBINSON, Curtis  Daniels, 19—years—old, and Robinson, 20—years=—old, were black resi— dents of Mobile, Ala., who were employed as Raborers at Turner Termi— nals in that city, On several occasions they had discussed the possi— bility of having sexual relations with a white woman,. One night around 10 o‘clock, after they had attended a meeting at the C. I. 0, meeting hall, they decided to lay in wait and Rape the first white woman who they could find. They stood at the mouth of an alley on Texas St, and when a white matron who had jeft work and was going home passed, they grabbed her from behind and dragged her about 50 feet into the alley where they took turns raping her. After theyhad completed the assault, they ran down Texas St. to Dearborn St, where they separated, The woman, who had been beaten and choked during | the assault, reported it immediately and after several innocent blacks had been taken into custody as suspects, a black woman who had seen Daniels and X&KXKKXSK Robinson running from the scene of the crime provided the police with their names and they were taken into custody. The woman who had been attacked identified both of them and they both  confessedAt their trials, which were held separately, both repudiate their confessions and sdid that they had made them out o? Ea re Both the black woman who had seen them running and the woman who had been raped identified them at their trials and evidence was offered showing that the trousers that both had worn bore evidence of sexual intercourse and carried dirt on the knees and legs that matched that found at the scene of the rape. Both were convicted and sentenced to die. Their cases were appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which afffimed the convictions and they were electrocuted at the Alabama tate Prison on August 13, 1943. f i pot  11 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 732 * fﬁ‘iwf ec 9  11 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 756 rX to PS _ " 2 » * U As. big_ocr: Titi t Yo t C Yn cod  DAUGHDRILL, Colin -  Daughdrill, a 26—year—eold white man, was the profilgate offspring of ~—Atstinguilshed parentage, his pormptfatker maternal grandfather being ~ __a probate judge of Etowah County and his father having been at one ___  time a wealthy Mobile Co. landowner, Daughdrill was born and raised        ~——in Etowah Co, where he married and became the father of two children, __in 1892, he was assisting his uncle who was a railroad agent,. _ A man named Armstrong Stewart was the yardmas ter ard when he and Daugh—     ¥~~Mﬂmmmmmm§wm rushed to his uncle‘s  _ _Mkm side, drew a pktol and killed Stewart, Even though he claimed — self—defense, he fled to Wyoming and the Indian Territory where he     ~——remained for two years until Stewart‘s brother, who was a witness to the unprovoked killing e f  damaging testimony against him, He then returned to Etowah Co. and     ~——~gave himself up on the indictment which had been returned against  ,,_y_%54nm§n,ciw,w§§pmmza_mlagﬁwmom.._m~mnignugﬁec,~ 21, 1895 ie was gambling with a saloon keeper named W. At the tlme, Barnes was discussing the purchase of some glass flasks with a XLAKXEXXXXI® $34 . + Montgomery salesman, J» I. Bates. The various brochures and prics lists — were spread on the bar betw een the two men and Daughdrill pushed them on the floor, Bates turned to remonstrate with him  and Daughdrill drew a pistol and killed him, He claimed that he fired in self—defense as he thought that Batés was going for KXX a pistél. But the salesman was unarmed and Barnes stated that he had made no threaténing gesture,. The speculation was that Daughdrill had entered the saloon hoping to pick a fight with Barnes who he actaully wanted to kill, The ‘fact that he was out on bond in a pre— tious killing weighed heavily against him and he was convicted and sentenced to death,. He was hanged in Gadsden on March 5, 1897.  His last words, spoken to a brother who was a witness at his execu— tion, were: "Make a man of yourself," His neck was not broken by  the fall and he strangled to death in the presence of the 21; wit nesses. big_ocr: Celle  y . """ ogee TFs!  Davidson, a black man, and his brother lived and worked on the Lowndes CB., near Brage, Ala., plantation owned by a Mp. Hamilton,. On several. occasions, the wikkk white oversebr of the plantation, Mr, Shanks, had occasion to reprimand Davidson for laziness. On July 21, 1890, Shanks found Davidson and his brother lounging by a fence, both armed with shotguns and evidently planning to go hunting. Onee again Shanks reprimanded Davidson for When D&vidson %&x replied in xxkxp what Shanks considered an impudent manner, the overseer started to dismount from his horse and Davidson shot him. After Shanks had fallen to the ground, Davidson shot him a second time and Shanks drew his pistol and shot the black man in his leg. Shanks was carried to a nearby cabin where he lingered for a week before he finally died, Tried, convicted and sentenced to hang, Davidson was executed at Hayneville, Ala,, on June 26, 1891.  June BIRMLNCHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Ala,, May 16 and Mxg 26, 1891.  JP

big_ocr: EDAVIS, George B..___________ t >. a as  Davis, a white native of north Georgia, deserted his legal wife there and took another woman to Columbus where they lived together as man and wife for some time, In 188h he moved to Seale, Russell Co., Ala,, where he obtained work as a farm laborer, Shortly afterwards, he brought his mistress there from Columbus and even though they NEKXXXKXAXXXXNX®XKXXA went through a marriage ceremony after their arrival in Seale, they did not live together, Instead, he rented a house about two miles from the farm where he was employed and she stayed there with him visiting her frequently, Davis began having an affair with the sister of another young white man in the area, Archi— bald Reems, and when Reems learned about the situtation, he remonstra—~ ted with Davis and told him to stop seeing his sister as he was a married man, In September, 1885, Davis Waylaid Reems in the woods and shot him in the back with both barrels of a shotgun loaded with squirrel shot, He then went over to where Reems lay wounded and while his victim pleaded for his life, saying that hf he was spared he would  swear that he had been shot by an accident and not involve Davis in any way, Davis drew his knife and cut Reems‘ throat so deeply that  his head was almost severed from his body, He then bludgeoned the  corpse so violently that the stock of his gun was broken. "Davis NEXT YORK TIMES, New York, N. Y., June 29, 1886 1 attempted to drag the body to the river but the task was too great for him and he went to the home of black man who lived nearby, told him mhat he had done and promised him Reems! boots if he would drage the body to the river and throw it in, Believing that the black man was disposing of the corpse, Davis went to the home of Reems‘ mother and told her that her son had been involved in some difficulty had had to leave the area for a few days, He explained that he had been sent to get some food and clothing which the old woman gave to him, Davis returned to the scene of the mrder to be certain that the body had been consigned to the river and there found the black man and one of his friends who he had summoned, Once again Davis admitted killing Reems and justified his action by saying that Reems had falsely accused him of stealing a load of oats. He then wandered off into the woods and managed to escape capture for two days after which he was taken into custody and charged with the murder, He never denied his guilt though he continued to maintain that the murder had occurred because of false accusations of theft and he was convicted ahd sentenced to die, At his execution at Seale on June 26, 1886, he made a speech from the gallows in which he confessed murdering Reems in anger and warned other young men not to marry more than once and got to tell women that they loved them unless it was true. hi closed his ‘talk by saying: "I hope my death will save ten thousand,

big_ocr: pat" | J. / 927 DeVaughn, a 35—@eareold black man, was a native of Birmingham, Ala., the son of a respectfd former slave, As a young man, he had moved to Richmond, Va., and there served a ten—year prison sentence for the murder of a black woman,. After his release from the penitentiary, he returned to the home of his father in Birmingham and obtained employ» ment as a laborer with the Stockham Pipe and Fittings Company,. On the afternoon of January 19, 1929, he went kxm rabbit hunting and was re—» | turning home ‘that night when he approached a parked car in which Au« burn B, Moore, the Superintendent of Safety and Sanitation for the Southern Railroad, was parked with Mrs, Ruby Thornton, When Moore  saw him walking towards the car, he got outside and raised the hood, DeVaught walked to within a few feet of Moore and shot in the face with the gun, Mrs, Thornton leaped from the car which was parked in  a secluded area 200 tyards off the Ketona Road in the Roebuck section of Birmingham and fled screaming. DeVaughh followed and overtook  her, shooting her in the back of the head, He then returned to Moore‘ body and robbed it of $22 and his watch and chain, After an ivestiga=— t Thot mat ihe mative for ths doubts all "— bers of the DeVaughn famiXy were taken to police headquarters and questioned as they were tke family lixing nearest the scene of the crime, Horace finally broke down and confessed when officers implied | \ that they were going to charge one of his brothers with the murder,  le said that when Moore had gotten out of the car, he had cursed him | and made a motion as he was going for his hip pocket, DeVaughn! said he was afraid the white man was reaching for a pistol and that he had fired in defense of his life, His conviction was not appealed and | on April 6, 1927, he became the first man to die in the electric chair at Alabhama‘s Kilby Prison,  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala,, Jan. 20, Jan, 21, Feb. 1, XXH 1927  DeVaughn died with a prayer on his lips and one of Moore‘s brothers came all of the way from Kansas to witness the exkcution, Dothan Eagle, Dothan, Ala., April 6, 1927.

big_ocr: Gales t __ 00 71776 LZEY, B $LD®£z aa If 7 /  Elzey, a black man born in 1868 near Ualtonﬁau killed another black youth when he was only lli—years—ohd in an argument over a mar— ble game and was sentenced to 20 years in the "tate Prison,. He was paroled after serving 8 months and went to Atlanta where he became a — member of a gang of robbers and murderers that operated throughout the Southeast. Prior to his execution, he confess@dd that he had takeng part in no less than twenty—one murderey He expressed regret only for the killing of his 7O—yeareold grandmother, Rosa McCazver » at 1"must-son s Station, Ca., who he said was shot in one of the gang‘s robberies,. He had led them to his grandmother‘s after she sold some stock, and when they had killed and robbed the old woman, they burned the house down to. obliterate evidence of the crime. Other murders took place in Louisiana, Tennessee , Georgia and Alabama, Early in January, 1889, he and two others went to the Cobb Co., Ga., farm home of Wldowed Mrs, William Hargroves for whom Elzey had worked: briefly, killed her with an ax androbbed her. Elzey fled to Alabama where he teamed up with other black members of the Gangs. Gilbert Lowe, Lawrence Johnson, Henry Joe, Lindsay Malachi. — One night in late January, 1889, a white man, Js We Meadows a who «#  had been drinking approached them and asked if they knew the direc tions to a woman‘s house. They offered to show him the way but in— stead led him to the top of Red Mountain in Jefferson Co. and blud~ geoned him to dea th before robbing him off his money and clothes. None of the group were suspected of Meadow‘s murder, On March 21, 1889, Elzey entered the Birmingham grocery owned and operated by Mrs, B, M, Lundle and when the woman turned her back on him, he bludgeoned her unconscious and robbed her, Mrs, Lundle lived, how» ever, and was able to, identify Elzey as hem assailant and when ques— tioned about the‘Meadows murder he confessed and named his accompli— ces, one of whom, Cilbert Lowe, preceded him to thk gallows. After  his conviction, Elzey confessed to the killing of "rs., Hargroves and his other crimes,. He was hanged at the Jefferson County Jail on April, 18, 1890, His execution was preceded by a lengthy sermon from the Minister who had counseled with him during his imprisonment and a prayer that lasted for six minutes, After the hanging, the minis= ter stood by the door to the room housing the gallows, hat in hand, and solicited contributions from the spectators as they filed out. big_ocr: _ FARMER, Will _  7 ea  Farmer, a black 2h=year=old native of Pickens C, Ala, was a tenant | farmer who lived with his wife in Tuscaloosa County» Farmer was ex» _ . ceedingly.jealous of his wife though, from accounts of the period, he had no —cause to bes — At — any rate, they quarreled frequently because of his possessiveness,. On the morning of August 20, 1893, she was found | alone on the bed in their cabin. Her throat had been so horribly cut — «~—with—a—razor, that only a few threads of muscle were holding it to ——— _the trunk of the body, Farmer had disappeared and he was the immedi—_ ate suspect, The sheriff decided that he would probably goto his <father‘s home in Pickens County and he was waiting for Farmer two ~ _ days latery WAENMXKXKXEX® and took him into custody when Farmer attempt» ed to enter his father‘s homes He denied his guilt of the murder of ~Ah#s wife but he was taken back to Tuscaloosa, charged with the crime ~ __and placed in jail, The black conmunity was so indignant that they __ organized a mob XNKZWNXXHE on the night of August ?2nd and intended taking him from the —J ail —and him, but some whiles —persons ~  ersuaded then to let the law take its course. _ Tried, convicted. and _ ggntencgd tgeﬁlang mmgg was executilegf gn geaioosg n Jan, T1833, before forty witnesses, On the scaffold, he confessed to his crime  and warmed others not to follow his example, He said that he had confessed to Jesus and was going straight to God, The fall failed to bresk his neck and he strangled to death, finally expiring fifteen minutes after the trap had been sprunge  BIRMINGHAM MILY NEWS, Birmingham, Ala» 1—5—189h. big_ocr: FIELDS, Samuel  Fields, a black man of low repute, was employed on a tuppentine farm near Dothan, Ala, He was very jealous of his wife and for no reason other than that, he shot her in the left breast three times on August h, 1897, killing her instantly, He fled from their house and was trailed by dogs and a posse for six miles before being captured,. Originally sentenced to hang on Dec. 8, 1897, he received a two—day respite from the Governor in order that the execution might occur on the same day as another man sentenced to hang on Dec, 10, and he was hanged from a gallows constructed in the jail yard at Abbeville, Ala., on that day,  A twenty foot enclosure was built around the gallows, but it had  a curtain which was raised in order that the two men might speak to the three thousand persons gathered to witness the execution, Eafh spoke in a laughing and jesting manner for over an hour. Nei— ther showed any fear of death and both seemed to treat the entire affair as a comedy, They both claimed that their crimes were com—  letely justified and called on a 1 i End ng§£n to raise their hands §%1£§§&S§§§3eéb%§§§8 hgﬁftes, blues BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala,, 12—10—1897  Abbeville TIMES, Abbeville, Ala,, 12—10—1897, 10—22—1897 and 8—13—1897

big_ocr: Fincher, a 30=yeareold white man, was a farmer who lived in the Patton‘s Chapel community near Lincoln, Talladega Co,, Ala, On the morning of Feb, 6, 1923, he went by the home of a neighbor, 7, R. Bunn, and purchased some eggs which he placed in the pockets of his overalls, Armed with a shotgun, he said that he was hunting crows and left the house immediately after Bunn‘s 16—year=old stepdaughter, Maybelle McCullough, left to walk to the fanily‘s mail box located  . one mile away» Miss McCullough met another neighbor before she reached the box and he gave her the family‘s mail. At that time  she told him that she had seen Fincher in a wooded area through which she had to pass and that she was frightened of him, When she did not return home, her family became alarmed and shortly afterwards, Fincher arrived at the Bunn house with an axe which he wanted Mr, Bunn to grind, Bunn informed him that he had to search for the girl and Fin— cher agreed to join in the hunt, Her body, crammed into a stump hole made by an uprooted tree, was found in the woods, 50=yernis from the path on which she had walked and within calling distant from her home:  late that afternoon, She had been raped and h s 3 Fincher was arrested the next day on guspiggonegﬁghgiggdggglﬁ§xwgf@es'  found on leggings that he had worn earlier XKXE the morning of her disappearance but that he had left at home when he returned to her house with the axe, RBloodstains were also found on his knife and gun, \ because of the possibility of mob violence, he was taken to the | _ Jefferson County Jail in Birmingham and while there he gold several conflicting and fantastic storkes before he asked to be allowed to  see Mr, and Mrs, Bunn, When they arrived with the Sheriff of Talla« dega County, he solicited a promise from tham that they would not  use what he had to say against him and admitted having seen and talked with the girl, He also stated that his going to the house with the axe was a subterfuge as he went there to see what was happening.  Mr, and Mrs, Bunn both testified against him at his trial and he was convicted on strong circumstantial evidence and sentenced to die,  The conviction was affirmed on appeal, He requested that the hymn "Will There Be Any Stars in My Crown" be sang immediately prior to  his execution, explaining that it was the last song that he had heard Miss McCullough play, and this was done at his execution at the Talla» dega jail on July 11, 1924, Prior to his execution, he was also allo wed to go outside the jail and address the 2,000 persons gathered in the courtyard and he said: "Farewell, everybody, Farewell, I am going an innocent man,— The crime they accuse me of is the most hideous ever committed in Talladega, but I am not gullty of it, Farewell," He then calmly renetered the jail and wen  the Lnalt while a clergymanj o S one f inet propery. big_ocr: FLETCHER, Earle [40 — 1 4C 6  Fletcher, a 23—year—old black native of Huntsville,rAla., was living in Elyton, Jefferson Co., when he killed another black man named Harris and was sentenced to fifteen years in prison He was assigned to work in the Flat Top coal mines and early in 1906 he got into an argument with another convict—worker, Bob Payne, who he killed with  a pick,. The argument and murder occurred in the presence of several other convicts, all of whom testified against Fletcher at his trial and he was convicted and sentenced to die, After his conviction, a physician was sent to his cell by the Governor of Alabama to test his sanity and the physician ruled that he was sane and accountable for his actions. He was hanged in the yard of the Jefferson County Jail in Birmingham on August 10, 1906. From the scaffold he made a state» ment in which he was highly critical of the trial judge who had gone fishing without granting him a writ of habaes corpus while KXX he had granted a write to a white man who had been found guilty of murder, The nosse slipped when the trap was sprang and the knot slid around  to rest underneath Fletcher‘s chin. His neck was not broken by the fall and he died of strangulation. The Birmingham News, Birmingham, Ala., 6—30—1906 and 8—10—1906  "June 27, l90£,..was found guilty by the jury and sentenced to be hanged in just two hours and ten minutes from the time his case was called in court," JOURNAL, Atlanta, GA, June 27, 1906 (13:3)

big_ocr: \ KEITH, Joe  Keith, a AZ 29—year—old black man, was employed as a laborer on the plantation owned by Robert Atkinson in the Green Briar district of Limestone Co., Ala, On Nov,. l4, 1948, he had been drinking heavily when he went to the house whets another worker, Enos Foster, lived. He told Foster that their employer wanted them to move some things that afternoon and they left the house together. Approximately thirty minutes later Keith returned alone and went into the house where Mrs., Foster was preparing supper and, without warning, struck her three times on the head with an iron pipe,. Her KKXKEXLZ 8O—year— old mother, Mrs. Queenie Clements, who was visiting ran to her daugh = ter‘s rescue and Leith bludgeoned her to death. Mrs. Clements! body was discovered at the door to the house XXXEX that evening by Mr., At— kinson and Foster‘s body was found about fifty feet away near the well house. Mrs, Foster survived her wounds and Keith, still wearing the bloody overalls, was arrested and confessed that he had killed Foster when an argument broke out between them, He said that Mrs. Foster had attacked him with a knife and thagmﬁzilg 2g i0ﬁldhngt re— avi struck her with the pipe, he a e at he ha ( ﬁi?gzg ﬁfgfnglements when she entegeg ihe affray. Mrs., Foster testlz fied against him at his trial where he was convicted of the murder o Mrs, Clements and sentenced to die,. The case was affirmed by the Alabama Supreme Court and when it went_be£e$a~the~eeverﬁnrwonfamplea“ for clemency, those opposed to granting a commutation thstified that the beatings were "unbelieveably brutal," The Governor declined to in ervene and Keith went to his death in. Alabama‘s electric chair  on July 21, 1950. His last words were: "The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh away,"  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama July 21, 1950.  46 SOUTHERN REPORTER end SERIES 705

I believe these are probably the s ame; | "Tuscaloosa, 12-29-1928=Chief Deputy Sheriff Foster Kin | and Deputy Sheriff W, I, Huff spent Monday night at Buhl | | investigating the murder of Charlie Parker wo was found dead in the woods near Buhl Christmas Day with the back  of his head shot away by a load of shot, The officers are holding Ed Skelton and Jim Franklin who have been offi~ clally charged with murder in connection with the crime, pair of bloody overalls were found on the wall of Ed Skel- ton's home near Buhl and othercircumstantial evidence secured by the officers against the men held, The case is nowin the hands of Solicitor E, L, Clarkson with all of  the facts. , Efforts are being made to raise bond of $1,000 for Skelton s release and it is thought he will be able to secure the amount, Franklin has made mo move to secure bail,  B!HAM AGE HERALD, 12=30=1925,

big_ocr: September 15th, 1899 GARDNER, Henry  Gardner, an 18=—year—old Mobile, Ala., bAack man, was arrested on June 14, 1899, and charged with carnal knowledge of a white girl who was under ten years of age,. After his arrest, there was con— siderable local indignation, and a lynching was averted only by  the prompt actions of the local authorities, Convicted and sen— tenced to be hanged on August 18, 1899, he was granted a respite  by the Govelmor when he received an affidavit from one of the jurors to the effect that he had been influenced. After the expira— tion of the respite, the Governor refased to intervene further and Gardner was hanged in the Mobile County Jail Yard on Sept. 15, 1899, The execution was botched in that the rope had not been properly tied, and when the trap was released, Gardner fell heavily to the ground. He was carried back to his cell for ten minutes while new preparations were being made and then returned to the gallows in great agony from the injuries sustained by his fall,. His last words  were, spoken when he cried out to his mother in the audience: "Your boy is suffering now, MKE Mama," " TCX RMIN E) a

ocr_text: GARRETT, Israel  4 - I  | "Alabama's Gov, James E., Folsom Thursday refused an appeal.!  | for clemency for Israel Garrett, 45-year-old Russell Co. _  | Negro who has twice been convicted of murder, and ordered the Negro put to death in the electric chair at Kilby Fyi-» son shortly after midnight Thursday,. Garrettm sentenced | to death for the 1915 slaying of a Negro woman, Ruby Toll1« ver, near Crawford, admitted killing his wife in 1932; but denied his guilt of the second crime. At the time he al- legedly killed the Tolliver woman, he was on parole from a life sentence, the Associated Press reported." Electrocu- ted on May 23, 1947. Columbus ENQUIRER, Columbus, Ga., 5=23-191;7  Afynciitenn (2) I - 2 f bkiwna
big_ocr: GARRETT, Israel  Garrett, a l;3—year—old black resident of Russell Cor, Ala., had served a prison sentence for assault with intent to ravish prior to killing his wife in 1932, He was then sentenced to life imprisonment and served time in prison until 1943 when he was paroled and returned to Russell County,. Two and one—half years after his parole, he went to the home ofrfuby Tolliver, a black woman who lived near Crawford,  and forced him to accompany her into the woods where he raped her,  He then cut her to death with a knife and buried her body in a shallow grave, — Garrett confessed shortly after he was arrested but he subse— quently repudiated his confession and maintained that though he had killed his wife thirteen years earlier, he was innocent of having raped and killed Mrs, Tolliver. Convicted and sentenced to die, his conviction was upheld by the Alabama Supreme Court and when the Gover—  nor refused his plea for clemency, he was electrocuted at the Albama "tate Prison on May 23, 191;7,  The Columbus ENQUIRER, Columbus, Georgia, May 23, 1917, 29 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 8     $4 A + §!

big_ocr: GERMANY, Allen —  Germany, a L}—yeareold black man, was a resident of Birmingham, Ala. After he had been tried and acquitted of the mirder of his first wife, he married a woman of questionable reputation who was much younger than he, He and his second wife, Jimmie, got into an argument over her attentions to other men early on the evening of April 2h, 1924, and, in a jealous frenzy, he practically decapitated her with a straig razor, The next day he surrendered himself to the police and admitted the killing, but claimed self=—defense, saying that Jimmie had threat, ened to kill him, His conviction and the death sentence were affirmed by the Alabama Supreme Court in a unanimous mflemorandum de— cision and the State Board of Pardons refused to r ecommend clemency, The Sheriff of Jefferson County and other jail officials, citing the facts that Germany had confessed to the murder; that he had been a model prisoner; that he was a black of unusual intellect; and that he bad killed his wife while in a jealous rage, rasied the money for a social worker to go to Montgomery and intercede with the Governor in his behalf, but Governor Brandon defused to intervene and Germany  was hanged in the Jefferson County jail yard on March 7, 1925, being pronounced dead 11 minutes after Int" t ap Fell, fe madd a" dying  statement from the scaffold in which he saids "I amydying unafraid, I do not fear death, I do pot believe that I should die on the— gallows. I do not believe that any man should, God never intended that man should tie that way, I offered to serve out ny life in any way that I was fitted, be the years many or few, to make up for my crime, but they would not have Its I am dying. I could do much with another chance, but I haven‘t it," After the noose had been placed about his neck, he was asked if it was too tight and he replied: "Just don‘t choke me to death," His last words, spoken just before the trap was sprung, were: "Are you all ready? I am," Before beginning the death watch, he gave the Chief Deputy two letters, one to each of two sis— ters, one of whom he excoriated for having betrayed him and sonspired against him , the other whom he bede a fond farewell.  102 Southern 917. BIRMINGHAM AGE HERALD» 4<25; 6—18, 1924; 3=234—3«=53—3«63

big_ocr: GOLSON, Will. 2 — 9—/ goo  Golson, an Alabama black man, escaped from the jail at Prattville, Ala., where he was belng held on a grand larceny charge and made his way to Birmingham where he was.joined by his wife and three chill» aren.  NEXFXEXKRXXE A warrant for his arrest had been issued in Mont— gomery on the charge of stealing a watch and when he was traced to Birmingham, the warrant was forwarded to the Sheriff‘s of flce there for his apprehension, On Sunday afternoon, Nov, 27, 1898, Chief Deputy Sheriff Robert Warnock, 40 years of age, and two associate Deputies went to the house in Third Alley where "olson was living  to arrest him, Warnock statloned XK&EXXKE his two associates at  the rea r door and he walked around to the front, being seen by Golson as he passed a window, As Warnock started up the steps to the porch, Golson opened the door and commenced firing hls revolver. Warnock drew a small weapon and returned the fire, but succeeded in only graming Golson‘s finge® as Golson closed the door after firing each round and did not present a target. Warnock was struck four times and died in a few minutes, Golson made his escape but was  \ CARY antured in a Smiths Ast : o captured in a Southside restaurant three days Later, His defense was that Warnock had opened the door and commenced firing without warning and that he had returned the fire in self—defense, but prior to his trial he confessed the actual details of the crime which he repeated on the gallows prior to his execution. Convic= ted and sentenced to death, his hanging was delayed by an appeal  to the State Supremes Court untill Feb,. 9, 1900, when he was hanged in the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham, Golwon was illiterate, but he evidently posskssed a good mind as he was able to memorize numerous verses from the Bible when they were read to him by the ministers who attended him during his last days and, converted to religon, he met his death calmly and without emotion, expressing his sorrow at having killed Warnocke A year after the murder, War— nock‘s widow who had been unbalanced by the crime, committed suicide by shooting herself through the temple with her husband‘s revolver,.  « 31111911” ”YA! {LPLIS‘ 3 R4 I'l’l..l’lbhdm, A184. 3 I: NIT’UWL’WT 9, 7.9()O Note: Golson‘s son, Willie Golson, hanged on same gallows for rape on June 8, 1923, See him,

big_ocr: GOSA, Wilmon  43—y car~ ofol Gosa, awplack veteran of World War II, was a laborer who lived in Tuscaloosa, Ala, He and his wife had been twice married to each other and XXXXKKXA twice divorced, and she had custody of their two children, an ll—year—old son and a S—year—old daughter, Sheila, Around dusk on the evening of January 27, 1959, after eating at the home of his uncle where he was staying, he went to the home of his wife, The front door was locked and she saw him attempting to force entry, She told the two children to follow her out the back door and the boy did —so,~ Sheila remained in the house and when Gosa erkrres forced his way inside he stabbed her to death with a butcher knife that he had obtained at his uncle‘s home, Shortly afterwards he wrecked his automobile and was taken into custody, At the time he admitted killing the child and said that he had done so to get even with his wife, He was sent to a State Hospital for a mental examination and, after he was ruled sane, he was returned to Tuscaloosa to stand trial, Gosa mainkasined that he had drank a bottle of rubbing aleohol before the crime and remembered nothing _ about it, At his trial where insanity was his defense, he said—that— he remembered nothing about being at the hoppital, Following his conviction, the case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court mainly on the grounds that the solicitor had asked a prejudicial question which,kxx though it was not answered, had prejudiced the minds of  the jurors, The court affirmed the conviction ruling that a preju= dicial question, not answered, was not harmful and he was electrocuted  at the *labama State Prison on August 31, 1962.  139 SOUTHERN (2nd) 321.  ‘Y800

big_ocr: caa, ten c. 7779  ~Grant, a 3Q—year—old white resident of Fensacola, Fla., was employed as a bus driver by the Florida Pulp and Paper Co. He was jealous of his second wife, Gertha, who had believed had been seeing other men and he had discussed these supposed infidelities w ith some of his co—workers, On the morning of March 8, 1947, he, Gertha and her Tégear—old son by a previous marriage, Richard, left Pensacola in his automobile and spent the day driving around in'“1abama, stopping for lunch at Fairhope and having a sandwich that afternoon at Brew— ton, Around seven o‘clock that evening, they were in Baldwin Co. when Grant stopped the automobile and asked Gertha to check and see if her door was fastened. As she turned her head, he drew a pistol from his belt and struck her. She Jumped from the car screaming  and he threw her to the ground and fired one shot into her body which he placed in the trunk of the car before driving off,. He stopped the car on one occasion, lifted the lid to the trunk and when he no— ticed that his wife was conscious, he fired another shot into her body, closed the 1id and drove of? again, Richard requested that he  his mother out of the trunk and he stopped the car at a bridgso éggfnéscggeg, lured the boy outside, knocked him over the head and  bushed him into the creekwwhere, he supposed, Richard drowned. He drove the car farther and then checked the trunk again, When  "a 4. t &  : , ' » inflicting a mortal wound, and buried her in a shallow grave by the  side of the road after removing her rings and watch, The body was discovered the next morning by a passing motorist who noticed her hand protruding from the ground and Richard, who was not drowned,  was found by the creek. Grant admitted having killed his wifs but he claimed that he had KZXZKXX become temporarily insane because of kr what he believed to be her infidelities and he also said that he had attempted to kill Richard because the boy kad withessed the pm shoot» ing of his mother and was making inquiries about her welfare, Richard testified against him at his trial and his plea of insanity failed to hold up, Convicted and sentenced to die, his case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which upheld the lower Court and he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on March 19, 1948. When  the switch was thrown, the executionsr discovered that he had failed to connect the current and Grant remained seated, breathing heavily, while adjustments were made and the chair was yeadled.  33 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 466  Cg<<525 'l/egééZéébécaﬁkv/Z/Z£;¢éj

big_ocr: GREEN,Eteptoe Tait > t. 92/67/5735 "3  ~—Green, a 33=—year=old black man, was born, raised, and had lived all— of his life in Sumter Co., Ala., where he was a tenant farmer, In ~1887, he persuaded Fmma Marr, the daughter of an aged black woman ——naned Harriet Marr—to—go and live —with—him. —Mrs. Marr—object—to ——— this arrangement and for the next three and one—half years, each              time that she and MB#X Creen met, a vigorous argument would ensue. —On— September 13,1891, —she—went—to—Green‘s house to make another ——— effort to persuade Imma to return home with her. Green and Emma Were working in the field when Mrs,. Marr arrived and when she went ——out —and —explained the nature—of her visit, Inma walked —to the—house — with her, Green later followed and started quarreling with Emma | __ over some accusations that Mrs, Marr had said that Green had made —— ——concerning—Enmma‘s disposal—of —a child —born—to them. —Green pulled ——— his knife and made an unsuccessful swipe at Emma and when he swung _ again, Mrs,. Marr stepped between them and he cut her throat, He — — —and Emma first hid —her. body in a shallow—grave_ about a mile from ——  his house and then he subsequently moved tm it to a sw wher  ——he buried ﬂ, % When”Mrsr'Magrwdi‘ not appear around gegmgwn é gouge sor for several days, suspicions were arouse and Green was taken into | custody for questioning. The sheriff formed a group that searched the area and they first discoverdd the shallow grave where Harriet Marr had first been buried. Still there was an underskirt that was identified as hers, Wagon tracks led fron there to a shelter mx at Green‘s place, and he was charged with murder, The body was not actually found for another week when it was discovered in the swampe Tried, convicted and sentenced to hang, Green finally con— fessed two days before his execution, He was hanged publicly in  . Livingston, Ala., on Sept,. 15, 1893» Green mounted the gallows: with what was described as an expression of agony on his face and when he spoke there was a tremor in his voice» He sang a song, parayed and then made a few remarks to his colored friends in which he acknowledged his crime and stated that he was ready to gos His neck was broken by the fall,  THE BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, 9—15—1893.  (Note: Green requested a change of venue which was denied, Was ‘tried three different times, convicted and sentenced to hang.  The Etate Supreme Court refused to affirm first two convictions and ordered re—trials, The third conviction was allowed to  stand. )

ocr_text: Sam Areenbill, Ala., Cont, a ¥  Sam Greenhill and Dave Dewberry, Tuscumbia negroes, both charged and convicted, Dweberry to Life imprison« ment, White was shot in head by Greenhill after he had arrested them for hunting on the reservation, His body found secreted in old cistern 12 hours later,. Officers worked on case some time before they were apprehended,  ._ They both confessed that Greenhill fired fatal shot  and Dewberry maintained that he assisted Greenhill in seretting body after death,  ABE HERRLD, 10-22-1920),
big_ocr: ﬁg) f Greenhill, a 35—year=old black man, was a resident of Tuscumbia, 412, On the morning of Nec. 8, 1923, he and his friend Dave Dewberry, armed ghth guns and accompanied by their dogs, went hunting on the U, 8. overnment Reservation at Nitrate Plant No, 1 near Sheffield, Colbert County, They had moderate luck when they were approached by a white guard, 38—yeare—old Harry S. White, The two blacks had previously agreed that they would kill a guard before they would allow, themselves to be arrested and prosecuted for hunting on the reservation. White placed them under arrest and they were walking to the guardhouse with him following them on horseback when White‘s attention was divert ed by the dogs chasing a rabbit and Greenhill shot him in the head, killing him instantly, Greenhill then took his wallet from his pocket] giving Newberry $10 of the #30 therein and also took White‘s pistol before they dragged him 50 feet and thew his body in a cistern that had 2% feet of water where it was discovered several hours later, Both Dewberry and Greenhill were arrested in Tusciimbla the next day and White‘s pistol was found in Greenkill‘s house, After intensive questioning at the Guard House of the Nitrate Plant, they both made  confessions admitting their part in the crime, Because of the fear of \ mob violence after several car loads of white men had appeared at the | guard house looking for them, both were taken to Birmingham for safe—. keeping until their trials at Florence, Lauderdale County, no U, S. Public Building being available in Colbert County and there both were convicted in the U, S, District Court KHKX«K Greenhill being sa@tenced to—die and— Dewberry receiving a life sentence, Greergill‘s conviction was affirmed on appeal and on October 9, 1925, he was returned from Birmingham to Florence and hanged there under the dirsction of Federal officials, His Last words, spoken after he had gone upon the gallows and when asked by Chief Deputy Sheriff Henry Hill of Birmingham whe— ther he had anything to say, were: "I guess not, Mr, H 111,"  BIRMINGHAM AGE HERALD, Birmingham , Ala,, 12—10; 12—ll; 12=12; 12-13, 12—l}; 12— 15~19?3, 10-02-192u, 10~=9 and 10=10=1925,. 6 FEDERAL (2nd) 13
