big_ocr: H ALE, Wesley  Hale, a Jefferson Co., Ala,, black man and two others, Anderson Shelton and Hugene Johnson, had been robbing the box cars of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad while they were at a siding at Ox— moor, On the evening of Jan,. 13, 1905, they were walking on the tracks towards Oxmoor for the purpose of raiding some of the cars when they engountered L & N fireman Edgar G. Almon who they attempted to rob, Almon drew a pistol and shot Hale through the heart just above the breast XKMXEKEXIXEK before Shelton and Johnson managed to take his pistol and kill him, They thought that Hale was dying and dragged him into some brush where he was discovered the next day and taken to the hospital, Thinking that he was dying, Hale made a full confession and named Shelton and Johnson as his two partners. He also said at that time that he had struck Almon with a stick before he was shot, but he subsequently denied this after ho had recovered. Tried first, Hale was convicted and sentenced to die. Johnson re— ceived a life sentence for his part in the crime while Shelton was also condemned to die, Hale received a 60—day respite to enable him to testify at the trials of his confederates, There was considerable sympathy for a commutation Of his sentence on the part of his jaillers| ths prosecuting attorney and the judge, all of whom felt that he was telling the truth when he stated that he had not struck KX Almon and was himself seriously wounded before the fireman was killed, but the Governor refused to intervenes and he was hanged in the Jefferson Co.  Jail at Birmingham on 0c§,. 5, 1905, Shelton followed him to the gallows later that month, y,  See also: SHELTON, Anderson,.  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA, OCTOBER 5, 1905.

big_ocr: HUGHES, Asbury, HUGHES, George, and SMITH, George . f“ / *~ / 5 7 7  Asbury Hughes, 21—years—old, his ?0—year—old brother George and 29— year=old George Smith, with the Hughes? brother‘s sﬁepfather,_John @rsyson, on the nignt of March 25, 1803, went to the home of Henry Porter near Carpenter, Ala., and terporized the household which con— sisted of Mr, and Mrs,. Porter, two other women and two young girls, demanding $500, When Porter explained that he did not have that kind of money at hame, they poured coal oll over some bedding and set fire to the house,. When the familly .attempted to save some trunks containing valuable papers and other treasured belongings, they prevented their doing so and tried to keep them in the burning house with weapons. Fortunately all escaped, but were —able to save only the clothes that they were wearing. | Asbury Fields wa spositively ldentified at one of the arsonists, and he, his brother and step— father were taken into custody on. April 9. George Smith, who was wanted in Ceorgia for the murder .of m man named Lum Street in Dade County, and in Tennessee for the murder of arevenue agent was cap— tured near Carpenter on April 27. _All four—of tho prisoners pro— tested their innocence, but they were convicted at their trial. The jury recommendbd mercy for Grayson and he was sentenced to  life imprisonment, but the Pughes brothers and Smith were sen— %     tenced to hang,. The three men were hanged from a commux gallows with three crossbeams "dJOlﬂ¢Pg the county Jail on Aug. 1, 1801,  Ah crowd estimated at 3,000 gathered for bur ﬂ"“uht10ﬂ and 150 armed men were detailed to mw Lntain order. Irlor to the executl ons Smith‘s wife rushed : up on the gallows and threw her arms around her husband‘s neck and had to be—forcibly removed, For a time, it lobked as though the guards.mightb have to firs on the crowd when they attempted to tear down the enclosure that had been built to &nsure the privacy of the proceedings. Though they con— tinued to deny their gu17t, Asbury ﬂubnap made one final statembnt that indicateﬂ that they were guilty, Just before they wore hanged he said: "You scusht to turn Uravxon alooses He was not there." This was the first instance in Maba ma nlutory for white men to be hanged for the crime of arson, f  THE STORY OF SCOTITSEORO , ALAQUJA by Wy do 4¢btc Rich Printing H1  $0 SNQ‘s a Nashville, 4 van“  /o, A /al—amia. 3 /  é/Wﬁc/éa ﬂo%,ﬂ€aa

ocr_text: September 9, 1é22. HALL, Sam  Autauga Co. black, killed wife. Maintained that he was innocent until just before execution when he confessed crime to Gov. Bibb Graves who attended execution on Sept. 9, 1937.  The Dothan Eagle  216 Alabama 336; 113 Southern 64.  TRUE DETECTIVE, Nov., 1933,pb62.  Large card. Alabama Book and Magazine Exceppts
big_ocr: 6 1 oter fi". ta" ie, dan 216 226  Hall, an Autauga Co., Ala., black man, and his wife, Kate, were separated but not divorced,. .He was in love with and wanted to marry another woman but she fefused to do so as ‘long as Kate was living and they were not divorced. In 1926 he knocked Kate unconscious with a piece of lead pipe and threw her into the Autauga Cr@ek while she was still alive, letting her drown, He and the other woman were promptly married but he was arrested shortly afterwards and charged with the murder of his first. wife. At his trial, Hall maintain that he and his wife were arguing in front of another black man named Major Wilson and that Wilson threw some rocks at him, one. of which struck him in the head, as KK Kate attempted ‘to cut him with a knife, He said that he picked up the pipe XKHXEXEMEKXHEF in the dark and struck her on the head. She then fled towards the creek while Wilso  found on his cap was caused by his having picked up her up and carrie her on his shoulder to the creek. Convicted and sentenced to hang, his case was appealed to the Alabama State Supreme Court which upheld ¥ *% KEX his conviction, As Alabama had substituted the electric chair for the gallows during the course of his appeal, the Supreme Court ordered the Cirfuit Court to resentence him to death by the new means of. execution and on September 9, 1927, he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison,. Prior to his execution, in a bid for exec:  utive clemency, he admitted to Governor Bibb Graves that he had mur—  cered his wife without provocation, Governor Graves was a witness at the execution,  THE Dothan, Alabama, Sept. 9, 1927.  SOUTHERN REPORTER, Vol, SO 113, Published by West Publishing CO# p ote, Paul, Minns, Pages 65—66

big_ocr: HALL, Henry and HALL, John / ”40 “'/ f f 5  The Halls, black brothers, both resided in Montgomery Co., Ala., near Pike Road,. On the evening of August 12, 1898, they had been drinking and entered the store on Pike Road owned by Hugh Beiser. Both were armed, John carrying a ,38 caliber pistol and Henry a shotgun, They became boisterous and were ordered from the premises, After a few minutes, they returned and became rowdy again. Beisor‘s young nephew, James, a clerk in the store attempted to put them out and John Hall flred at him with his pistol but missed, When Beiser XH LKX® grabbed his own pistol and fired at John Hally Henrj Hall shot him with the shotgun and Beiser died in a few km minutes, John Hall was taken into custody the next day and was found to have been wounded in the chest by the shot fired by Belser. Henry Hall escaped to Florida where he was captured on August 19 by a posse composed of relatives and friends of Belser. Both were convicted of the murder and sentenced to die and they were hanged in Montgomery on Jan, 20, 1899. Both of the condemned men made  speeches from the gallows with Henry Parl talking for eighteen minutes, They professed religon and claimed that they  T} s Tuse k C mi is Beiser in self—defense. big_ocr: [ fee and JONES, Albert Les y 9 ra risa e tae n te rots im o —*  A  Grimes and Jones, 23—year—old BXXEK illiterate black residents of Russell Co., Ala,, had become friendly with some black veterans of the Second World War and were intrigued by their tales of how easy it was to kill] other human beings. They decided to rob a O6l;—year— old white former school teacher and the owner of a grocery store, Daniel W. Pearce and his 57—year—old wife, Mattie Vann Pearce,. at their home at Pearce‘s Cross Roads, a few miles from Fort Mitchell, They origlnally planned the crime for the night of Nov, 23 $; 1952, but were frightened off. The next night, they entered the Pearce home and walted for their return when they shot Mrs, Pearce, knocked Mr, Pearce unconscious and set fire to the house bEfore stealing $70 XFENCXKAIEXXEIEEXEXXLIEZ ond a pistol fran their automobile. The  house was completely consumed by ‘the flames and it was thou ght for     x2»  severa J]. days that a gas explosion had caused the fire, However, an autopsy performed by the State toxlcologist disclosed the fact that Mrs., Pearce had been shot first and the imvestligatlon that followed led to the arrest of Grimes and Jones who confessed the crime o were convicted and sentenced to death, and following a clemency  he are ng Iv a W 3. y ik W P hearing in which gaid that they vould 14iva aa . aand ay a t> 4 (1 LL}; UOLh BAQLC til” U 13115; "(Jot/Ll“ Just-JO as Lac) 0d (117”.LSQ1,f11’lS  Both if thelr lives were spared, the Governor refused to intervene? They were electrocutkd at Kilby Prison on April 23, 195/;, Grimes, though knocked unconscious by the first shock of electricity, soon began breathing and gasping for air and a second shock was necessary  A  to kill Aigts  The Columbus ENQUIRER, Columbus, Ga., 11—26—1952 ; 11—27—1952; XXXXX1 1—=23=195l, and 1;=2);—1951; ?  "..,. When Arthur Lee Grimes was executed in Alabama in 195, the doc» tor found his heart still beating, He stepped back and waited for it to stop, but instead of expiring, Grimes started to shudder violent—  ly and thrash against the straps. "e started to come back to con—  sclousness, gasping and sucking in air, It took seven full minutes of juice, six massive jolts in all, to end his life," AN ENCYCLOPEDIA OFP AMERICAN CRIME, By Carl Safakis; New Yorks Facts on File Publica» tions, 1982; ‘page 238. s

HARRIS» Lee and MITCHELL, Abe  Hanged Birmingham, Alabama, on June 7, 1895, See large
big_ocr: Harris, a 23—yeareold black native of Union Co., S. C., went to Bir=  mingham, Ala,, in the fall of 1891; and formed a gang of black theives of which Mitchell, a 22—year—old native of Crenshaw Co., Alay was a  member and Harris‘! right—hand man, In Dec,, 189, they waylaid a young Ensley grocer, James F, Thornton, who was returning home with a  | wagon load of supplies, When Thornton attempted to draw his pistol, both Harris and Mitchell shot him, stole his money, watch and chain and left his body in his wagon, In the early part of Feb,, 1895, they were out of money and decided to rob an elderly black grocer, Pleas Meriweather, They entered Meriweather‘s store and, when the old man  — turned his back, knocked him unconscious with a club and then cut his  throat from ear—=to—ear, — Their loot consisted of a few cents, some silver spoons and some trinkets, Harris Mtchell and several other black men were arrested the next week on circumstantial evidence and they day after they were taken into custody, Harris confessed before a coroner‘s jury, naming Mitchell as his accomplice in the two murders,  He wore a strange smile on his face while reciting the details of the crimes and actually appeared to members of the jury to be boasting.  Mitchel]. confessed the next day and both men stated that Harris had ‘actuallyilubbadjﬂemeaihm;andxmt his throat, They also admitted __ a mmber of other robberies in which innocent victims had been wounded. | though not killed, Both wers tried for the Meriweather murder, con— _| victed and sentenced to death, Prior to their executions, they sold their bodges fo a Birmingham mortician who announced plans to embalm and exhibit them, They were hanged in the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham on June 7, 1895. Both spoke from the gallows, admitting their crimes for, the last time, warning those present to beware of bad company and stating that X® they were assured of forgiveness for their sén@s and felt that they were bound for Heaven. Neither neck was broken and KXXKX Mitchell died in 102 minutes while it took 12 for Harris to strangle to death.  NMS, Birmingham, Ma, 1—7—1008. —

big_ocr: HARRIS, Will  Alar 78 I4 c Z Harris, a black man who had formerly lived in Wilcox County, Ala,, moved to Selma, Dallas County, Early one morning in Octoger, 1901, he watched 10—year—old Mattie Bell, a black girl, as she walked across a rallroad bridge spanning a creek to take her father‘s breakfast to the mill where he worked,. When the girl returned, Harris followed her across the bridge and along the track untill the reached a clump of trees, He dragged her into the grove, raped her and then bludgeoned her to death with a tree limb, A group of blacks working in a nearby field heard the girl‘s screams and saw them struggling but did not interfere as they said that they thought that Harris and Miss Bell were "playing,." Harris was taken into fustody that same day by a posse of blacks who combed the countryside searching for him after the ° body was discovered, At the time of his preliminaty trial, a large group of blacks attempted to take him from the custody of the Sheriff and lynch him as he was being returned to the jail from the court. Convicted and sentenced to death, he attempted suicide by grinding up "s bore ho hod iis, ons and ho planned to _ cell. A few days later, Parris confessed his guilt and stated that he had raped a number of small girls 1n‘Wilcox CounLv before movxng to  xﬁled. He was hanged Zn the Dallas County Jail at Selma on March  28, 1902, before a small crowd of witnesses, Prior to his execution, he was allowed to address the large crowd of blacks who had assmebled outside the jail and he stated that he hoped that his execution would be a warning to others, The drop of eight feet broke his neck and he  died without a struggle. big_ocr: — JOHNSON, R " +C  Johnson, allas Jrnest McGruder, a 17—year—old black youth, was om— ployed by Jack T. Walton, a prominent Hale Co., Ala., cattleman who lived alone on his farm about 15 miles from Greensboro. After his release from the State Reformatory where he served a sentence for horse theft, Johnson‘s friend, Richard Brown, also obtained employ— ment on the Walton farm, They had previously discussed killing their 63—year=old employer and when they went to work on the morning of Feb, 8, 1945, they had determined to do so. They attended to thsir chores and when Walton left thé farm on his pickup truck, they broke into the house where they stole a shotgun, a pistol, some shells and some cartridges,. They hid ‘at the side of the house and when Walton returned and started to unlock the door, Brown shot him with the shotgun, They walked over,axk@# inspected the body and when they saw a hand move, Johnson told Brown to shoot him again and Brown fired  a shot into his body with the pistol, They then loaded the body on a wagon, covered it with a skiff and drove the wagon to the Warrior River, They tied a tractor wheel and hub to the right side of the  body with a plow rope, punched holes in the skiff and then pushed it,  loaded with the body into the river,. In addition to taking $ h‘ig money, they also stole several sacks of cattle field and they divided the proceeds with Jackson‘s uncle after telling him that they had killed Walton, As Walton lived alone, he was not missed for several days and Johnsan and Brown were taken into custody for questioning  on March 5, 195. Johnson confessed two hours later and told officer; where to diugxthe river to recover Walton‘s body and it was recovered on the next day, Brown also confessed and Johnson s Uncle was arrested, Both Johnson and Brown p&eaded not guilty by reason of Ansanity but no substantiating testimony was presented on Johnson‘s behalf,. Both wers convicted and sentencea to die while Johnson‘!s uncle received a 30 year prison term, Their appeals to the Alabama Supreme Court were unsuccessful and Johnson was electrocuted at the  Alabama State Prison on January 25, 1946, Brown followed him to the electric chair one week later, |  %  bee also: BROWN, Richard  21} SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 17 The GREENSBORO NATLHMAN Greensboro, Alabama,  *) f 6 wrung . a Cut £ » If,“  } g | sharif ( ¥ 4 AAA ® 4 Gs f io When E/ sut & ra dog tw dP.

big_ocr: HAYGOOD, Perry Lee  Haygood, a 25—year—old black resident of Birmingham, *la., conspired with a companion to rob the delicatessen owned and operated by W. J. Trotter on the corner of 18th Street and 10th Avenue, Bir— —mingham,. On the morning of Fsb, 2» 1948, the two men arrived at the shop around 7:20 4, M., just as who was carrying the previous day‘s receipts, opened. Haygood and Sims ordered two chocolate milks, a box: of crackers and two tins of sardines which they ate, When they finished, Haygood drew a pistol. and Bhot and killed Trotter, Sims, who was not expecting gunfire, ran as Haygood robbeit the dead ma n, Later that day, Haygood pawned his gun and purchased a newbBuit of clothes, paying cash, The gun, subsequently shown to be the murder weapon, was retrieved from the pawn shop by the police department, When Haygood was taken into custody, he main— tained that he had obtained the money with which he had paid for the new clothes and a good portion of which he still hag in his possessio: by gambling with friends. Sims, also arrested, confessed his part in the robbery—murder and testified against Haygood at his trial where he was convicted and sentenced to die, An l11—year—old boy and another man who passed by the shop that morning also identified Haygood as being in the delicatessen shortly before Trotter was shot and his mvwﬁnwmrmimmef~san~nﬁﬂmw cartons and the box of rrackers, Convicted and sentenced to die 3  his case was appealed to the 4labama ZXKFRE Supreme Court which up» held the conviction and sentence and he was electrocuted at the Ala, State‘Prison on March 18, 1949. He: protested his innocence to the very end and sang the spiritual E  "Can‘t Hear Nobody Pra y" after  he had been seated and strapped .in the chair. f  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama March 18, 1949  38 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 593

big_ocr: | COBB, Curtis  Cobb, a 22—year—old black Birmingham, Ala., school janitor, waylaid. two white girls who were golng home, He stepped from behind.a.tree and, when he grabbed them, one of the girls was able toffreewhersalf and ran, The other child was dragged into the bushes and struggled with Cobb before she lost consciousness and he raped her.. big_ocr: JOHNSON, Frank. & ~ 4] 4743  Johnson, alias Bradley Johnson, a Bl4—year—old black man, had served a term in the Alabama Prison system, He lived with his wife and mother in Bessemer, Jefferson Cor, 4la., where he was employed as a workman by the Pullman Company, On the night of January 13, 1941, he attempted to assault a white woman but was unsuccessful when she resisted, A few hours®later, armed with a pistol, he entered the two—room home of an 18=—year—old white couple who were asleep with their XEXKME 9—yonth old baby, He secured the shotgun which the young husband kept by his bed and, threatening to kill all three, he forced the woman to have sexual relations with him, On the night of January 26, he attempted #o assault another white woman but her husband was able to fight him off, On the night of Jan,. 31, he en— tered the bedroom of another white woman who was sleeping and fled when her screams aroused her husband and son, Some neighbors XKK got a good glimpse of him as he fled and his wallet, containing his identification papers, were found under the woman‘s window,. He was arrested the next morning and identified by the victims of and nesses>: to all of the assaults, Johnson confessed but as his trial he repudiated the confession which he claimed he had made XKHKK through fear and sought to prove an alibi by his wife and mother, His case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed the conviction and the sentence of death, stating at the same time that the Police Chief of rstepped his bounds in refusing  to permit his attorney to see him until the attorney obtained an order from a judge and that the solicitor had been overzealous in his prose— cution, Johnson was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on June  14} 1911-30 $  #  wap f 4  } A $ b » i. £ 4 # fads d an # 4 {If — wegho a ? ¢ whe  5 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 632 e* / e  £24 4 ia ews o7 22 CL 1Cr (2/8 #s Z2)

big_ocr: WITI, Alex | "4 t ey tng  Hill, a 25—year—old black tenant farmer residing near Eoline, Bibb Co., Ala., owed $5.00 to Rufus Hubbard, a prominent white farmer of the same locality,. On June 1, 1899, the two men met in a road and got into an argument over the debt,. Hubbard overpowered Hill, tied him with a rope and took him to his house where Hill agreed to work the debt out,. After working for one—half of one day, he left,. On June 5, he returned to the Hubbard farm with his brother, Will HL11l, and called Hubbard to come outside. Hubbard was i111 and while he dressed, Mrs, Hubbard went to the door where Alex Hill shot her through the heart, killing her instantly, When Mr, Hill rushed out with his gun, H111 fired and wounded him in the arm,. Will Hill was captured in Bibb County three days Rater and returned to Eoline where Mr, Hubbard identified him as being the man with Alex Hill. He thas then shot to death by Mr. Hubbard and the men who had cap—= tured him, Ten days later, Alex Hill was captured in Walker Co. ﬁalking north along a railroad track, He was held in the jail at Jasper untll time for his tria > as ret — § whe§e he was tried, convicééd iﬁghgghggnggg {gxgggzd tngiﬁfeaﬁglle  Xg§t§§nged in Centerville on August l;, 1899, one day‘ less than two nuns from the date of his crime,. H6 met his fate calmly and, at wis 1 #*%4} 3 cA his request, a mumber of persons in the crowd came forward and j ~ ie shaked hands with him, He specifically asked that Mr, Hubbard  who was also there shake his hand but ﬂuuuard refused.  TRMINGHAM DAILY NEW x), August LL 3 1899 § — Birmi1 harﬁ 3 AlZ s

big_ocr: HIGH, Epﬁriam £///¢ z 2  High, a black native of Bessemer, Ala., had served a prison sentence for robbery, «After his release, he went to Bibb County where he sought employment in a saw mill at Camp Hugh (Pondville), In the autumn of 1923, he followed J, M, Arnold an elderly white man when the latter started home one afternoon and, when he overtook him, he threw him to the ground, stabbed him fourteen times and left him for deadyin the public road, Arnold recovered from his wounds and testi fied against High at his trial where he was convicted and sentenced to die, Newspaper dispatches generated gonsiderable sympathy for High because of a prevalent feeling that a man should not be executed for robbery, However, the State Board of Pardons after hearing the judge who had presided at the trial testify before themthat the case was "as bad as a case could be and without provocation or mitigation! they refused to recognize clemency and the Governor declined to in— tervene, He was hanged at Centerville on September 1, 1922. Prior to his execution, he confessed the crime and asked that copies of the  newspapers reporting his execution be sent to his mother in Bessemer,.  High was an exceedingly slender man and, as the fall did not break his neck, he strangled to death, BIRMINGHAM AGE—HERALD, Birmingham, Alabama 9=1 and 9—2—1922  Letter dated Oct, 25, 1977, from Mrs., Josiah Kennedy, Box 98, Centre— ville, Alabama,

big_ocr: HOCKENBERRY, Joseph H. and REEDY, Daniel F.  Hockenberry, a white man born on Feb. 18, 1923, suffered a change of personality after his parents were separated when he was 1/;—years— old, becoming "depressive, impulsive and sneaky." He lived with his mother until he was convicted of an assault on a woman and sent to prison for ons year in 1942. After his release, he lived with his father for a short time until apprehended for another rape and sent to the Gallinger Municipal Hospital in Washington, D. C., as a psycho pathic personality, He spent eight months in the psychopathic ward and while there met Reedy, also white and two years younger, They pdotted an escape and on Feb, 1, 19h, they knocked a guard uncon— scious and fled in a stolen automobile,. They went to New Orlenas, La. stealing automobiles and snatching purses and raped or attempted to rape several women,. After leaving New Orleans, they drove through Missiskippi to Birmingham, Ala,, and on Feb. 11, they abducted a married woma n and drove her car to a secluded area near Bessemer where they both raped her After they had com pleted their assault they robber her and attacked her with a knife,. leaving her for dead, before driv}n*q2f€i%§egggva%£g?go%%%£impg gured shortly afterwards, they were both ident 1 DoJ lienists who I“ io. 3 plea was ons of ll’lSanlty and alirenisy they confessed, Their p came from the wasthington hospital stated that while they were both psychopathic personalities, they knew the difference between right and wrong,. Both were. convicted‘ and sentenced to die and thelr cases were appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed the con— victions and sentences, The mothers of both men came to Alabama and pleaded for a commutation of their sentences unsucessfully, They were clectrocuted ah the Alabama State Prison on March 16 1945, with the husband of their victim in attendance as a w1tnuhm. In a clemency hearing before the Governor just prior to their de&ths, Hockenberry nrofessed religion, saying that he hdd "found God in the death house." Reedy maintained that he didn‘t recall what happened clearly, — s F  IRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama ar h 16 19h).  20 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIGS 590 20 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 533° 7 M a. .> xé 7 ck .,

big_ocr: HODGES, Amos ‘ 7“ = /5/ 75  Hodges, an Escambia Co., Ala., black man, was involved in a menor le» gal difficulty in which a black woman named Rose Stainback was sche— duled to appear as a witness against him. Hodges uttered a‘ number of threats against her life and on January 21, 1892, he walked to her house and killed her by firing one barrell of a double—barreled shot— gun nto her body. When officers investigated the scene of the mur— der, they found footprints and by them, about 25 yards from Mrs, Ptainback‘s house, they found some calico cloth and tissue paper  that had been used as wadding, After Hodges was arrested k®EX on sus picion because of his earlier threats, they searched his house and found a shotgun concealed with one barrel fired, The other was packed with scraps of calico cloth .and tissue matching that found  at the murder scene. Addionally, the buckshot in the unfired barrel matched that taken from a plank behind Urs, Stainback‘s body,. "hen the officers ‘showed the gun to Hodges, he admitted that it belonged to him and additional circumstantial evidence was the fact that his  shoes matched the prints found at Mrs, Stainback‘s house. . At h%?, ggiggﬂvﬂodges took the stand in his own behalf but refused to affirm  that he had shot Mrs. Stainback,. In his summation, the prose» cution stated that this was tantamount to an admission of guilt, The defense objected to this statement, but —the—ob Lhon—  and the defense took an exception. TKEXEXSEZ "fter Hodges! trial and conviction, the case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which reversed the conviction and ordered a new trial because the Court had refused to give the following defense requested charge: "That a reas» onable doubt is defined to be a doubt for which a reason could be given. " Hodges was then tried again, the requested charge given, convicted and sentenced to die., He was hanged hanged at Brewton on July}, 1893, At his request, the Sheriff personally pulled the — latch on the trap door when Hodges said that he did not wank any of the deputies to do the job, yue  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, July 8, 1893. 97 Alabama 37 — _ f - letter dated April 12, 1977, from Mrs, Carolyn McLendon, The Escambia  County "istorical Society, Brewton, Alabama,

big_ocr: HUGHES, Asbury, HUGHES, George, and SMITH, George . f“ / *~ / 5 7 7  Asbury Hughes, 21—years—old, his ?0—year—old brother George and 29— year=old George Smith, with the Hughes? brother‘s sﬁepfather,_John @rsyson, on the nignt of March 25, 1803, went to the home of Henry Porter near Carpenter, Ala., and terporized the household which con— sisted of Mr, and Mrs,. Porter, two other women and two young girls, demanding $500, When Porter explained that he did not have that kind of money at hame, they poured coal oll over some bedding and set fire to the house,. When the familly .attempted to save some trunks containing valuable papers and other treasured belongings, they prevented their doing so and tried to keep them in the burning house with weapons. Fortunately all escaped, but were —able to save only the clothes that they were wearing. | Asbury Fields wa spositively ldentified at one of the arsonists, and he, his brother and step— father were taken into custody on. April 9. George Smith, who was wanted in Ceorgia for the murder .of m man named Lum Street in Dade County, and in Tennessee for the murder of arevenue agent was cap— tured near Carpenter on April 27. _All four—of tho prisoners pro— tested their innocence, but they were convicted at their trial. The jury recommendbd mercy for Grayson and he was sentenced to  life imprisonment, but the Pughes brothers and Smith were sen— %     tenced to hang,. The three men were hanged from a commux gallows with three crossbeams "dJOlﬂ¢Pg the county Jail on Aug. 1, 1801,  Ah crowd estimated at 3,000 gathered for bur ﬂ"“uht10ﬂ and 150 armed men were detailed to mw Lntain order. Irlor to the executl ons Smith‘s wife rushed : up on the gallows and threw her arms around her husband‘s neck and had to be—forcibly removed, For a time, it lobked as though the guards.mightb have to firs on the crowd when they attempted to tear down the enclosure that had been built to &nsure the privacy of the proceedings. Though they con— tinued to deny their gu17t, Asbury ﬂubnap made one final statembnt that indicateﬂ that they were guilty, Just before they wore hanged he said: "You scusht to turn Uravxon alooses He was not there." big_ocr: 9/28/1856  JACKSON, Melvin  Jackson, a Lf—year—old black resident of Phenix City, Ala., was a prisoner in the city jail, On the night of Sept,. 2, 1954, he escaped and early the next morning entered a rural home where a young white woman and her two—yeare=old son were sleeping. After first disguising himself by putting on a short—sleeved woman‘s dress and tying a scarf around his head, he armed himself with a rifle and entered the room where the woman and child were sleeping,. When they awoke, he told the woman that she knew what he wanted and when the baby began crying, he ordered her to fix breakfast, After they had eaten, he threatened to kill both her and the child if she refused to submit to him and  he then raped her, When he left the house, he took the woman‘s bill=— fold, some extra cartridges and the rifle and he discarded the dress, scarf and a cold drink bottle a short distance away, Jafkson was arrested six days later in a Columbus, Ga,, theater, after being pointed out to the officers by his father, In addition to making both an oral and written confession, he showed officers where he had hidden the rifle and it was recovered, At his trial, his victim identified him and only defense was one of insanity, His father testified that he sometimes acted peculiar but that he knew the difference between right and wrong and he was convicted and sentenced so die, The conviction and sentence were affirmed by the Supreme Court of ﬁhlmma on appeal am} he was electrtmcuted at Kilby Prison on «£2711! erbem 2.38: 10360; tart Mayt 2 V f  88 SOUTHERN (2nd) 206 . 7>,/ f/g/ngzftmq uce.

big_ocr: ACKSON, WiLL  Mee ‘C —14. — yes, Jackson, a black man, was in Decatur, Alas, carly in 1905ymhen he ° was arrested by Officer Es Le on a KKXKK charge of vagrencys As Steele was taking him to jail, he snatched the officer‘s pistol and shot and killed hime Jackson was taken into custody almost irimediately by several nearby citizens» He was taken to the J effer= son County Jail in Birmingham for safekeeping XMAX along with XKKX John Collier and Harvey Smith, charged with and subsequently con— victed of the rape«—murder of Miss Belle Bloodworth , and mas guarded by Guardsmen when returned to Decatur for Ris trail and later for his executions He was hanged on June 16, 1905, from the same gallows with Collier and Smith, Prior to his execution, he said that he had killed Steele because he was afraid that Stecle would kill him, His neck was not broken by the fall and he died  of strangulations u '  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, June 16, 1905

big_ocr: 3—12—1869 ° | Iohnson, an 18—yeareold mulatto, and Tomlin, a 2l—yearecld black man, were both former slaves who, disdaining work, were members of a size— | able gang which operated dn the outskirts of Mobile, Ala.,, and subsis~ ted by robbery and plunder, On the night of Oct, 21, 1868; they and others in the gang participated in the mass rape of an elderyly white woman and the next night they waylaid a young white man, Archie ghlin,who was on his way home for the evening, at the Eslava Bridge and when McLaughlin resisted their attempt to rob him, Tomlin, the gang leader, shot and killed him, Tomlin forced another member of the gang, WENKKKKMKEK Wesley Saulsberry, at pistol point to remove the dying man‘s boots and the gang took all other articles of value from his person, Six members of the gang, including Johnson, Tomlin and Saulsberry, were rounded up, and one member, Aleck Mobley, turned State‘s evidence, Johnson and Tomlin were each sentenced to die and two others, Israel Beverly and Thomas Burns were sentenced to life im— prisongent while Saulsberry was acquitted ater the other members of the garg, including the two condemned men, testified that he had been forced to participate, There was no appeal of the conviction,«?u3 the Governor granted a respite from their original execution date of Jan,  15 to March 12, 1869, and they were hanged beflore a tremendous crowd iicluding members of the murgired man'ggfamlly in the Mobile County * ”p3éiikﬁéﬁgu6ﬁwﬂéféhwfﬁ;hf859."‘énwfhé”ﬁighﬁ“ﬁéf6fé“£héff"éxééﬁﬁi6ﬁ95‘ﬁf both men, who had experienced religious conversions while awaiting | death, talked freely to reporters and Tomlin expressed the belief that "When they caught him the authorities got the biggest thief and ras» cal in Mobile County", admitting that he had committed many robberies and rapes, as well as murdering McLaughlin for his money,. Before go— ing to the gallows, Tomlin asked for a cigar and while smoking it re» marked that it would be his last, While his hands were being tied, he said to the jailer: "Tie me tight, Mr.Joe, and pray don‘t go to hell, but go to heaven,." Roth were cool and collected and each made a brief talk from the gallows admitting their crimes, While the death warrant was being read, Tomlin cried out to a small boy seated in a nearby tree: "You had better be praying," When the drop fell, many in the crowd cheered, The ropes slipped to the back of both ments — heads and both strangled to death, — Their bodies were cut down in 15 minutes. t  MOBILE WEEKLY REGISEER, March 20, 1869, (Article filed in red bound book contain manuscript of THE TREE about the Boyington case from Mobile.)

big_ocr: 3—12—1869 ° | Iohnson, an 18—yeareold mulatto, and Tomlin, a 2l—yearecld black man, were both former slaves who, disdaining work, were members of a size— | able gang which operated dn the outskirts of Mobile, Ala.,, and subsis~ ted by robbery and plunder, On the night of Oct, 21, 1868; they and others in the gang participated in the mass rape of an elderyly white woman and the next night they waylaid a young white man, Archie ghlin,who was on his way home for the evening, at the Eslava Bridge and when McLaughlin resisted their attempt to rob him, Tomlin, the gang leader, shot and killed him, Tomlin forced another member of the gang, WENKKKKMKEK Wesley Saulsberry, at pistol point to remove the dying man‘s boots and the gang took all other articles of value from his person, Six members of the gang, including Johnson, Tomlin and Saulsberry, were rounded up, and one member, Aleck Mobley, turned State‘s evidence, Johnson and Tomlin were each sentenced to die and two others, Israel Beverly and Thomas Burns were sentenced to life im— prisongent while Saulsberry was acquitted ater the other members of the garg, including the two condemned men, testified that he had been forced to participate, There was no appeal of the conviction,«?u3 the Governor granted a respite from their original execution date of Jan,  15 to March 12, 1869, and they were hanged beflore a tremendous crowd iicluding members of the murgired man'ggfamlly in the Mobile County * ”p3éiikﬁéﬁgu6ﬁwﬂéféhwfﬁ;hf859."‘énwfhé”ﬁighﬁ“ﬁéf6fé“£héff"éxééﬁﬁi6ﬁ95‘ﬁf both men, who had experienced religious conversions while awaiting | death, talked freely to reporters and Tomlin expressed the belief that "When they caught him the authorities got the biggest thief and ras» cal in Mobile County", admitting that he had committed many robberies and rapes, as well as murdering McLaughlin for his money,. Before go— ing to the gallows, Tomlin asked for a cigar and while smoking it re» marked that it would be his last, While his hands were being tied, he said to the jailer: "Tie me tight, Mr.Joe, and pray don‘t go to hell, but go to heaven,." Roth were cool and collected and each made a brief talk from the gallows admitting their crimes, While the death warrant was being read, Tomlin cried out to a small boy seated in a nearby tree: "You had better be praying," When the drop fell, many in the crowd cheered, The ropes slipped to the back of both ments — heads and both strangled to death, — Their bodies were cut down in 15 minutes. t  MOBILE WEEKLY REGISEER, March 20, 1869, (Article filed in red bound book contain manuscript of THE TREE about the Boyington case from Mobile.)

A4 7 a  Johnson, 4A 25—year—old black native of Meridian, Miss., moved with his wife and two children to the plantation owned by Captain J. W. Winston in Lacy Beat, Sumter Co., Ala., in January, 1896, He had repeated disputes with the overseer of the plantation, a white man named A, F. Clark, who he felt was cheating him out of a portion of his share of the crop» On the night of Dec. 8, 1896, Clark  was sitting at home with his wife and children when a disturbance was heard in the barn among the livestock. As the overseer stepped outside the house to invéstigate, he was instantly killed by two shotgun blasts, Johnson, who disappeared with his wife and family immediately after the crime, was suspected because of his trouble with Clark and he was captured in Mississippi a few daysylater. Returned to Alabama, he confessed but claimed that he had been hired to kill Clark by three other black men, Convicted and sen—  tenced to death, he was hanged at Livingston, Ala., on duly 30,  1897. — Prior to his executi E + i reflérated his quilt. ution, he made a statement in which he BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, 7—30—1897

big_ocr: JONES, Sandy M4 M  Jones, a 28—year=old Bessemer, Ala., black coal miner had lived a fairly exemplary life up thtil the night of April 5, 1889, having never been in trouble with the law. On that night, he and two com» panions were drinking heavily and carousing in the black section of Bessemer and some alarmed residents notified the police. ‘ones! two companions were taken into custody in their homes without inci— dent. When Policeman John Manning and two other officers went to Jones! house and knocked on the door, Jones delayed opening it, claiming that he could not find a match to lifht the lamp. M&nning handed him some matches through the door and after Jones had lighted the lamp and addressed, he admitted Manning. When Manning told him that he was under arrest, Jones picked up a Winchester rifle and shot the officer through the chest, killing him instantly. He then started firing the rifle repeatedly through the front door and when Manning‘s fellow officers ran to the back door to enter the house, Jones escaped through the front, He was recognized at a danfgée in Mobile, Ala., in Januayy, 1890, and returned to Birmingham where he was speedily convicted and sentenced to death, He was hanged at the W Jefferson County jail on May 9, 1890. f BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., 5—9 — 1890  According to Sexton‘s Led ger for the Southside Cemetery, later Red Mountain Cemetery, where Jones is buried, his age was 22", Ltr, dtd 2=7—1985 from Marilyn Davis Barefield, 1108 88th St, So., Apteo 1, B‘ham, AL 35205

big_ocr: KEITH, Vincent  Keith, a Childersburg, Ala., black man, used a hickory stick to bludgeon to death John Houston, another Childersburg black man, After his arrest, Keith confessed and stated that his only reason for killing Houston was to steal a few dollars that he knew his victim had, After his conviction and sentence to die, he turned to religion and took great consolation from the visits of the various ministers who came to see him, Prior to his execution, he addressed a large crowd that had assembeld from the Jak window of his cell and he made another statement from the gallows in which he admitted the justice of his sentence,. He was hanged at the County Jail in Talladega on May 16, 1901.  Birmingham NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama May 16, 1901  His friends sang "Nearer My God to Thee" during his last moments. ARKANSAS GAZETTE, 5—16—1901

big_ocr: KNIGHT, Jefferson - //Z / / / y 7 y  Knight, allas Jack Knight, a Pensacola, Fla., black man, was visit— ing in Mobile, Ala., on the night ofJuly 28, 1897, and was engaged in gambling with cards when he got into an argument over the game with another player, Frank Dantzler, Knight pulled and shot and killed Dantzler on the spot. As he ran down the street attempting th escape, he was being pursued by two poliecemen when  a third officer, Joe Tucker attempted to block his passage. Knight shot Tucker through the neck and he staggered inside a building be— fore he also died, Convicted and sentenced to death, Knight‘s  case was appealed to the Supreme Court of Alabama which upheld the conviction and sentence and he was hanged before a crowd of 1,000 witnesses in Mobile on Jan,. 21, 1898, after confessing his crime on the scaffold and blaming it on whiskey and gambling. His neck was broken by the fall, but it was ten mimites before he died. His last request was that his body be returned to Pensacola for burial and in order to assure that this wish would be complied with, he raised  t gacgng¥ Ezsg%¥%£%oﬁsgrinted solicitation requesting donations to BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Ala, 1—2%—1975  ME Tien Tous

MOORE, Ben ba Bp v er  "Ben Moore, negro, hanged at Chambers County jail, Lafayettd Ala., at 6 AM on moming of 6-8-1923 for murder of Taylor, merchant, of Fairfax, The negro was calm as he mounted the scaffold and made no death statement, Thursday afternoon Moore confessed his guilt and implicated Jim Sledge, negro, now serving a life sentence, He said Sle dge aided him in the killing of the merchant, Blaming 'whiskey gambling and bad company' for his crime, Moore mounted the scaffold calmly and stood without a tremor as the rope was being placed about his neck, He prayed audibly throughout the time he stood on the gallows and shouted a firm "good- bye" to the officials, He had been baptized in the jail Thursday, when the last relighous rites were held, The crime for which Moore was hanged took place during an attempt ed robbery in 1922." B'HAM AGE HERALD 6-9-1923 Affirmed = Memorandum decision - 96 SOUTHERN 939

big_ocr: content od lun  fﬁﬁiﬁﬁﬁﬁi‘Jih"éhdeODGERS}’Jbé” y oat m, 2 v og 3 Blacks, hanged at Birmingham, Ala,, March 25, 1910, They went to Ens— ley during the State Fair in 1908 and entered store of John Simms, black merchant, where they ordered 5¢ worth of tobacco, They gave 10¢ in payment and as Simms was making change, Powell drew pistol and pointed at him, Simms grabbed gun and was about to get the better of Powell him when Powell cried to Rodgers to shoot which Rodgers did, Powell admitted to number of robberys and siad he. shot Herbert Johnson on llth St., Birmingham, on July kth for which he was never arrested, Powell reared in Goodwater, Ala., and Rodgers also native of Alabamae Smallest crowd to ever witness hanging in Jefferson County saw this one, even newsmen being deputized, Both spoke from gallows, Rodgers saying that his mother and white friends tried to send him to school and teach him to do right thing but he would not listen,  Powell said that since he was born almost had been bad, had stolen, committed highway robbery byt had never killed any man, At Rodgers‘ request, Dep, Sheriffs Joe Kantznester and Eugene Robinson mounted scaffold and shook hands with both men. Hever of trap pulled by Sheriff Higdon, Dep. Sheriff Percy Higdon cut string holding lever and in doing so severely wounded two fingers of the Sheriff inflicing an injury which Dr, had to dress inmediately, Drop fell at 11:03 and  Powell, the smaller, quivered for several minutes, Rodgers never  moved after fall, Powell declared dead in 11 minutes and Rodgers in 18 minutes, both necks being broken, Both bodies given to relatives, Powell‘s to go to Keliyton and Rodgers to be buried in Birmingham, — ~They were baptized in bathbub in county jail at 9 AM on morning of deaths, The widow of Simms and her sister allowed to visit and they begged the womens!‘ forgiveness which was given. |  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., March 25, 1910.  Evidently no appeal,

Rome AG af Ca cal Gavel t "Jull 27, 191h«=Two negro murderers were hanged in Alabama yesterday (Ju¥$2 26, 1914), and for once during the pre- sent administration little or no effort was made to ob- tain commutation of the death sentences imposed on the men«,»»Will Mack, of Bibb County...was executed for kill- ing a fellow convict at Lucile Mines, in Bibb County«»» Governor O'Neal said yesterday that little effort had been made to obtain commutations for the condemned men, Their attorneys took the matter up with the Governor, but did not submit any petitions asking that the sentence be commuted. Will Mack was serving a life sentence for mur= der at the time he killed his fellow convict, Will Ander= son. big_ocr: % <2 MALONE, Cleveland 9&4“ 2 7/ AZ 5 / S | f f raped | Z Malone, a Talladega Co., Ala., black man, the young daughter of a Childersburg farmer, The child identifed Malone as her assail~ ant and he was chased by an angry mob to Childersburg where he was taken into custody. Befause of the determination of a group of local people to lynch him, he was taken to Calhoun County and hold in the jail there until his trial when he was convicted and sen— tenced to die. Malone protested that he was innocent, but he was electrocuted on Feb, 27, 1931. When he was led into the death cham— ber and seated in the electric chair, it was discovered that the chair was not wired for the execution and he was forced to sit there for nine minutes while the preparations were made,. During this time, he went through terrific mental anguish and repeatedly beggod that — he be put to death, After the switch was thrown and he was mxecuted, one of the guards was so unnerved that he faiktod. & (  THE TALLADEGA DAILY HOME, Feb. 26 and Fob, 27, 1931.

big_ocr: MUNSON, John Henry, Jr.  Munson, a black man, lived in Ensley, Jefferson Co., Alay On the night of Jan, 30, 19h7, he and a companion named Walton entered the Ensley store owned and operated by Will and Gertrude Geer, also black, for the purposes of robbery, Munson was wearing a mask and armed with a pistol. He ordered Geer,kexxk who was sitting down, to stand up and turn around, As Geer did so, Mrs, Geer who was standing KXSIHEXKIMJXAXEXX$ behind her husband attempted to remove his mask and Munson fired the pistol three times with one bullet striking a counter, one wounding Geer and the third killing Mrs, Geer, At his trial, Munson admitted having been in the store but claimed that he had gone there to make a puchase, He said that when ho reached into his pocket for money, Geer saw his pistol and grappled with him for possession and that the gun discharged accidentallyy as he was strugg~— ling to keep KEXXEXKXEKXXX the pistol and get out of the store. Con— victed and sentenced to die, his conviction was to the Ala— bama Supreme Court which affirmed it and he was electrocu ed at the f Alabama State Prison on March 19, 19484, Munson died with a prayer  on his lips and his last words were: "Lord have mercy,." One of the straps on his legs was loose and when the current was applied, that leg kicked out violently. mmxmmgmmmxwmgmwnmammaxmxmxmxmmx BLRMINGHHM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama March 19, 1948  33 SOUTHERN REPORTER ond SERIES, 1,63  xSP Abebaniu IJ

ocr_text: MARTIN, Rhonda Belle , C f  Mrs. Martin, born in 1908, was a Mobile waitress at the Ag -time of her arrest as a mass murderess, She confessed to  __having killed by arsenic poison: (1) her daughter, Emo- -  gene Garrett, in 1937; (2)her mother in 1938; (3) her  ~-husband, George Garrett, in 1939; (;) her daughter,  _ Caroline Garrett, 6, in 1940; (5) her daughter, F1ly -  Elizabeth, in 193; and (6) her husband,Claude Marting  in 1951, At the time of her arrest, she was also killing  _by the same method another husband, Roland Martin, who  was the stepson of her sencond husband, Claude Martin,  She was electrobuted at Alabama's Kilby Prison on Oct.  £1, 1957. ial  Source: Detective Cases - June 1969. .  i a m+ {7 i J C HAD AA.. 2 (A. d Ac AY | CGV E 28 dil hice nt ff
big_ocr: MARTIN, Rhonda Belle Garrett Gibson  Mrs, Martin, a white woman born in 1908 in Lucedale, Miss., was a waitress by occupation, Divorced from her first husband, she next married George Garrett and they moved to Montgomery, Ala., and became the parents of five daughters, all of whom died while children, In 1937, her three—year=old daughter, Emogene, had worried her by re— peatedly asking for water, so she gave the child a glass Into which. she had placed arsenic and the thttle girl died,. From that time on, all who came into contact with Mrs, Martin seemed to mysterlously die. She was never suspected, because she always used different doctors each time a family member became 111, After her mother, her other four children, and George Garrett had all died, she marrled a widower named Claude Martin in 1949. He died following a lingering 1lllness  in 1951. Mrs, Martin, a ssisted by his step=son, Roland Martin, had | nursed him through his sickness and, after his death, she and the young Navy veteran who was 23—years her junlor married and moved to When Roland Martin became ill and local physicians were unable to dia= gnosse his allment, he was sent to the Veterans! Hospttal in Biloxi Miss., where it was discovered that he was suffering from arsenica poisoning,. A check on his revealed that all who had bee n close to her had mysteriously dled and Caaude Martin‘s body, s .;§' PHT  when exhumed, revealed traces of arsenic. Hrs, Martin was taken into custody and charged with incest for having married her : tapson and questioned about the mysterious deaths,. She finally confessed _ to having klllcd her hquands, Carrett and Martin, her mother, and  o (0%. e nsurance and she was drawing —       Llaude Martln8“'uOCLal éeuurltv even though she was married teuhlumw  _ stepson, Convicted of, murdering Claude Martin in Mont tgomery. The McCords quarreled con— stantly and fought frequently, As Nancy McCord was much larger and far stronger than her husband, she always won the battles and he re— sented this situation so much that he was frequently heard to remark that he would put a stop to it even if it meant killing her,. in May, 1891, Mrs, McCord disappeared and her husband was immediately suspected of having made good his threats, The Sheriff was notified and when he and a posse arrived, they noticed drag marks leading away from the house. | MeKELROY, Jim f | "Selma, Ala., August 29, 188h= Jim McKelroy, the negro wife \ murderer, was hung today, He murdered his wiff near Orr» ville last fall, He was soon captured and tried, His  only personal plea of defence was made when the judge was about to pass sentence upon him, at which time he said:  'I do not think you ought to sentence me to die. W was forced and driven to commit the crime, I did it because I  simply could not help ite Seeing and knowing wrat I did of my wife made me so mad that I was crazy and did not know what I was doing, That's all I have to say,' On the scaffold today he refused to talk and met death firmly, The execution was void of any exciting incident," MOBILE DAILY REGISIER, Mobile, Ala., August 30, 1884. | NORRIS, Robert  \ "The year 1837 saw the first public execution in Walker County, Alabama, Robert Morris was convicted of the mur- der of his stepfather and was hung for the crime in June of that year, The gallows was erected in the woods a mile and a half from Jasper, and consisted of two upright sawed pine posts set in the ground and spanned with a cross=beam of the same material. No trap was provided and instead a common cart was used, The condemned man was put in the cart, the noose placed around his neck, and when all was ready the cart was driven from beneath the gallows, The gallows stood until 1856 when the second public execution took place and was handled in the same manner," EISFORY OF WALKER COUNTY, ALA,, by John Mart?n Dombharte Cayce Publishing Co., Thornton, Ark, Copyright  1937 by Dombhart, page 33» I On 7-10-1579, spoke with Mr, Bruce Myers, Route nine, Box © local histord 1 retired _- probation officer and he informed me that this man's last - name was Norris (the book only listed as N-=--), Mr, Myers said his brother Reubin was also indicted and that they obtained a severence, Robert, tried in Walker County, was convicted and sentenced to hang, while Reuben, tried in Fayette CGunty, was acquitted, Mr, Myers also said that he thought the year was 1836 instead of 1837 but this was possibly year of murder, | NORRIS, Robert, - *  Hanged at Jasper in June, 1837. Legislature of Alabama o Dec. 23, 1837, appropriated $15.00 to Elijah H., Hudson, Sheriff of Walker County forexecuting Robert Norris and furnishing clothing, ACTS OF ALABMA, Vol., 23, p 120  Act of June 30, 1837, appropriated $19.00 to George W. Patterson and $151 to Robert Guthrey and James Ables for apprehending Robert Norris, charged with murder. ACPS OF ALABAMA, Vol. 22, p. 32.

big_ocr: MILLER, Frank é/ze/ﬁo/ of » Ofc) Miller, alias "Dutch Henry" and "Big Dutch", KKEXKREEX was a native of Germany who never revealed his real name in order that he might spare his family of embarrassment,. He had come to New York City when he was 15—years—old to live with an older brother who died shortly afterwards, On his own in a strange land, Mller became involved with a gang of safe blowers and rapidly built up a repu— tation XMEKZ in police departmants thoughout the country as a leading crook, On the night of March 23, 1900, he xxm was a member of & gang including Frank Ducnan, Frank Edwards, Tom Fay, John D. West and a crook known as "New York Harry" who broke into the Bir= mingham, Ala,, office of Standard Oil Company, beat and shot the night watchman, A, J, Clayton, blew the safe and stole over $300, After the burglars had left, Clayton issued an alarm and later that night, Mller and Duncan were stopped by police officers J, W, _ Adams and G, W, Kirkley for questioning. They were accompanying the two policemen to the station house where they were to be ques—  tioned by the officer in charge when Miller drew a 3 revolver shot Adams, At the same time, Duncan shot Kirkley, ® 33th aggfi-  cers returned the fire as their prisoners fled, §  4  but neither Miller nor Duncan was wounded, Kirkley died shortly afterwards, but XHKXEX Adams lingered until after the entire gang had been rounded up following a tip that the police received from underworld sources, Before he died, Adams positively identified Miller as the man who had shot him and Duncan as the man who had shot Kirkley, Miller swore on the witness stand that Duncan had not been with him that night and claimed that his companion was "New York Harry" who had fired the shots that killed both officers,. Because of the doubts that his testimony created in the minds of the jury, Duncan received a life sentence, but M.ller‘s conviction, based largely on Adams‘ deathbed statement resulted in his receiving a death sentence, He financed an expensive legal battery by the instigation of "an endless chain letter‘ "scheme whereby each recipient of a letter sent him ten cents and contimed to maintain his innocence as well as that of Duncan, His appeals were all rejected and when the Governor declined to intervens, he was hanged at the Jefferson County Jail in Birming— ham on June 28, 1901, From the gallows, he reiterated that Duncan, gig-sad go stand trial later that year for the murder of Kirkely, tried for the murder of Mune yas not  a Z, a C4. big_ocr: \ Milton, alias John Williams, alias John Milson, was a 35—yeareold  ‘ black man who had, beginning in 1916, served a sentence in the Alabama prison system following his conviction of assault with intent to mur— der at River Falls, After his release, he went to Birmingham and on  | April 12, 1923, was sentenced to eighteen months and seven days on a larceny charge and sent to Road Camp number six near Morris, Jeffer»  \ _son County, Milton had a good record at the camp and in time was  made a trusty and the waterboy for the road crew, On August 8, 192}, he went to a farm near where the crew was morking and secured a pail of water, While there he observed Mrs, Blaney Collins, the XAXKXKI daughter of the farmer, who was visiting there with her four children,. Around 3:30 that afternoon, he saw her leave her father‘s farm and be» gin walking through the woods with her children, the youngest an 8. month=old daughter, Maefron, who she was carrying in her arms, As they walked through a wooded area adjoining a field, Milton intercept» ed them and demanded that the woman have sexual relations with him, She told the older children to run for help and he started after tham  with a double—bladed axe when she screamed,. He then turned on. her and struck two blows with the axe, oneof which seriously wounded her  and the other fatally injured Maedron, A farmer heard her outcries — and was on his way towards them, shouting at Miton to desist, and — he mounted a nearby horse belonging to the workeamp and rode away, le managed to elude the huge posse that gathered to search for him and made his way to Birmingham where he spent the night and read an account of his attack in the paper the next morning, He then went to | Pratt City where he caught a train for Memphis, Tenn., Arrested and _ obJalled there for yagrancy, he went to Chicago upom his release where he spent another short time in jail for vagrancy before going on to tqavenna, Ohio,. There he was arrested for an attempted assault on another white woman and a deputy Moticed that he resembled‘ a photo— g; aph of himself published in a fingerprint magazine and notified the irmingham authorities who went to Ravenna and returnedhhim to Jeffer. «son County, On the train trip back to Alabama, Milton made complete Mconfession which he repudiated at his trial, His conviction was on appeal —and he was hanged in the Jefferson County jail 0 M‘d on July 31, 1925, On the gallows, Milton, who said that the only! eason why he had run from the camp was because he feared that he youl “be whipped for drinking —some uvhlskey that day, said; "I am gohn Mllﬁn‘ QT am going to die in a few mnutes for a crime I never committed, f t 5 the rlsp am. éthg gigktpﬁggegtggggghégp Egg Egg}! 6 $3351 Skaglﬁgoﬁm af W; was; l/Jeen lace d about his neok, these were his last words. 10 Southern O9 ﬁB ham AGE HERALD 8—93 8-10' 10=25; 10—27; P0—=28; 19211 12=3—192}

big_ocr: MTNCEY, Lodias Joo f f {2 "aP A yl 7/49  Mincey, a 30—ysar—old black resident of Troy, Ala., was in a grocery store on Love Street on the night of August 25, 1945, when a man named Jimmie John Hanson made a small purchase and, in paying the clerk, jestingly said that he was "a man with money, " Mancey and Hanson left the store together and wers seen walking down the Central of Georgia Railroad track, A Bhort time later, Ranson‘s body was founder under an overepass of the railroad. His throat was cut and there were other knife wounds on his face, Mincey fled to Birmingham where he was taken into custody, At the time of his arrest, he con— fessed having killed Hanson for the £3.00 that his victim was carrying. He surrendered the knife that he had used in the murder and demonstra— ted for the officers the manner in which he had cut Hanson‘s throat. Convicted and sentenced to dle, his cass was affirmed by the Albama Supreme Court, When the time came for him to go tbo the electric chair, he barticaded himself in his cell at Kilby Prison for more than one hour before he was persuaded to surrender. .It then took seven men ten minutes to strap the struggling man in the electric chair, He was executed on HKXXXX June 20, 1916. THE TROY HERALD, Troy, Alabama, June 20, 1946  25 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 777  "Montgomery, Ala., June LL, 19}6—30=year—old Lodies Joe Mancey, negro slayer of a crippled white man, staved off electrocutidn for more than an hour Friday by barricading himself in a Kilby prison death cell, The Negro, denied an llth hour bid for clemency by Gov. Sparks, looped bed sheets around the lock of his cell in such a way that prison offi— clals were unable to unlatch a bolt on the door,. hen officials, in— cluding the prison chaplain And a Salvation Army major, pleaded with Mincey to give up, the powerful Negro sloshed water on them through the bars and muttered: ‘I can do it if I want to.!‘ Finally, at 1 AM, Mincey gdceceded —to the pleas of State Patrolman Otto Dees, walked from the death cell and calmly changed his wat er—soaked clothing, He began to struggle, however, as he started his walk to the electric chair and battled for several minutes with seven prison officials, including 2689 pound E, P, Gray, a prison guard captain, before he was finally strappei in the chair. Peak, Jr., the son of a Wetumpka contractor, who was on a hunting trip and forced the boy to submit to sexual acts after which he bludgeoned him to death with his airerif% e and through the body into the Coosa River, When the boy did not return home that night, a search party was formed and the body was found around noon the next day, Winters was taken into custody for questioning at a Wetumpka lumber yard shortly afterwards and when he could give no valid explanation for having in his possession a note signed by Peak and three of his school friends, he made a complete confession in which he said that he had killed the boy to preven his teporting the mexual assault, Because of the nature of the crime and the in» tensity of local feeling, he was held in the Montgomery County Jail for safekeeping, An immediate session of the grand jury was called  on Feb, ?? and he was indicted with biS'trial beg%nn1ng on March 16, Convicted and sentenced to die, his electrocution a Kilby Prison on August 39, 1949, was and other Heaven,"  witnessed by his victim‘s father  His last words were: "I hopﬁ I meet that Boy in  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama  HERALD, February 24, 19)  March 16, 1949  Vetumpkﬁ, Ala,, August . 11, 19};9 ix I ae ,424£{éi¢u;4/ 55> €?/;25 “b27taﬁ~"fﬁé:5  Feb; 17, 3911‘39;

big_ocr: ODOM, Homer Garland  Odom, a 23—year—old white resident of Jefferson Cor, Ala,, loitered around the small grocery store owned by 7le—year—=old William Alexande McDonald on Highway 31 near Gardendal@ all afternoon on Feb., 8, 1949, As McDonald was closing that night, Odom attempted to take the bag containing the day‘s receipts and when whe old man resisted, he shot and killed him, The body was discovered the next morning by passers by who noticed it lying on the floor of the stopg through the windows There were no eyewitnesses to the crime, but Odom became an immediate suspect because so many people had seen him hanging around the store on the preceding day and when he was taken into custody he confessed and showed officers where he had hidden the murder weapon which ba— listics tests conclusively proved had fired the fatel bullet. — His conviction was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed it and he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on July 21,  1950. After he was seated in the chalr, he smiled at the warden and spoke his last words: "I"ll be sessing you, "  THE BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama July 21, 1950 6 SOUTHERN REPORTE 6s —  TER — 2nB SERIES 1

big_ocr: f MURPW Thomas f os  white, hanged at Mobile, Ala., on February 26, ‘1825.  "The execution of Thoms Murphy, for the murder of John Kilbourn, | took place in Mobile on Feb, 26. He was visited during his imprison ment by Reve Mr. Warren, who also accompanied him to the place of execution, A great cancourse of people had gathered to witness, | Disobedient to the control and percepts of his parents, this candidate] for the gallows, at an early period, is prepresented as having plunged deep in the abyss of vice — lewdness, gambling and d1551pat10no . nched upon the bosom of the raging torrent, falth, honor, justice and every virtue of the human breast were engulphed and sh1p~wrecked in  — is from the MOBIIE REGISTER: The exe ion of Murphy took place on Friday last amidst a vast concourse of spectators assembled to wit» ness the sad and inpressive catastrophe, From the time the unhappy culprit 1 ft the prison he maintained to the last moment a most extraordinary firmness, even during the fewawful moments of prepara— tion, after he had ascended the fatal platform, he observed a steadi= | _ ness and self—possession that were truly astonishing; assisted in adjusting his neck to the cord = spoke to several gentlemen with calmess and deliberation, and almost wit hout apparent emotion,, launched &xk® the tremendous precipice that separate s time from eternity, A tridube of thanks is due from this community to the  the devouring vOrteXe — ee.,»IThC follogqii commmicatich on the subject bes te ie e re ue 4 I d \  — Sheriff for his excellent arrangements, and the propriety with whlch ] he p rformed his painful duty; to the uniform companies for their __ martial appearance and conduct; and especially to the Rev, Gentleman who attended the miserable youth, for a most eloquent and appropriate and forcible address, to the anxious multitude, If the moral —results of this awful exhibition are other than salutary, the fault, at any rate, will not rest with him, And may we not indulge thehope that our clvil authorities, aided by public semtiment, will be aroused to a deeper sense of the necessity of frowning down the monster vice by every legal —and moral restraint,. If we will countenance the gaming  house andbthe brothel, the inevitable consequence is, that we must tolerate the gallows, HUMANITAS." CAEAWBA PRESS AND ALABAMA  GENCER, Cahawba, Ala,, 3—12—1825 (3—3).

big_ocr: NEWELL, Pig § of R 577  Newell, a Dallas Co,, Ala., man, had for some time been stealing chickens from various people. One of his victims, a white man named John Phillips, suspected him and was able to bu#ld up a definite case against him, He confronted Newell with the evidence that he had obtained and it was so conclusive that Newell decided to kill him rather than run the risk of prosecution and possible imprisorment, In December, 1896, he shot Phillips from ambush and then attempted to burn the body on a pile of leaves and twigs. However, it was not completely consumed completely and enough re— mained to indicate XHEZXMEXMHXXNEXX that Phillips had been shot be— fore the fire though it was impossible to determine whether or not hewas dead at the time that the fire was started. Newell was arrested for, charged with and convicted of the crime. Prior to his hanging in Selma, Ala., on July 30, 1897, he confessed that  he had killed Phillips, His last words were: "Good bye; meet me on Jordan‘s shore,"  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, AlaQama July $0, 1897  f’xjf/ﬁf a* 5 o f ANA iQ S5 J 2.)

big_ocr: gees oy ~ ami h /o;./g galt  Oliver, a hleyear—old white farmer and mlllwnrfer, lived with his  wife Vidic in the Friendship Community of fimere County, Ala.. A  large and powerful man, Oliver was an alcoholic who took a sadistic pleasure in beating his frail 90 pound wife when he was intoxicated, On Dec, 11, 1934, he was in a drunken rage and followed her from place to place in the community, brutally be&ting her fn the presence of many witnesses, Finally, he forced her from the wardrobe in the home of a neighbor where she had taken refuge into his car and drove in the direction of their home still beating her, When they arrived at their own house, he followed her inside in the presence of their terrified children and continued beating her, She —crawled under a  bed for protection, he dragged her out and continued striking her until she was unconscious, He and a son then started towards a doc» tor with her when he discovered that she was—dead,— Oliver at first maintained that she had been killed when she fell from a porch but when a bloody club was found which he had used as a weapon in addi tion to his fists, he conceded that he might have killed her and urged his oldest son to tell the truth, The boy made a complete statement _in which he said that after his—father—realized—that dead he — had kissed her and begged her to speak to him, At his trial, he main—= tained that he was too drunk to remember what had happened and he was | convicted and sentenced to die, The conviction was reveresed by the Alabama Supreme Court on the grounds that the coroner of Elmore County who had been instrumental. in building the case against him and had testified for the prosecution had been appointed a special bailiff  and had been placed in charge of the jury and he was tried, convicted and sentenced to die a second time, The second conviction was affir= med on appeal and he was electrocuted at Kilby Prison on December 10,  1937. big_ocr: PATTERSON, William M.  Patterson, a 25—year—old black resident of Jefferson Co., *la., and his wife, Mattie, separated following a series of domestic disputes, She had him arrested for assault and at his trial he was convicted and sentenedd to a term in the State Prison, After his release, he went to the house where she was staying on two separate occasions  but failed to find her at home. On his third visit, which was just three weeks after his release from prison, she was at home and he  sat and talked with her in the presence of another woman for some time,. The conversation had been pleasant and agrheable when, with» out warning, be drew a knife and attacked her. The other woman attempted to intervene and Mattie sought to flee, but he succeeded in inflicting fatal wounds. Convicted and sentenced to die, his case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed the sentence and he was electrocuthd at the Alabama State Prison on June 26, 1942,  8 SOUTHERNREPORTER 2nd SERIES 266

Findlay, a px 37—year— old priminent white farmer and merchant of Moundsville. One morning when Findlay and 39—year—old John Parker, a farmer of Cypress were discussing a business transaction concerning a tractor at the house where Patton lived, Findlay and Patton got into an argument over one— half ton of fertilizer. A young black boy who witnessed the &ffair said that Patton drew a knife and stabbed the two white men and then rushed into his house, obtained a shotgun and fired a load of buckshot into each man. He then took a XXFEXXXKKEXEK heavy stick of wood and cat both over the head. Patton fled before help arrived and XXKMLXXK XXKEXXEXHXWABEK found Findlay dead and Parker djing, A posse was formed and Patton was taken into custody when he went into a store at Akron and purchased some turpentine which he planned to place of his feet in an effort to elude bloodhounds. Patton wonfessed when he was arrested and the refusal of the court to grant a requested change of  venue formed the basis of his agpea; to tha 8 tate Supreme gggrt afgﬁr he was convicted and sentenced to die, The higher Court affirmed the conviction and he was electrocuted at the Alaba ma State Prison on  July 20, 1943. big_ocr: PILLEY, Robert S. ("Steve")  Pilley, a 2l;«~year—old white resident of Birmingham, Ala., had an un— fortunate childhood after his father died. His mother was subsequent ly to state as his clemency hearing that "he never had a chance" and  a sister testified at the same hearing that many times during his childhood the family "didn‘t even have food in the house." When he was l7—years—old he was sent to prison for twenty years following conviction on a robbery charge. — He was paroled early in 19l;); and went to Mobile. He then returned to Birmingham and joined up with a man named J, Earl Mobley, They borrowed a pistol and, on the night  of July 11, 19h, they went to a sandwich shop located at 1309 looss Ave., and owned by George Nolan Goatley, Mobley waited in the cer while Pilley went inside and ato tliree sandwiches, When the clerk went to the cash register to ring up the sale, Pilley drew the pistol and ordered him to give him the money, At that time, CGoatley started to the front of the store and Pilley informed him that it was a hold up, When Goatley turned to walk bakk to his office, Pilley shot him and the bullet entered the back of his neck inflicting a mortal wound,  After leaving the shop, he and Mobley went to Mobil? ghiﬁq gbg%8¥9re taken into custody a few days later, Pilley confesse e_au J op His plea was not guilty by reason of insanity but no evidence  @ insanity was presented in evidence and he did not take the stand in his own behalf. His confederate Mobley who had not entered the res=— taurant received a prison sentence while he was sentenced to die,  The Alabama Supreme Court affirmed the conviction and when the Gover— nor refused to grant clemency he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on April 19; 1946, His last words were the outspoken prayer: "May the Lord have mercy upon my soul." His family claimed his body and he was buried in Elmwood Cemetery , Birmingham,  THE BIRMINCHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama April 19, 196,  25 SOUTHERN REPORTER &nd Series 57  4YC1 Aa SAS  See REVEALING DETECTIVE, April, 1949, page 16 — ALABAMA — BOOK AND MAGAZINE RXCERPTS,

big_ocr: REDDING, Will_  Redding, a 26—year—old black native of Jonesboro, Ca., was living in Birmingham where, for some time, he $XXKX¥S«XE&ESX dated a black woman named Annie Green, Miss Green finally met someone else whose com pany she preferped and Redding became insanely jealous, He pur— chased a revolver and the next time that he saw her on the street, he shot and killed her, Redding attempted to escape but was cap— tured before he left the city and charged with the murder, Convic— ted and sentenced to die, he was hanged at the Jefferson County Jail in Birmingham on Dec, 20, 1901. His last words, spoken from the scaffold were: "This is my last day in this world and it is from keeping bad company,. You who have daughters and sons, I tell you keep them out of bad company, Keeping bad company has brought me  to the gallows, I feel that I am going to God. I feel that I am going to Heaven. That is all I have to say."  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala.,

big_ocr: HOCKENBERRY, Joseph H. and REEDY, Daniel F.  Hockenberry, a white man born on Feb. 18, 1923, suffered a change of personality after his parents were separated when he was 1/;—years— old, becoming "depressive, impulsive and sneaky." He lived with his mother until he was convicted of an assault on a woman and sent to prison for ons year in 1942. After his release, he lived with his father for a short time until apprehended for another rape and sent to the Gallinger Municipal Hospital in Washington, D. C., as a psycho pathic personality, He spent eight months in the psychopathic ward and while there met Reedy, also white and two years younger, They pdotted an escape and on Feb, 1, 19h, they knocked a guard uncon— scious and fled in a stolen automobile,. They went to New Orlenas, La. stealing automobiles and snatching purses and raped or attempted to rape several women,. After leaving New Orleans, they drove through Missiskippi to Birmingham, Ala,, and on Feb. 11, they abducted a married woma n and drove her car to a secluded area near Bessemer where they both raped her After they had com pleted their assault they robber her and attacked her with a knife,. leaving her for dead, before driv}n*q2f€i%§egggva%£g?go%%%£impg gured shortly afterwards, they were both ident 1 DoJ lienists who I“ io. 3 plea was ons of ll’lSanlty and alirenisy they confessed, Their p came from the wasthington hospital stated that while they were both psychopathic personalities, they knew the difference between right and wrong,. Both were. convicted‘ and sentenced to die and thelr cases were appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed the con— victions and sentences, The mothers of both men came to Alabama and pleaded for a commutation of their sentences unsucessfully, They were clectrocuted ah the Alabama State Prison on March 16 1945, with the husband of their victim in attendance as a w1tnuhm. In a clemency hearing before the Governor just prior to their de&ths, Hockenberry nrofessed religion, saying that he hdd "found God in the death house." Reedy maintained that he didn‘t recall what happened clearly, — s F  IRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama ar h 16 19h).  20 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIGS 590 20 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 533° 7 M a. .> xé 7 ck .,

big_ocr: SMLTH, A hdrew Lee  Smith, a 3l—year—old black coal miner, lived at Alden, Jefferson Co. Ala, He frequently conducted a crap game in Kkx® one of the rear rooms of his house and after Alden came under the police jurisdictior of Graysville, he was raided twice during the Christmas Seaston, 1950. Around 5:30 on the morning of April 21, 1951, Graysville Po— lice Chief Stanford R, Howton and Constable of the 360th Precinct, Sam Linn raided a game with Howton entering the house through the back door and Linn entering by a front door. They arrested all of the participants and allowed them to make appeara nce bods. While the officers were making out the bonds, Smith took some clothes out to his automobile and then returned. After the two officers had finished and left the house, Smith opened fire with a pistol and killed both of them, He then got into his car and fled, Smith was XXKEKXX capthred in Bessemer around 11 o‘clock that same morning and confessed shortly afterwards. His plea was insanity and kkx various members of his family testified that thero was a streak of insanity in the family and that Sith had acted "queerly" on occasions, However, the superintendent of the mine where he worked  said that he beligved Smith to be sane and a psychiatrist who had examined him ruled that he was sane, His conviction was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which upheld the lower Court and he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on May 2, 1952.  _The BIRMINGHAM NEWS » Birmingham, Alabama, May 2, 1952.  57 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2 nd SERIES 5 LJ  f rior ¢ / A  f; 3 4’! f? # / if ff“ f p: a" if”,  p we**"
