big_ocr: | magnum“ ile /d>*,/y77l  Rice a Greene Co., Ala., black man attended a "supper" shortly be= fore Christmas », 1893. He and another black man, Burrell Kimbro, got into an argument after they had a few drinks and Rice left,. He went home, got a shotgun, loaded it and waited for Kimbro, When Kimbro left the party, Rice Waylaid him and killed him withthe gun, He fled but Kimbro‘s kinsmen made a diligent search for him for aver a wook during which time Rice was hid out in the Bigbee swamps. Several weeks later, ho felt that he was secure from further pursuit and  was making his way North when word was received that he had been spotted hetween Brookwood and Woodstock, Ala, A deputy sheriff walked for over eighteen miles through the woods and arrested Rice  # ho offered no resistance, It was known that a number of months previously Rice had killed a black woman in jealous Rurtwpot fury when she refused to marry him and prior to his execution he confessed that he had also killed two other men — one in Birmingham and one in the — State of Mississippi. After expressing his readiness to die from the gggifold, Rice was hanged in the jail yard at Eutaw, Ala., on May 1§,  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., Page 7

big_ocr: | RICHARDSON, Robert e (re  Richardson, a Demopolis, Ala., black man, conspired with his brother, Albert, and John Hoskins, another black man, to rob Dr. Frank L. Fos» cue, &a prominent and wealthycitizen of Demopolis, Dr. Foscue was known to take a long walk each afternoon for his health, and one afternoon late in December, 190h, the three conspirators waited in hiding by a public road one mile west of Demopolis that they knew he would pass. After he had passed them, they EKXXK§H emerged from hiding and fired a shotgun filled with buckshot through his back killing him instantly, The body was found shortly afterwards and bloodhounds were used to trail the three men who were taken into custody that night, Hoskins confessed and gave State‘s evidence for which he received a life sentence, The Richardson brothers, both of — whom maintained that they were innocent,. were condemned to die, Al— bert Richardson committed suicide in his cell after his conviction while Robert‘s conviction whs appealed to the State Sypreme Court which ordered a re—trial, Before this was held, he made a desperate attempt to escape from the Marengo County Jail at Linden and was transferred to the Dallas County Jail which was stronger, Kt his  second trial, he was once again convicted and sentenced to die. He had boasted that he would never hang and once again he tried to es— cape and was prevented only after a hand=to—hand struggle with the jailer, Still protesting his innocence, he was hanged from a sca— ffold constructed in the County Jail Yard at Linden on June 29, 1906.  THS XNKN) XEXFKIREKAKIXKLIZL  The NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, June 29, 1906     "Demopolis, AL 12—17—190b—=Dr. F. L, Foscue has been shot and killed about one mile west of Demopolis, Near H, L, Woods Lumber Company. At the time he was taking his usual walk down the railroad track, He was shot in the back with buckshot, eight striging and four passing through ais body, The shooting occurred about h o‘ clock,. Se was robbed of his watch and chain, Uther pockets were also rifled, Dr. Foscue was L8 years old, He was wealthy and liked by everyone in Demopolis where he  He leaves a wife and 3 children," JOURNAL, Atlanta, Ga. ocr_text: ROBFRSON, Lewellen  "Seale, Ala,, June 13, 188 - Lewellen Roberson, black, was hanged for the murder of Troy Allen, also black, during last March near Fort Mitchell, He had denied the killing until he reached the gallows when he made a full confession, saying he had shot Troy with a pistol while riding with him, Strangled, Talked freely saying that he had prayed that his sins be forgiven but felt that they were not and he was dying without hope,"  MONTGOMERY ADVERTISER, June 14, 1884.

big_ocr: ROBERTSON, Alexander ("Aleck") 37 ~16 ~ / 70 J/  Robertson, a Jefferson Co., Ala., black laborer, had a bad reputa— tion and was considered a dangerous man by all who knew him, He met a young black woman on the right of way of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad at Trussville, and when she spurned his advances, he drew a pistol and shot her, He then threw her around, disfiguring considerably, B_fore leaving, he shot her several more times, Robertson, illiteraia, was considered an unruly prisoner in the jail both before and after his trial at which he was convicted and sentenced to die, He showed little interest in spiritual consola— tion until shortly before his execution when he began secing a minister and was convérted. His last words, spoken just before he  was hanged in the Jefferson County Jail yard at Birmingham on March 10, 1905, were:"Lord have mercy."  Birmingham NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, March 10, 1905

ROBINSON, Henry |- Black, hanged Union Springs, Alabama, Nov, h, 1887  See large card  Montgomery ADVERTISER, Montgomery, Ala., Nov. 5, 1887 "Referring to Henry Robinson, the negro hung at Union Springs on 11-;=1887, the Union Springs HEERLAD says it is reported that his real name was Henry McLean and that he and his brother killed another negro for his money and wife in Barbour County several years ago, Henry's borther was hanged for this crime but he got away," MONTGOMERY TISER, 11-12-1887, (Note: Wesley McLean, hanged at lay- ton on Jamuary 15, 1874.)
big_ocr: ‘Robinson, a 47—year=old black man who had been born into slavery in the ‘State of Florida, was brought to Alabama as a child and raised in Ala— ‘bama after his mother had been purchased by a man named John Cameron, ‘In 1858 he was married to a woman several years older than he and they became the parents of four children who lived, three boys and a girl,. ‘A field hand, he was sent to Mobille during the Civil War to aid in the erection of breastworks and afterwards he returned to Bullock County, ‘When the war concluded, he and his famly, freed, remained in Bullock County where Robinson worked as a sharecropper on a plantation,  Around 1883, Adam Owen, an 80O—yeareold black man, widely respected by others of his race, moved to an adjoining plantation with his 25«—year— old wife, Polly, In time, Robinson became the lover of Mrs, Owens and their conduct was such that their relationship became general know» ledge. On June 1, 1887, Owens visited Robinson in a field where he was working, possibly to remonstrate with him about his attentions to his wife, and Robinson attacked him with an axe, After Owens was dead, Robinson dragged the body to a log pile and fired it, IKXXX®KK When  others in the neighborhood inquired as to Owens! whereabouts, P lly said that he had gone to Butler County to visit relatives but this  explanation failed to satisfy them and a search was instituted, His skeletal remins were found in the remains of the fire and Robinson     \ ss , but bola seve  Owens had attacke him first with the sze and that the killing was accidental or in self—| defense. Mrs. Owens was also arrested as an accessory before the fact, but she was released at her preliminary hearing when no real evidence against her could be produced and Robinson maintained that she knew nothing of the crime, While his conviction was not appealed, he was granted one 30=day respite from the original date of sxecution to the disappointment of the huge crowd of blacks who were totally tic towards him and had gathered for the hanging on the original date, Then, on Nov, L, 1887, he was ridden in a wagon from the jail to the gallows, 3% miles away on the southwestern boundaries of Union Springs, and hanged, Robinson went to his death calmly and even jJested on the scaffold when he asked Sheriff Charles M, McRae: "Captain, is there any danger of this thing breaking down before you are ready?" The Sheriff assured him that there was not, and one of the several thousand blacks outside the burlap bagging that had been erected around the gallows shouted: "You needn‘t be afraid of anything of that sort," After the cop and noose had been placed over his head, he remarked: "Hanging is might bad, but if a man is ready, why let it be over with as quick as possible and all will be right and well," His last words, spoken just before the trap fell, werer "I am ready," His neck was  broken by the fall gnd KKX he was, pronounced dead in 11 minutes, #p hirer? f} j 0&ch i/ Soe 252707

big_ocr: SMITH, Charley  Smith, a 23—year—old black native of Texas, KXKXXEXXNKKXXAKXXKK was a Seaman who had served in the U. S. Navy, KXXk He had a tenth grade education and had served one term in a Texas Prison for burglary, On July 10, 1948, he was in Mobile, Al2,, EEKEX unemployed and attempting to re—enlist in the Navy, He had applied for unemployment compensa— tion but had not started receiving it, That night, he took a woman with whom he lived part of the time to the hospital and early the next morning he caught a cab to 1754 Limerick St, where he rented a one room house in the back of the main dwelling, Shortly afterwards the lady who lived in the main house was awakened by the sound of groans and she noticed a taxi with the lights off parked in front of her house. She went outside with a flashlight to investigatém and found the unconscious body of driver Monroe Young Ja ckson in the weeds in a ditch, She summoned the police and an ambulance and Jack son died before he reached the hospitals, WKEKXEKKXK It was subse— quently revealed that he had been struck over the head seventeen times with a blunt instrument. When police searched the taxi, they found Smith‘s seaman TD card, his CIO union membership card and other papers  in the front seat and when they showed them to the lady who had found the body, she took them to an upstairs apartment at 301 Dearborn Ste __ they forced the door open and found Smith in the bed with his woman — friend, The shorts that he was wearing were covered with blood and his bloody outer clothing NKAKXKK was soaking in a tub of water, omith confessed having killed Jackson but claimed salf —defens He ‘said that when they reached Limerick St., he did not have enough money to pay the fare and that Jackson had taken the wallet from him to check for himself, Smith said that he crawled over the front seat and that Jackson hit him in the crotch with a lead pipe,. He said that he took the pipe from Jackson and used it to bludgeon him to — death, He admitted that he had stolen the taxi driver‘s moeny and  he showed officers 8B6@ where he had hidden Jackson‘s wallet and watch, After his congiction, his case was appealed to the Alabama. Supreme Court whichh affirmed it and he was electrocuted at the Alabama Stapte Prison on May 26, 1950  43 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 821  A32 szzof

big_ocr: SANDERS, Luke  Sanders, a Perry County, Ala., black man was working with his brother Tom and a group of other black men in a gang supervised by a white man named Mullins, On April 18, 1899, the Sanders brothers had words with Mullins and when they went to work the next day, both were armed, An argument between Mullins and Tom Sanders ensued  over Mullins‘! ordering him to go for a pail of water for the work» men to drink and shots were exchanged with the result of Tom Sanders‘ being wounded,. Luke Sanders then drew his pistol and without warn— — ing emptied the contents into Mullins, Killing him on the spot.  Luke escaped to Arkansas where he was subsequently locaked, arrested and returned to Perry County for trial, Convicted, he received a death sentence., His attorneys appealed the case to the Alabama Supreme Court which, though it did not order a new, mailntained that the case was not one of first degree murder and that they death penalty should not be exacted. It requested the Governor to commute the sentence to life imprisorment, The Governor did grant a respite for thirty days for the Board of Pardons and Parole_to study the request, "Both the Judge and County Solicitor from Perry County appeared and requested that the sentence not be commuted and when two of the Board Members voted against commtation with one voting in favor, the Governor @ided with the majority and allowed the sen— tence to stand. Sanders was hanged in the corrider of the Perry County Jail at Marion on March 6, 1902.  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala, 3—6—1902  / s ~f Fi g A ALL. big_ocr: SEAS, Jim M eS q 7F F [f  Seams, a Tuscaloosa Co., Ala., black man, was wanted by the Sheriff‘s department on a minor charge. When Deputy Sheriff Outrey went to arrest him in the spring of 1888, Seams shot and killed him. He was — taken into custody almost immedately and taken to the Jefferson Co, Jail in Birmingham and held there to prevent his being lynched. He was originally convicted and sentenced to hang in Tuscaloosa County but the State ®K% Supreme Court overturned the conviction and ordered a new trial with a change of venue, He was then tried in Greene Co., convicted and sentenced to hang for the second time., Seams maintained throughout both trials and until he was hanged XK at Eutaw, Ala., on Jan, 25, 1889, that he had shot the Deputy in self defense, J ipa 70 THE EVENING NEWS, Birmingham, Ala, 12—6—1888, page one i 7 1«2 «1889, page one 30 Ive 1=25=1889, page one  fie pheailsy sap tis. big_ocr: $1 C        SSHELTON, Anderson  Shelton, a lias Andrew Hall, was a Jefferson Co., Ala., black man who, with Wesley Hale and Eugene Johnson, had been robbing the box cars of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad at its siding at Ox— moor, On the night of Jan. 13, 1905, they were walking on the track toward Oxmoor when the met L & N fireman Edga r G,. Almon who they decided to rob, Almon resisted, drew a revolver and shot Hale through ths breast before Shelton and Johnson overpowered him and used his own revolver to kill.him, Thinking that Hale was dying, they dragged him into some bushes and left him, He was found the next day and taken to a hospital where he confessed, naming Shelton and Johnson as his accomplices, Hale was tried and conficted first and sentenced to die, Johnson received a life sentience, At his trial, Shelton, who maintained that he was innocent, was convicted largely on the testimony of Hale who had been given a 60—day respite to give evidence, and sentenced to hang also. Hale was executed during the first part of October while Shelton followed him to the gallows in the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham on Oct, 27, 1905, While awaiting execution, he was accused of being the man who had raped two black women in the Birmingham railroad yards, breaking a leg on one of them and seriously injuring the other but ,; as he was already under sentence of death, he was never tried for those two offenses, After he stepped on the scaffold, he denied his guilt for the last time and then spoke his last words to the Sheriff;:  "Go ahead, I am ready." A sister of his victim witnessed the exe— cution from a window overlooking the jail; yard.  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, BIRMINGHAM, AIA.,.0CT. 27, 1905.

notes: The date of the crime is a little uncertain. Different records give different dates.

big_ocr: SUMMERVILLE, Ed Lee:  Summerville, a black man, had abducted a young black ‘girl in Missi— sippi in 1926 and a warrant was issued for him there. Howsver, he had moved to Pickens Co.,A&labama, and it was necessary fop—the warrant to be forwarded there,. When Pickens County. Deputy Sheriff Burt C. Jphnson went to serve the warrant, Surmerville shot.—and killed him,. He then escaped and was not captured until. 1935 when. a fingerprint check revealed that he was serving time on & —road. gang in Scottsboro, Ala., for assault with intent to. kill, He was returned to Pickens County for trial., convicted and sénténeéd to death. "e was electrocuted at Kilby Prison on Aug. 7; 1936.  THEL DOTHAN EAGLE, DOTHAN, AIABAMA, Sheriff W, A. Scott and Chief Deputy B. C, Johnson went to Somerville‘s vogtage in Spring Hill Community, 8 miles from Carrollton on AM of 11°22 with warrant from Columbus, Miss., charging him with kidnapping of 15—year=old negro girl, As they approached cabin, he opened fire firth a barricaded door and both Scott and Johnson killed, He had con— Linued firing after both _ fell mortally.wounded and then fled, Attack _ was unexpected as neither officer had a chance to make move for guns Sheriff was whistling as they entered the gate, Somerville, armed, fle fied. — BIMMINGHAM NEW, 11—23—1926.

big_ocr: | SKIPPER, Lage  Skipper, a black tenant farmer, lived between Newville and Capps Sta— tion, Henry Co., Ala, Several years before the crime for which he was executed, he had gotten into an argument with awhite man, Mr, Baker, and in the course of the difficulty, Baker was slashed across the face and nose with a pocket knife, On Saturday night, Sept, 16 § 1916, Skipper and his wife were returning to their home in a wagons They had been to Newville and Skpper had been drinking, They passed another wagon in which Baker was riding with two other wWitk white men, John A, James and his son, Charles, a Newville barber. Words were exchanged between the white men and Skipper who drove directly to his house and, over the protests of his wife, got his gun and returned to the wagon in which the three men were riding and shot James » inflicting a fatal wound from which he died the next day, Young James and Baker who were unarmed fled for help, Skipper took Mr, James!‘ watch and wallet and fled to Dothan where he caught a train to Jacksonville, Fla, From there he wont to Savannah, Cas p Washington,», D. C, », and finally to — New Jersey where he was captured in May, 1917, At his trial, Skipper claimed that he had shot James in self=defense after the white men had forced him to kneel and pray and whipped him, He was originally sen— tenced to be hanged on Oct. 2, but the Governor granted a respite un= . til Oct, 26, Because of the danger of Skipper‘s being lynched before the Governor Wad reached hisﬁgecision on a commutation, he was taken to the jail at Montgomery until the Governor declined to intervene further, He was then returned to Abbevé@lle where he was hanged before a crowd of 3,000 witnesses on October 26, 1917.  Skipper was allowed to speak from the gallows for one hour before he was hanged and he read a fifteen mage manuscript in which he gave the details of his life, In answer to a direct question, he maintained for a last time that he had killed James in self—defense, Mr, James is buried at the Tolbert Church Cemetery in Henry County where his tombstons erronsously lists the year of his death as 1917.  HENRY COUNTY STANDARD, Headland, Ala., Sept, 23, 1916 ggﬁgeﬁASS FARMER, Headland, Ala., June 1», 1917; Oct. 4, 1917; Nov. Lg 7 ;

big_ocr: | Adolph (Dave)  Smith, a REXX ?23—yeareold Geneva Co., Ala., black man and another black from breenvmlle, Ala., went to the Dundee filling station— grocery store operated by ivy Sammons on Sunday night, June 2 h, 3938, and gained admlttance when they claimed that they wanted t  make a purchase, They robbed Sammonn of $81 at knife point aﬁd  then, as Sammons knelt and pleaded for his life, Smith cut his throat in an unsuccessful attempt to kill him,. An armed possee of about  200 men combed the dense underbrunsh and swamps for the men and Smith was captured at Oak Crove between Geneva and Hartford. He confessed and named his accomplice who was traced from Geneva to Creenville and from there to Birmingham where he also was taken  into custody, The accomplice received a prison sentence, while Smith, who had actually cut Sammons‘ throat in an effort to kill  him and prevent identification, was sentenced to die,. He admitted his guilt once again when interviewed by the Covernor and the Pardons and" P irole Board and they refused to branf clemency, He was electro— cuted at Kilby Prison on Def. 30, 1938.  \ 1 "my  ENEVA COUNTY RERPER, Geneva, Ala., 6/30/19? and 1/5/1939

big_ocr: SNEAD, Buster  Snead, a 4Q—year—old black resident of Bibb Co., Ala., was totally blind. For over a year, he had argued with a black woman, Ellen Mason, over $20.00 that Snead alleged she owed to him, Early on the morning of July 1h, 1947, armed with a Wouble—bit axe," he broke into Mrs, Mason‘s house and went to the bedroom where she was sleep ing with her daughter, Mazell Blackmon» He attacked the sleeping wo— man with the axe, inflicting a wound on the forehead which penetrated to the brain, and a wound on the throatawhich severed her juglar veinp either of which was sufficient to prove fatal, Miss Blackmon was also wounded in the attack, Snead then returned to his own house and when officers arrived, they found the blood—stained axe on his front porth and his clothes were also bloodstained. Snead confessed at the time of his arrest that he had killed Mrs, Mason over the $20,00 debt. Convicted and sentenced to die, the case was taken to the Alabama Supreme Court on appeal where it was affirmed,. Snead was elsctrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on March 25, 1949, 38 SOUTHERN REPorTEr 2nd SERIES 576  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, March 25, 1949  A  4° pt pansion» I/} / 1/5! big_ocr: STEVENSON, ALABAMA, CONTINUED o  Final Statement: "I was born near Jacksonville, Ala., May 9, 1882. My father, J. A. Stevenson, a Confederate veteran. My mother was a Miss Smiths, I was reised on a farm, I went to a country school about one month, I was a member of the Sunday school and a member of the Baptist Church, I joined the church when I was about 18 years of age, My mo— ther joined the church at the same time, I have been kind and helpful. to the poor and needy when in distress. I was run over by a wagaon when I was about ten years old and have always felt that my head was injured by the accident, I have also had two or three blows which have caused uncomciousness, My head was split open when I was a child. I lived with my father and mother until # was 21 years old, I would go away and stay a month or two at a time at work. I always got along with my fatkh r and mother and my brothers and sisters, I have three sisters and four brothers living, I have one sister married, I formed the habit of using wnisky and it has caused me a lohkof trouble, I would like to say to theyoung men of thik country not to use whiskey as it will cause them much trouble, I have been free from gaming and crap=shooting, W., L. Tatum, the sheriff of Crenshaw County, is a nice man and I want to thank him for his kindness wile in his charge. I desire to thank W, H, Sboddard for his kindness and efforts in my bee ¥. ¥ "C#  half Q'Ir‘i “Gﬁbd I am trusting,. —I feel that my sins hatte been forgiven, and that Christ is my savior, I have nothing in my heart against any one living," BIRMINGHAM NEWS 10=22=1909

big_ocr: STEWART , Jimmie  Stewart, a 33—year—old black man, lived at 1} KEERHE Carpet St., _ Montgomery, Ala., with his common—law wife, Ella Owens, On the morning of August 5, 193, he had been drinking and he and Miss Owens got into an argument. When shekleft to go to house of her mother, Mrs, Hannah Langford, a 12 Glass Street, Stew— art threatened to go there and kill everyone at the house, That afternoon he borrowed a pistol and between two and three o‘clock he went to Mrs, Langford‘s house. When she refused to admit him, he forced his way inside and shot her three times before fleeing.  irs. ‘angford died from her wounds that night but Stewart was not captured until March, 1935, At that timgﬁehe confessed killing  Mrs, J"angford but claimed self—defense. siid that he had gone there to get money from Ella who was sleeping and that Mrs, Lang— ford had run at him with an ice pick,. This version was disputed by another daughter of Mrs, Langford who was a witness to the entire affair and Stewart was convicted and sentenced to die, His convic—  tion was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court and a list of several exceptions was filed, but the Court upheld the conviction and he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on May 15, 1936.

big_ocr: THAXTON, Henry  Thaxton, a black resident of Birmingham ,an Ala,, and two companions, stopped two white men, Samuel W. Hunstucker and 4, M, Boyd who were walking to their boarding house near the Birmingham Rolling Mills on She night of Dec. 22, 1906. Thaxton and his accomplices were armed with pistols and demanded the money that the two men were carrying. Thaxton was KEXHX covering Hunstucker and, as he held his pistol  in the man‘s face, Hunstucker sought to turn his héad. Thaxton  then shot him and killed him instantly, Thaxton was the only one  of the trio to be captured and even though he admitted his complicity in the robbery, he denied that he had shot Thaxton and claimed that One of his accomplices had fired the fatal bullet. However, Boyd positively identified him as the gurman and testified to that effect at his trial which Lasted for only four hours from the time of the enpanelment of the jury,. Thaxton was originally scheduled to be exe— cuted on Dec, 27, 1907, and on that day the witnesses had assembled, he had been situated on the scaffold and the noose placed around his neck when, at the very last minite, a 15—day respite arrived from  the Governor in the hopes that Thagzon would rigigﬁ gg ﬁgggp‘ gas of his accomplices wo more respites were gr condemned maﬁ.stili failed to reveal the names, the Governor refused to intervene further and Thaxton was hanged in the yard of the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham on Feb, 10, 1908. The Sheriff who had FEXKEXIKX recently taken office, had promised in his campaign that he would make executions serve as a warning to young men and among the witnesses were three boys under the age of 12 who were ad— mitted by the Sheriff‘s order, The sameSheriff also arranged with Thaxton to throw out his right index finger after the trap fell if he retained consciousness, However, Thaxton‘s neck was broken by  the fall and the only movement of his hands were the convulsive t  2—10—1908 ; Accomplice Rugene Twitty captured in Mobile on 9=2=1909 and made a full confession, saying Thaxton had fired shot, Third man, Jim (aka Red) Johnson not then captured, When Thaxton received first respite, was on gallows, black cap over head, and sheriff had hand on lever when a messenger arrived with respite, B‘HAM News, 9=2«=1909 Convicted on 11=8—1907 in trial that lasted only ; hrs, BN, 11—9=1907

big_ocr: THOMAS, Andrew  Thomas, a 28—year—old white resident of Mobile, A la., had been placed in jail there for some minor infraction of the law. Shortly after his release, he began to abuse his wife and she finally left him, returning to the home of her parents, On the morning of April 30, 1906, he followed her to the home of his mother where she went to visit their child and rushed into the room where she was sitting with an oath on his lips and shot her,. As she sank to the £loor, begging him not to kill her, he fired another shot into her breast and she died instantly, — Thomas was taken into custody shortly after» wards near the scene of the crime. At his trial, he was convicted and sentenced to die, but his execution was delayed while his case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed the convic— tion and sentence, On March 15, 1907, he became the first white man in Mobile County to be executed in forty years when he was hanged in the jail yard there,  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, 1—25—1907 and 150 ALABAMA 31 (h)3 SOUTHERN 371)

big_ocr: — WALKER, Ernest Cornell Um" /LZ";$z./2;7E;77I  Walker, a 2h}«yeareold black resident of Jefferson Co,, Ala., was a Janitor, On the morning of. Nov, 1, 1958, he went to the apartment in Homewood occupied by a building superintendent for whom he had worked in 195 and KKXK«XKXX sought employment, After the superin— tendent informed him that there were, at that time, no vacancies but that he would get in touch with him if one should occur, Walker left but remained in the neighborhood until he saw the superintendent leave, He then returned to the apartment and entered, surprising the superintendent‘s wife, a 8—year=old white woman, After beating her and forcing her to reveal where the shotgun was kept, he dragged her upstairs and forcibly raped her, He then locked her in a closet and waited until her husband returned home, He robbed them of the money they had in their possession and terrorized them with the gun before he left the apartment after locking them in separate clostts. Walker was captured a week later, having positively identified by both the man and the wife who knew him well and he made a confession, At his trial, he pleaded not guilty and not guilty by reason of insani ty and while not evidence was produced to show that he was, in fact, insane, his attorneys sought to show that he was feeble—pinded, His conviction and the sentence of death were affirmed by the Alabama  . Supreme Court and he was electrocuted at Kilby Prison on Dec. },1959, £3 LJ A leaad (  ast words were: "Jesus has saved me.,"  Birmingham, Alabama, Dec. !, 1959

big_ocr: | witkem, ding ove — FER  Walker, a black man, lived with his father, Jim Walker, Sr., in Jefferson Co., Ala,, about eight miles from Birmingham, On the  night of April 8, 1905, he waylaid William D. Hill, a white man who was traveling a seldom used path between his house and a commissary and shot him to death, robbing the body of $22.15. Walker went by the cabin that he shared with his father and then into Birmingham where he boarded a freight train to Ballas County where he was sub sequently arrested, Returned to Birmingham, he confessed that he  had killed and robbed Hill but said that his father had forced him  to do so, The elder Walker who protested his innocence was also arrested and charged with the crime,. Jim Walker, Jr., was tried first, convicted and sentenced to die, At his father‘s trial, he refuted his earlier story and said that the old man had nothing to  do with the crime, Nonetheless, Jim Walker, Sr., was also convicted but because of the doubts ¥XXXE raised in the jury‘s mind by his son‘ conflicting testimonies, he was sentenced to life imprisonment. Jim Walker, Jr., was hanged in the Jefferson County Jail Yard at Birming= ham on March 9, 1906, Before his death, he wrote out a confession in which he once again stated that his father had nothing to do with Hill‘s murder and claimed that he had involved him only because he believed that the old man had turned him in to the authorities,. He Pepeated this confession and absolution of his father from the  gallows just prior to his execution which he met. in a calm manner.  NIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, 3/9/1906  From Death Certificate; 16 at execution;

big_ocr: —Washington, a black man, was a resident of Birmingham, Ala,, where he had been employed by Louis Wallock, a fruit merchant, In mideDecem— ber, 1926, Wallock discharged Washington, an ex=convict, who he sus» pected of having stolen a pistol and they got into an argument over #5,00 that Washington claimed was owed to him in wages and Wallock refused to pay, On the night of Dec. 30, he displayed the stolen pistol to another of Wallock‘s employees and annoum ed his intention of killing the merchant, The other employee, also black, contacted Wallock and warned him of wWashington‘s threats,. Early on the morning of Dec, 31, Wallock and the employee were seated in Wallcok‘s truck which was parked at 17th St, and Morris Avenue when Washington approached and fired xixx five shots into kk Wallock, inflicting wounds from which the latter died one hour later in a Birmingham hos— pital, Washington was captured shortly afterwards in a house at Sixth Alley and 21st St, while in the process of changing his clothes, He was located by the police on the basis of a tip provided by a black woman who said that he had shot at her on the preceding night, Wash» ington maintained his innocence throughout his trial and until shortly before his execution even though he was positively identified as the killer by eyewitnesses, On the day before his execution, he admitted that he had killed Wallock and also confessed to having committed three robberies and two burglaries, Ab the time of his confession, _ two other men were serving prison sentences for one of the burolarles, to which he confessed, He was electrocuted at the Alabama State Pri— son on March 9,. 1928,  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama Dec, 31, 1926; Jane 1, 1927; March 9, 1928,

big_ocr: WHITE, Charles  White (alias C, W. White, alias Herbert William Write, alias James White), a 5l—year—old black man termed "a giant" by the Birmingham, Ala., NEWS, posed as a fortune teller, In 1938 he arrived in Troy, Pike Co., Ala., where he rented a room in the home of ablack woman which he used as his office as well as living quarters. One of his clients was paralytic 20—year—old white woman who was considered to have the mentality of an 8—to—12—year—old child who had an obsession about having her fortune told. On ons of her visits to White, he raped her, telling her that she would soon be married and become  the mother of several children,. when the woman left, she was noticed by several people to be crying and when she told what had happenéd, Waite was arrested and charged with rape which he indignantly denied At his trial he admitted that the girl had paid him money on EK "two or three cccasions" for answering questions and that on her last visit she had received " a full reading." Convicted and séntenced  to die, White‘s case was a pealed to the Alabama S upreme Court which affirmed the conviction, He was electrocuted at Kilgy Prison on  June 9, 1939. He died protesting his innocence and his last words were :"I‘m glad I can sit in the electric chair an innocent man, " THE TROY HERALD, Troy, Alabama  THE BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, June 9, 193°  188 SOUTHERN REPORTER 388

- WHITESIDE, John - -=- large card  Black, hanged Birmingham, Ala., August 26, 1921.  Had murdered with shotgun J. L. Bourgeoise, 73-year-old Confederate Veteran, and his 15-year-old companion, Lacey Murphree, as they were walking on road, returning home from a fishing trip,. After chase of ? days, White- side, who had recently escaped from Talladega jail, was captured in Chattanooga and had Bourgecise's watch in his possession at time, lengthy talk from gallows in which he baid he had bea saved from sins and urged everyone to do wight,"  BIRMINGHAM AGE HERALD, 8-18; 8-28 & 8-27-1921 Worksheet in "Llabama not written up
big_ocr: Whiteside, alias Ambrey Garrett, was a black man who was first arrested in Jefferson County, Ala., on Oct, 15, 1916, and charged with the highway robbery of another black man, Acquitted of this charge, he was sent to the Jefferson County chain gang in 1917 on conviction of vagrancy and carrying a pistol and he subsequently escaped, In 192%, he was arrested in Talladega County on charges of grand larceny and he and several other black prisoners managed to escape from the jail prior to trial, He stole a suit of clothes, a shotgun, pistol and armunition fromthe home of a cousin near Vincent, Shelby County, Ala,, and was fleeing through the woods near Henry Ellen, Jefferson County, on the afternoon of March 22 when he encounted a 73—yeareocld Confederate veteran, J. L, Bourgeonise, and his 15=—yeareold companion, Lacey Murphree, who were returning from a fishing trip on the Cahaba River, Fearing that the lus uss looking for him and that theman and boy would report his whereabouts, he shot Bourgecise in the chest,killing him instantly, and when the boy attempted to flee, he shot him in the back, He took Bourgecise‘s watch and chain, a Masonic ring and some money and fled, The bodies were discovered at & o‘clock that night by the victim‘s families  and bloodhounds were placed on Whiteside‘s trail, He was surrounded at Springville, but managed to hop a freight to Chattanooga and was " followed there by a deputy sheriff who recovered Bourgecise‘s ring | in the railroad yard where Whiteside had dropped it, When he was _. arrested, he still had Bourgeoise‘s watch and chain in his possession but protested that he was innocent of the murders, When he was re— turned to Birmingham, he continued to maintain his innocence but pro«— fessed fear of being lynched and begged to be locked up in jail, A few days later he made a complete confession but at his arraignment he claimed that he had been forced to kill the two by two white men who held guns on him, His conviction was not appealed but he was granted a respite while a mental examination was made wich concluded that he was sane. He was hanged in the yard of the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham on August 26, 1921, Whiteside made a brief talk from the gallows in which he expressed the hope that his sins had been forgiven and urged others not to sin so that they, too, wuld not be punished, —  BIRMINGHAM AGE HERALD, Birmingham, Alabama, 3—24; 3=25; 3—273; 3—293 3=31; h«103; he=273; h=28; 6—263; 8—18; 826 and 8—27—1921,

big_ocr: Jt." f 5 } f l WILLIAMS, Alonzo | M 254 [at O  Williams, a Jefferson Co., Ala., black man, was sentenced to a term in prison on a nonecapital felony conviction, Assigned to work in the Pratt Mines, he became enraged with another convict, Bob Calla— han, and NWEXKK#AXHXMXHJXXXKKXZKXM® struck him in the head with a pick, killing him instantly, On March 18, 1899, he was convicted of this murder,z®® sentenced to life imprisonment and returned to the mines, Once again he became angry with another prisoner and this time his victim was a convictznamed. John Richardson who he murdered in the same manner, Tried for Richardson‘s murder, he was convicted and, in accordance with Alabama‘s law requiring a death penalty for any convict who commits murder while serving a life sentence, he was sentenced to die, His case was appealed bo the Alabama Supreme Court on the grounds that, it was class legislation and the Court affirmed the conviction, reasoning that where a man w@®®k®X was already servihg a life sentence, any sentence less than death would be no punishment at all, After his conviction had been upheld, Williams became con verted to religion and prayed constantly, The commotion that the created was considerable as, druling the course of his prayers, he § would groan, wall and clap his hands, On one occasion, a man passing by the jail thggght that he was being mistreated and complained to the Sheriff, Williams went to the gallows laughing and praying. He urged everyone K®XEXKXHKXHZX present to meet him "in Glory" and his last words, spoken after the black cap was Lowered over his head, werer "Praise Godi"!_ He was hanged in the yard of the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham on June 28, 1901, *  Birmingham News, Birmingham, Ala., June 28, 1901,  30. SOUTEERN 336 nes rma k ha f "(Special Dispatch to the Journal,.) Birmingham, Ala., June 29. — A  lively fisticuff occurred in the ounty jail yard yesterday afternoon between Chief Deputy Sheriff Albert Strarford and Policeman Rogers of Bessemer, The affair was incident to the hanging of the negro, Alonzo Williams, The crowds of curiosity seekers had so thronged the jail yard that it seemed impossible to get rid of them. At this ‘juncture, Mr, Stradford brought a hose into play, and some of the water sprinkled on Mr, Rogers. "r. Rogers became very angry and reprimanded Mr., Strad— ford, The result was that the gentlemen came to blows, but they were  soon separated and everything was all right," JOURNAL, Atlanta, Ga., June 29, 1901 (2=3 &.

big_ocr: name. orem . 47 (JIA  | Williams, a white planter, lived near Montgomery, Alabama, On Jan.  1, 1829, he went to the Montgomery County Court House to attend the | annual hiring of slaves,. As he was entering the door the Court House, Silas Goree, a constable, sought to serve a write on him for debt ; and Williams drewa knife and stabbed him trhough the heart, killing | him instantly,. He was granted a change of venue to Autauga County j where he was convicted and sentenced to die, but his case was appealed to Supreme Court which reversed and remanded the sentence, ordering a newtrial, on the grounds that there were irregularities in  the transfer of the indictment from Montgomery to Autauga County,  was tried a scond time, convicted and on January 27, 1832, he was hanged in Montgomery,  He  A BRIEF KISTO ©  ORY COF MONTGOMERY by 4M, P, Blue, Essg,. big_ocr: WILLIAMS, William C. ("Willie")  Willlams, a 29—year—=old white man, had been sentenced to life im— prisonment from his native Mobile County, Ala., for robbery in 1934, He escaped from a prison gang and made KKX his way to Bir— _mingham, Ala., where, on May 30, 1939, Detective J. T. Moser attempt: ed to arrest him, Williams shot and killed the officer and was captured shortly afterwards, Convicted and sentenced to die, his case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court on the grounds that the fact that he was an escaped life prisoner was mentioned in the indictment and precluded his receiving a fair trial, NEXXHXX  The conviction was affirmed and he was electrocuted at Kilby Prison on June 14, 1940.  PIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, June 1M}, 1940. 4% — 195 SOUTHERN REPORTER 213%

WINTON, Jim Hanged Jefferson Co,. Jail, Birmingham, Ala., 12-20-1901  See large card  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala, 12-20-1901
big_ocr: WINTON, Jim  Winton, allas Will Winton, a 25—year—old black native of Loudon CO# , Tenn., moved to Ensley, Ala,, in 1899 where he was employed by the Decatur Car Wheel Works. He loved his wife dearly and when she threatened to leave him in 1901, he begged her not to do so, They argued for some time and when she walked out of the house and start— ed away, he followed her with a razor and cut her throat from ear to sar, Winton made no effort to escape, and when he was taken into custody, he stated that he loved his wife and had killed her to "gave her from becoming a bad woman,." He seemed to have iﬁffi  lost all interest in living and asked that he be allowed to plead guilty and be sentenced to hang, When it was explained to  him that he could not do this in a c@pital case, he seemed indiffer— ent and made no effort to cooperate #ith his court appointed attor— ney. Convicted and sentenced to hang, he was executed at the Jeffer— son County Jail in Birmingham on Dec, 20, 1901. As he stood on the  gallows, he smiled with his lips closed and it appeared that he was actually stifTling a laugh,. BILIMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, 12~20—1901.

YOUNG  Slave, executed Coosa County, cir. 1851,  On Feb, 4, 1852, Alabama Legislature appropriated to  S, A. Pearch, Sheriff of Coosa County, for feeding Young, a slave, the property of Patrick McKinney, who was con- demned to behung and for all other incidatal expenses to  the execution and burial of the same, $23.50. ACTS OF ALABAMA, Vol, 35, page 506
YOUNG, Gary  black man, electrocuted(Mobile County)on 7=22-1938. Alias ("Horse"), had killed Charles Emanuel,  an aged Mobilian, with a piece of iron,  MOBILE REGISTER, 7-22-19 38

f.YOUNG, Jackson  Jackson Young, colored, was hanged at Seale, Ala., on Nov, 28, 1896, He outraged and murdered his sister about three months ago, The crime was one of the most horrible ever bought to light in the state, He died protesting his innocence and said he would soon be in Abraham's bosom." big_ocr: HLEXANDER, Robert, PUGH, Louis and PUGH, Howard L, S24 /FZ2 —  ub)  Alexander, an 18=<year=old butcher‘s helper, Louis Pugh, 18=—years— old and Howard L, Pugh, 17—=years—old, were all black residents of — _ Tuskegee, Alas Alexander, by kims far the most forceful of the three, was an avid reader of the exploits of the Jesse James and Rube Bur— rows gangs, and he enlisted his two friends into a gang that he planned to form which he hoped would surpass all others in its ex» The three boys managed to pull off a few unspectacular and unprofitable burglaries, On the night of Feb, 2, 1893, they entered the residence of Mr. and Mrs, Jesse Cox, a respected and well=to~do white couple, They demanded money from Mr, Cox and when he refused to give them any, Alexander commenced an assault on Mrs. Cox. When Mr, Cox attempted to protect his wife, Alexandér shot him several times in the body, incapacitating though not killing him, He then proceeded to rape Mrs,. Cox before they escaped. Four other Tuskegee blacks were suspected and arrested for the crime and a lynching was narrowly averted on two separate occasions» Finally the Sheriff  XEXEKXHK secretly took them out of town to the jail in Montgomery for safekeepinge Shortly afterwards, Alexander was arrested on a minor charge, Somehow he managed to carry his pistol into jail with him a,d he showed it to a fellow prisoner, W#KEXMEIMK®K bragging "that  was the pistol that shot old man Coxa" <The other prisoner told the Sheriff what Alexander had said and stated that he had revealed that the Pugh brothers were his accomplices, They were promptly taken into custody and the—ef forts — at interrogation —centered on the younger Pugh who was the weaker of the three boys. ° He confessed ___ _ and all three were indicted, Tried in JX April, they were convicted. —and sentenced — to hangs —Ini tially Alexander—showed —a great deal — of ——— _ bravado, but while awaiting execution he became converted to religion and he was baptized in jail shortly before he was hanged,. The parents —of the Pugh brothers—made—an—ef fort —to have — their sentences commuted — but they were unsuccessful. On May 26, 1893, they were driven in a covered hack from the jail to thé gallaw$ located approximately     a three-quarters of —a mile away. They each made a brief~ statement from

ocr_text: HALE, Richard, JOHNSON, Thomas and RIVERS, Sanf  All hanged at Troy, Ala., on 3-31-1899 for the murder of Mrs., +ra Meyers and her daughter-in-law, Nps, 8,  Meyers, at Josie Beat on 12-18-1898 for robbery.  See large card.  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama Feb,. 25, 1899 March 31, 1899
big_ocr: BALE, Richard, JOHNSON, Thomas and RIVERS, San =" —" 4—1FZ f? .  Hale and Johnson, both white, and Rivers, a black, were residents of rural Pike Co., Ala, On the night of Dec,. 18, 1898, they went to the home of Mrs, Ira Meyers, a widow, and her daughter—in—law, Mrs, E. Meyers, also widowed,. The two wonen ran a small store near their home in Josie Bkat and were generally known to keep large sums of monsy in their house, A young hired man named Cook who lived in the same house with the two women was awakened shortly after midnight by a struggle from the elder Mps, Meyer‘s room and when he rushed in to assist her in her struggle with a man, he was knocked unconscious, When he came to, the house was on fire and he dragged Mrs, Meyer‘s body from the dwelling. He. then returned to the house and dragged out the body of the younger Mrs,. Meyers, Both women had been bru— tally bludgeoned with an ax and while the younger woman was already dked, Mrs, ira Meyers lingered for several days before she also died of her wounds,. The house and all of its contents were com— pletely consumed by the flames, Hale and Johnson wers taken into  custody on suspicion and lodged in the county jail at Troy where  tivers and several other blacks were also being held for investiga— tion, Rivers finally broke and confessed that he had been at the scene of the crime, but he swore that he was forced to accompany Hale and Johnson who he named as the actual killers, stating that they stole several thousand dollars in currency before setting fire to the dwelling in the belief that the bodies of the occupants and all traces of the crime would be d&stroyed. Rivers &KXXXE gave  "ta te‘s evidence at the foint trial of Hale and Jofnson and they were convicted and sentenced to hang, Rivers then stood trial ham- self and though he pleaded guilty and begged the court for mercy, he also was meted the death pmnalty, The Governor refused to intervene and all three were hanged at Troy on March 31, 1899.  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS, hlrmmgahm, Ala.y Fobs 25, 1099 March 31, 1899

big_ocr: ALSTON, William Edgar  Alston, a hl—year—old white man, lived at Dora, Walker Co., Ala, In 1926, he and his twin brother, Julian, killed a man named Melvin Kim— ball, They were granted a change of venue to Tallapoosa Co. and wore there convicted and on Oct. 1, 1926, they were sentenced to life imprisonment, When they were paroled, William returned to Dora and married Christine Freeman. In time she left him and returned to the home of her father, On August 6, 1945, Alston went there and hid un— til all of the family except Christine, her younger sisters and some bables had left and Bken he forced his wife to go into the woods with him,. Shortly afterwards her sister heard her scream and when the other members of the family returned home, a search was started. Her body was found about eight hours later with three deep stab wounds in her back, two deep knife cuts on her neck and cuts on her hands, Al ston, who had been drinking was promptly arrested and chargeq with the crime, Convicted and sentenced to die, his case was automatically appealed to the State Supreme Court which found no errors and he was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on August 16, 196,  THE BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham , Alabama Au§ust7lék 1946 OUTHERN REPORTE sERiESs 87 eze 712 . ; !(, 2 26 SOUTHERN REPORTER ond SERLZS 877 C Mea d auen. 16 oh "Alexander City, Ala., Aorkl 17, 1926—Two youthful country boys, twins are being held here on a charge of murder which they thought they could escape with a fine, They are seid to have confessed to Sheriff J., M. C Gaunt that they killed George Kembrell, 19, to obtain $16.03, The twins are Julian and Ed Akston, 22, They confessed to Sheriff Gaunnt, he said, that they enticed Kembrell to —a point a mile from the Dixie Construction Camp at Cherokee Bluffs, where all three were employed, o the pretext of a hunting trip, When they came to a secluded spot they fired their shotgun at him, blowing off the top of his head, they re» lated, ~Rifling the pockets, they placed Kembrell‘s body in a spring, the sheriff said,. Returning to the camp, fellow workers questioned them, concerning Kembrell, They at first said they did not know, but, questioned separately, told conflicting stories concerning what had happened. Suspecting foul play, employees held them prisoners until $heiff Gaunnt was summoned, He questioned them and they confessed, agreeing to pilot the sheriff to where Kembrell‘s body lay, One of them is reported to have asked the sheriff: "How mich will our fine be" When they were told murder is a capital offense, they appeared greatly surprised,. the sheriff said, Further inquiries at the camp revealed that the twins had plotted to hold up the Dixie Corpany‘s payroll,.  ~Sheriff Gaunnt said and had asked a negro to help them in the job, — This, had they been successful, would have netted approximately $4,500  2 hasan Mirus Af ~! big_ocr: WOODS, John February 8, 181A  {/b 1 &) Woods, a ]7—year—old white Tennessee youth, had served in the Tenne— ssee Militia for less than one month when he went on the expedition commanded by General Andrew Jackson to subdue the Creek Indians in the Mississippi Territory, On Feb, 6, 181}, they were encamped at Fort Strother in what is now Talladega Co., Ala., and Woods KKK had served on guard duty all night, That morning, he received permission to leave his post and eat breakfast, While he was doing so, the officer of the day passed and ordered Woods and his comrades to remove the scraps of their meal from the ground, Woods refused in a most unmllitary—like manner and the officer ordered him arrested. Woods primed his gun and announced that he would use it on the first man to lay hands on him,. When Jackson himself ordered his arrest, the boy surrendered and was promptly court—martialed and sentenced to be shotyfor mutiny, For two nights, Jackson went without sleep as he pondered the fate of the boy. KXXXKKX Finally he decided that Woods! death would help restore discilpline to his disordered armg  and he allowed the execution to take place,. On Feb, 8, 181l;, Woods  was shot by a firing squan composed off Regulars in the presence of nis fellow militia men.  4 Mpi ld     THE RAVEN by Marquis James, Copyright, 1929 by Marquis James. Published by Grossett & Dunlap, New York, Pages 31—32

I believe these are probably the s ame; | "Tuscaloosa, 12-29-1928=Chief Deputy Sheriff Foster Kin | and Deputy Sheriff W, I, Huff spent Monday night at Buhl | | investigating the murder of Charlie Parker wo was found dead in the woods near Buhl Christmas Day with the back  of his head shot away by a load of shot, The officers are holding Ed Skelton and Jim Franklin who have been offi~ clally charged with murder in connection with the crime, pair of bloody overalls were found on the wall of Ed Skel- ton's home near Buhl and othercircumstantial evidence secured by the officers against the men held, The case is nowin the hands of Solicitor E, L, Clarkson with all of  the facts. , Efforts are being made to raise bond of $1,000 for Skelton s release and it is thought he will be able to secure the amount, Franklin has made mo move to secure bail,  B!HAM AGE HERALD, 12=30=1925,

big_ocr: GAST, Joseph Whecler  Gast, a 37—year—old white veteran of World War I, lived with his wife, the former Lillie Vera Boyd, and their six children at Ralph, Tuscaloosa Co., Ala, For a time during the depression, Cast had joined the Civilian Conservation Corps and was assigned to one of ite camps, He returned to his family in August, 1934, and in April of the following year he killed his wife with a shotgun in a domes» tic dispute., At his trial, Gast refused to give any reason for the murder, saying that she was dead and could not defend herself so he would say nothing detrimental to her character. His plea was one of insanity and his defense witnesses who testified in h  pert witnesses as well as severaltlay witnesses who testified that he was sane, Convicted and sentenced to die, his case was appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which affirmed % his conviction, At the hearing before Governor Graves for a commu=~ tation of his sentence, Gast said that he had killed his wife in a jealous rage when she told him that she had been intimate with other men while he was away at the CCC camp, He was electrocuted at the Alabama State Prison on June 5, 1936, His last words were: "I ‘m sorry for what I‘ve MXXKEK done, but I know in my heart that God has forgiven me." He is buried at the Memorial Park Cemetery in Tusca— loosa in a section reserved for war veterans,  The DOTHAN EAGLE, Dothan, Alabama, June 5, 1936.  The TUSCALOOSA NEWS, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, March 12, 1936,  167 SOUTHERN REPORTER, 55h — 7. 35 Z_ Wot/await 36 ¢

big_ocr: [ fee and JONES, Albert Les y 9 ra risa e tae n te rots im o —*  A  Grimes and Jones, 23—year—old BXXEK illiterate black residents of Russell Co., Ala,, had become friendly with some black veterans of the Second World War and were intrigued by their tales of how easy it was to kill] other human beings. They decided to rob a O6l;—year— old white former school teacher and the owner of a grocery store, Daniel W. Pearce and his 57—year—old wife, Mattie Vann Pearce,. at their home at Pearce‘s Cross Roads, a few miles from Fort Mitchell, They origlnally planned the crime for the night of Nov, 23 $; 1952, but were frightened off. The next night, they entered the Pearce home and walted for their return when they shot Mrs, Pearce, knocked Mr, Pearce unconscious and set fire to the house bEfore stealing $70 XFENCXKAIEXXEIEEXEXXLIEZ ond a pistol fran their automobile. The  house was completely consumed by ‘the flames and it was thou ght for     x2»  severa J]. days that a gas explosion had caused the fire, However, an autopsy performed by the State toxlcologist disclosed the fact that Mrs., Pearce had been shot first and the imvestligatlon that followed led to the arrest of Grimes and Jones who confessed the crime o were convicted and sentenced to death, and following a clemency  he are ng Iv a W 3. y ik W P hearing in which gaid that they vould 14iva aa . aand ay a t> 4 (1 LL}; UOLh BAQLC til” U 13115; "(Jot/Ll“ Just-JO as Lac) 0d (117”.LSQ1,f11’lS  Both if thelr lives were spared, the Governor refused to intervene? They were electrocutkd at Kilby Prison on April 23, 195/;, Grimes, though knocked unconscious by the first shock of electricity, soon began breathing and gasping for air and a second shock was necessary  A  to kill Aigts  The Columbus ENQUIRER, Columbus, Ga., 11—26—1952 ; 11—27—1952; XXXXX1 1—=23=195l, and 1;=2);—1951; ?  "..,. When Arthur Lee Grimes was executed in Alabama in 195, the doc» tor found his heart still beating, He stepped back and waited for it to stop, but instead of expiring, Grimes started to shudder violent—  ly and thrash against the straps. "e started to come back to con—  sclousness, gasping and sucking in air, It took seven full minutes of juice, six massive jolts in all, to end his life," AN ENCYCLOPEDIA OFP AMERICAN CRIME, By Carl Safakis; New Yorks Facts on File Publica» tions, 1982; ‘page 238. s

big_ocr: | HARRELL,, Tyrie | _ ~ ee Ta  (Harrell, alias Torrig Harrehgggwaéhﬁf‘M{9k tenant on the farm owned by a 29—year=old white man, Chester Estesy‘about five miles from Tallassed ElmoreyCo,, Ala, , The relationship betweénqﬁhe two men had always been a friendly one and Harrell was regarded as one of the best workers on the Estes farm,. H4PPEll had frequently termed Estes the best "boss man" for whom he had ever worked and only the week preceding their difficulty had signed up to remain on the farm for another year.  On August 2h, 1935, Haéaell sold a bale of cotton and instead of going to the home of Estes and making a prompt settlement, he purchased some whiskey which he drank that night and the next morning, Around 9+00  A, M,, Estes, accompanied by a friend, went to Harrell‘s home and Es» tes asked him if he had settled a $2,50 debt for which Estes had stood at a rural store and Barrell replied that he had, Estes then suggested that they go to the store and verify the settlement and, without warn— ing, Harrell drew a pistol and shot him inflicting a wound from which Estes died that afternoon in a Tallassee hospital, While a posse and bloodhounds searched for him, Harrell surrendered to a private citi—  zen and was taken to the jail at Wetumpka, At his trial he msintained that he had fired only in self=defense after Estes had advanced on him with a lapge rock but this was at variance with the evidence which  showed that Estes had run when Harrell drew the pistol and that Harrel] had pursued him firing. The case fas affirmed by the Alabama Supreme ( Court on appeal and he was electrocuted at Kliny Frison on June 17, 1936, His last words were to the Penitentia ry Warden: "Thanks for  what you have done for me,"  167 SOUTHERN 728 WETUMPKA H ERALD, Wetumpka, Alabama, 8—29—1935

big_ocr: HUGHES, Asbury, HUGHES, George, and SMITH, George . f“ / *~ / 5 7 7  Asbury Hughes, 21—years—old, his ?0—year—old brother George and 29— year=old George Smith, with the Hughes? brother‘s sﬁepfather,_John @rsyson, on the nignt of March 25, 1803, went to the home of Henry Porter near Carpenter, Ala., and terporized the household which con— sisted of Mr, and Mrs,. Porter, two other women and two young girls, demanding $500, When Porter explained that he did not have that kind of money at hame, they poured coal oll over some bedding and set fire to the house,. When the familly .attempted to save some trunks containing valuable papers and other treasured belongings, they prevented their doing so and tried to keep them in the burning house with weapons. Fortunately all escaped, but were —able to save only the clothes that they were wearing. | Asbury Fields wa spositively ldentified at one of the arsonists, and he, his brother and step— father were taken into custody on. April 9. George Smith, who was wanted in Ceorgia for the murder .of m man named Lum Street in Dade County, and in Tennessee for the murder of arevenue agent was cap— tured near Carpenter on April 27. _All four—of tho prisoners pro— tested their innocence, but they were convicted at their trial. The jury recommendbd mercy for Grayson and he was sentenced to  life imprisonment, but the Pughes brothers and Smith were sen— %     tenced to hang,. The three men were hanged from a commux gallows with three crossbeams "dJOlﬂ¢Pg the county Jail on Aug. 1, 1801,  Ah crowd estimated at 3,000 gathered for bur ﬂ"“uht10ﬂ and 150 armed men were detailed to mw Lntain order. Irlor to the executl ons Smith‘s wife rushed : up on the gallows and threw her arms around her husband‘s neck and had to be—forcibly removed, For a time, it lobked as though the guards.mightb have to firs on the crowd when they attempted to tear down the enclosure that had been built to &nsure the privacy of the proceedings. Though they con— tinued to deny their gu17t, Asbury ﬂubnap made one final statembnt that indicateﬂ that they were guilty, Just before they wore hanged he said: "You scusht to turn Uravxon alooses He was not there." This was the first instance in Maba ma nlutory for white men to be hanged for the crime of arson, f  THE STORY OF SCOTITSEORO , ALAQUJA by Wy do 4¢btc Rich Printing H1  $0 SNQ‘s a Nashville, 4 van“  /o, A /al—amia. 3 /  é/Wﬁc/éa ﬂo%,ﬂ€aa

ocr_text: JIM June 21, 1837  Slave, executed Tuscaloosa Co., cir, 1837  Act of Alabama Legislature passed 11-24-1837 appropriated $450 to Daniel Dent, being $ value of slave Jim, executed in Tuscaloosa County and also $30 to Sheriff James G, Blount for executing him and two others, Additional #30 to John D, Phelan for prosecuting the three, ACTS OF ALABAMA, Vol. 23, pp 92 and 123.  The New York Herald of August 1, 1837 (2/4) reports the éxecution of two slaves in Tuscaloosa for the attempted  murder of a "Col, Dent" probably on June 21, 1837. I feel that this is the case and the other is the two slaves  belonging to S, M. Meek.

big_ocr: content od lun  fﬁﬁiﬁﬁﬁﬁi‘Jih"éhdeODGERS}’Jbé” y oat m, 2 v og 3 Blacks, hanged at Birmingham, Ala,, March 25, 1910, They went to Ens— ley during the State Fair in 1908 and entered store of John Simms, black merchant, where they ordered 5¢ worth of tobacco, They gave 10¢ in payment and as Simms was making change, Powell drew pistol and pointed at him, Simms grabbed gun and was about to get the better of Powell him when Powell cried to Rodgers to shoot which Rodgers did, Powell admitted to number of robberys and siad he. shot Herbert Johnson on llth St., Birmingham, on July kth for which he was never arrested, Powell reared in Goodwater, Ala., and Rodgers also native of Alabamae Smallest crowd to ever witness hanging in Jefferson County saw this one, even newsmen being deputized, Both spoke from gallows, Rodgers saying that his mother and white friends tried to send him to school and teach him to do right thing but he would not listen,  Powell said that since he was born almost had been bad, had stolen, committed highway robbery byt had never killed any man, At Rodgers‘ request, Dep, Sheriffs Joe Kantznester and Eugene Robinson mounted scaffold and shook hands with both men. Hever of trap pulled by Sheriff Higdon, Dep. Sheriff Percy Higdon cut string holding lever and in doing so severely wounded two fingers of the Sheriff inflicing an injury which Dr, had to dress inmediately, Drop fell at 11:03 and  Powell, the smaller, quivered for several minutes, Rodgers never  moved after fall, Powell declared dead in 11 minutes and Rodgers in 18 minutes, both necks being broken, Both bodies given to relatives, Powell‘s to go to Keliyton and Rodgers to be buried in Birmingham, — ~They were baptized in bathbub in county jail at 9 AM on morning of deaths, The widow of Simms and her sister allowed to visit and they begged the womens!‘ forgiveness which was given. |  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., March 25, 1910. big_ocr: AE; BEN and CHARLES 2—20—1835 hanged (probably Russellville, Ala.), on Feb, 20, 1835.  _ Crime in Russell‘s Valley on 1=25=1835. Datelined TUSCUMBIA NORTH _ ALABAMAAN. "It falls our lot to have to record in the columns of your journal, one of the most cold blooded and outrageous murders ever committed in a Christian land, on the person of Mr. Harvey Gholson, son—of Francis Gholson, Esq., of Russell‘s Valley, by a batch of negro fellows on the evening of last Sabbagh about I; o‘ clock PM, It appears that one of the fellows (Elijah) belonging to Mr, Lawler, a close neighbor of Mr. Gholson, had been detected by young Mr, Gholson in dis posing of money stolen from his young master, Mr, Lawler, and that in the act he took the money from him and told him he would retain it un til he saw his master about it, All this transpiring in Russellville and on a Sabbath day, gave the fellow every opportunity to collect his band of assassins, which it seems he lost no time in doing, and placed them about 2$ miles on the road from town = Elijah himself following the deceased, who was on horse—back; until they arrived at the spot destined for the murder and there in an indescribable manner, horribly mangled the person of / our much lamented friend by dakking out his  brains and cutting his throat from ear—to=ear — then dragging him abou! ten paces from the road and rifled him of some $40 with everything els they found on h&s person, and then left him a prey for the vultures and fled, Some six or seven of the band who wre supposed to have been | cancemed in this infamous deed are in custody = but the captain, — _ Elijah, is not yet taken (Wednesday night) but was seen on the sklrth of the mountain this morning, brandishing his war instruments; we | apprehend no doubt, however, but our worthy citizens will have him, as many of then are now on the scout, = Later: We understand that all — — implicate d in the murder have been apprehended, " SOUTHERN ADVOCATE, Huntsville, Ala., Feb. 3, 1835 (3—2), "Tuscumbia, Feb, 21, 1835=  Of the five negroes brought to trial last week as principal and accessories to the murder of Mr,. Gohlson, only one, Elijah, was con— victed, He was sentenced to be hung on Friday (Feb, 20, 1835)." SOUFHERN ADVORATE, March 3 1835 (25).

Montgomery, Alabama, Feb, 6, 1926-Criminals sentenced to | death after Feb, 28, 1927, in Alabama will be electrocuted | at Kilby Prison instead of dying on the gallows as has | been the custom in this state. This was the contents of a statement issued by Gov, Brandon in which he stated that \the state was making prepearations for the installation of an electric chair at Kilby Prison by Oct. 1, 1926, the date set by a law eneacted in 1923 by the Legislature, Thi was date set for installation of electric chair systems Sen, J, C, Inzer of Gadsden is the author of the law abolishing the gallows and it was only after a fight had b been carried on in the state legislature for ten years that it was finally passed in 1923, When Kilby Prison was - planned a section was set aside for an electric chagr %nd fBrlﬁhEPﬁeBEBbﬁBhSeﬁﬁb a separate bulldlnglwil; be§ ull  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, B'ham, Ala., 2-6-1926

| pIECTRIC CHAIR FOR DOGS IN BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA. "Birmingham, Ala., April 30, 1914. - A death chair to provide death by electrocution has been installed by Birmingham, it will be used in ridding the city of dogs and the canines which are picked up by the dog catcher and held for the usual time and not reclaimed will be placed on the XWKXIX death chair and electrocuted, It was decided that the old way of putting to death the dogs was cruel and so the death by electricity was suggested. A ** try-out was made this morning and the scheme found to work well, It is expected that a couple of thousand dogs every year will be put out the way via the electri- city route." ADVERTISER, M,ntgomery, AL, 5-1-1914 (9-1,)

"The number of legal executions during 1888 has increased | over last year when it was mich smaller than for many years | previous, The total number was 87 as compared with 79 in 1887, 83 in 1886 and 108 in 1885, The executions in the several states were as follows: Alabama, 5; Arkansas, 5¢ California, 5; Connecticut, 1; Delaware, 1; Georgia, 3; Illinois, 2; Indiana, 1; Iowa, 1; Kansas, ?; Kentucky, 1; Louisiana, 3; Maryland, 1; Massachusetts, 1; Minnesota, 1; Mississippi, h; Missouri, h; New York, 9; New Jersey, h; North Carolina, 2; Chig, 3; Oregon, 1; Pennsylvania, 5; South Carolina, 5; Tennessee, 2; Texas, 6; Arizona, 1; Idaho, ?; Montana, ?; Washington, 1; Wyoming, 1; Indianz Territory, ?; Of this number, all were males but one,  57 were whites, 29 negroes and one chinaman,  ATLANTA CONSTITUTION, Atlanta, Ga, 1-6-1889

big_ocr: Duncan, a 27—year—old white native of Rushtown, Ohio, had worked at various eccupations including railroading and as a fireman on Puget Sound steamers befere joining a meb of safe—blewers including Frank Miller, Frank Edwards, Tom Fay, John D, West and a hoodhum known only ag "New Yerk Harry,." On the night of March 23, 1900, the gang was in Birmingham, Ala., and breke into the Birmingham office of Standard Oil beat and shot the night watchman, blew the safe and stole ever $300. The watchman gave an alarm and later that night Duncan and Miller were stepped by police officers J, W. Adams and G, W., Kirksey for questioning. They were walking to the police station with the officers when they suddenly drew pistols, Miller shot Adams and Duncan shet Kirksey, Both officers returned the fire as the two prisoners fled, but none of. their shots were effective, Kirksey died shortly afterwards, but Adams lingered until after the gang had been captured fellewing an underworld tip and, en his death—bed identified Miller as the man whe had shot him and Duncan as the murderer of Kirk»  » . Batt — f ae 332m a gig: 31311 were tried £1.th fer the murder of Adams and Miller re  ath sentence while Duncan received iter imprésonment, — He maintaine ed a sentence of life  d that he was not wit I : the officers were shot and Miller swore thattghg‘i ﬁiﬂegteylﬁr sey was "New York Harry ", the only member of the gang who was never | | _ _captured, Duncan was then tried for the murder of Kirksey, convicted and sentenced to hang, On Jan, 20, 1902, he escaped from the Jeffer— son County Jail in Birmingham and remained &t large until September, | 190, when he was taken inte custedy in St, Apgustine, Fla,, as a __/ suspect in a bank rebbery, His identity became known because of the wanted posters that the Birmingham Police had clrculated over the United States and he was returned there to await execution. A con— siderable effort was made to have his sentence commted on the grounds that he was not with Mller when the officers were shot, but the Governor refused to intervene and he was hanged in the Jefferson Co,  Jail Yard on Nove 25, 1904, He met his fate calmly, protesting his innecence until the very end,  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Alabama, Nov, 2 5, 190. big_ocr: BROWN, mag M Z q—20—/40) ,  Brown, a black native of Welford, S, C., who stated before his exe» cution that his real name was John Wilson, was employed as a laborer on a farm in Springville, St. Clair Co., Ala, On May 7, 1901,'he was working in a field when the 18—year—old daughter of a prominent white farmer passed returning home from school, Brown followed her to a point by a pond where he crept up behind her and choked her severely before he raped her,. Afterwards, he threatened to throw her into the pond and drown her but spared her life when she pro— mised not to identify him, While the girl staggered home, he fled first to Birmingham and then to Anniston, Atlanta and finally Charleston whire he was arrested a fow days later, When the girl related her ordeal and identified Brown who she knew as her assail= ant, a posse of about seven hundred men started combing the area. An unidentified black man was shot and killed in Leeds because he refused to stop and be identified,: When Brown was returned to Alabama, he was lodged in the Jefferson Co,. Jail at Birmingham for  . safekeeptng until Aug,. 22 when he was tak A was con ;n§5d by a JEEY that delibegh tedégzggg shville where he  nly e%even minutes,. The girl appeared as a witness against him and related the assault, positlvely identifwrlng Brown as her raplst. After the trial, a mob | attempted to storm the court house and lynch Brown, He was defended by the Sheriff am 28 deputies and one of the mob, Walter KXXK Blanke enship, was shot and killed, A heavy rain started and Brown was sneaked out of the back of the courthouse into the woods, and taken to a train where he was returned to Jefferson County to await his execution. On the train, he confessed to the deputies and the re— porters who accompanied them tha t he had raped the girl. He was returned to Ashville under heavy guard on September 20, 1901, and hanged from a gallows on the court house yard, The fence surrounding the gallows was only twelve feet high while the gallows stood twenty fest above the ground, so the large crowd that had gathered to wit— ness the execution had a good view of the entire proceedings. Brown  repudiated his confession from the gallows and stated that he had made it only befause he was frightened.  THE BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., 8—22 &£8—23—1901 & 9=—20—1901 Victim was Miss Dell Garrett, JOURNAL, Atlanta, 9—20—1901 (3/5.)

EESTER, James  White, hanged at Tuscaloosa, Alabama, on Nov, 30, 1827, for the murder of his wife., See the worksheet in Alabama - not written up.  "Tusgaloosa, Uct, 20, 1827-James Hester, convicted of the murder of his wife, received sentence of DEATH this morn- ing, to be executed on the 30th of next month, The judge's charge, though short, was deeply impressive, but if appeared to have no effect on the obdurate criminal, Three Sisters of Hester's remain in jail, indicted as pare ticipants in the murder of irs, Hester -= the limits of the present term no affording time for their trial," COURIER, Charleston, SC, November 8, 1827 (1124)

big_ocr: SCOTT, Bill ﬂ “7297/ 09 F y  Scott, a Hale Co., Ala., black man, was a tenant on land owned by John A, Singley, a prosperous and respected planter and store owner who lived approximately eight miles from Greensboro,. On Dec. 1, # 1897, Singley went in to Greensboro and transacted business KKXZK netting him $700.00 which he took back home with him, It is believed that Scott somehow knew that Singley had the money in his home for late that night he, went to the Singley residence and summoned the farmer outside on the pretext of helping him retrieve a stray mule, After the two men had walked about 150 yards ffom the Singley resi— dence, Scott turned on him,felled him with a club and cut his throat from ear to ear. He then went back to the house ; entered At and  cut the throats of Mrs, Singley and the Singley‘s only child, a 10= year—old hy, He then ransacked the house, found the hidden money and fled, Singleyt was discovered by a neighbor who had started home late and he survived until the next day, positively identifying Scott  as his assailant before he died. Mrs, Singley and the child were  $1?  dead when help reached the house. Scott was captured a week later by a black tenant in Perry County at whose house he had stopped for food,. He was held in the jail at Marlon for a time, but then moved to Selma because of the intensity of the feeling in Greensboro and the fear that an attempt to lynch him could be more effectively. prevented in Selma, He KXK confessed that he had killed XKZ Mr, and Mrs, Singley but said that the boy had been killed by some other ‘black men who he sought to implicate. However, all had proven all— bis and Scott alone was tried, convicted and sentenced to hang. He was hanged in the jail yard at Greensboro on Feb, 25, 1898, before a crowd of 100 witnesses,. He met his death without a tremor and  his neck was broken by the fall, killing him instantly.  mﬁamammYOFGmmmmmw,Aummm.  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala, 2—25—1898  ~>
