big_ocr: DYR, Albort Are T. gets.  Dyer, a 3}—year—old white man, was a steward in a Birmingham, 41a. , hotel, He met his 18—ysar—old wife, a clgarette girl, while working there and persuaded her to marry him in spite of her reservations because of the difference in their ages. Trouble developed when Dorothy became pregrant because Dyer wanted the child and she did not,. When he refused to agree to an abortion, she left him and moved into an apartment with the hotel‘s 2?—year=old hat—check girl, Dorothy Lyemance. After his wife left him, Dyer started drinking heavily and on the afternoon of Nov. 12, 1939, he purchased a cheap revolver and went to the hotel which was crowded with Armistice Day who had just left a football game, When he found Dorothy in the crowd, he asked her to return to him. She refused and he | drew his pistol and shot and killed both her and "Irs. Iymance. After he had emptied the revolver into the two women, he exclaimed "I am on my way to the electric chair," and stood holding the pistol until police arrived to take him into custody, Se admitted killing the two women but he later said that he was sorry that he had killed his wife,. He expressed no remorse SXXZK over the murder of Mrs, Lyemance  saying that he blamed her Bor breaking hp his home by encouraging his wife to date other men and that she deserved to die. Tried, con»  victed and sentenced to death, his case was appealed to the Alabama State Suprme Court which affirmed the sentence, He was electrocute at Kilby Prison on January 9, 1942, dying with a prayer on his Lips,.  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., Jan, 9, 1942.  . SOUTHERN REPORTER Ind SERIES 311  /a Cy Wé77

JACKSON; Julius —— —— y sono a crus mi f QFZ;Zf4LA,0.dH{dQ._-f + © ¥ | Jackson, a inutive Talladega Op., Ala., Negro approached the parked car near which Leamon Shields, a Sycamore KXX sawmill owner and his  |_ divorced companion, Mrs, Vera Edwards were sitting on the night of  | Dec. 14, 1940, When the couple heard his approach, Shields turned to | see who it was and Jackson fired a shotgun into his chest, killing him instantly,. He then dragged Mrs, Edwards into a field where he  _ raped and robbed her, It is believed that he would have killed her  ~ also had not an automobile approached as he was completing the attack. _dJackson went to his home where he told his wife what he had done and threw Mrs, Edwards! wrist watch into a well where it was recovered when Mrs, Jackson related her husband‘s confession to officers., Jack= son escaped and was not captured until Jan, , 191, when he was cor— nered by two farmers in a barn near Weowka, Because of the intensity of the feelings in Talladega County, he was taken directly to Kilby Prison where he confessed the murder, the robbery and the attack and  he was held there until his trial began, From the witness stand Mrs, Edwards positively identified him as Shield‘s murderer and her  attacker and he was convicted and sentenced to die. When he was asked for his last words at his electrocution on July 11, 1941, he  (rere  v  > replied: "I only wants to say that you all has been good to me, I thanks you."  The Talladega Daily News, Talladéga, Ala, 1=—6—l; 2—2l—l4l; 2=2)4—)}1;  2=25=llg 2=26—l1; 741-441. Clippings provided by Christina Diebold, Reporter. o

Cunningham, a black man, was a resident of Talladega, Ala., had never before been in trouble and was generally considered a quiet and peaceable man, However, on Feb, 12, 1921, he had been drinking when he entered a Talladega store and stole a $5.00 sweater,. A clerk immediately reported the theft to Policeman Eugene Hobbs and shortly afterwards Hobbs stopped Cunningham in an alley to question him, Cunningham drew a straight razor and slashed Hobbs repeatedly in the throat, inflicting fatal wounds, Cunningham then ran from the alley and Hobbs staggered out, calling to passersby to stop Cunningham, He was subsequently captured in another alley where he had taken refuge and was taken to Hobbs who lay dying on the ground and identified Cunningham as the man who had cut him, Cunningham maintained that he had only held Hobbs while another black man did the cutting but the subsequently admitted that he alone was involved, A mob formed and the Sheriff hastily drove Cunningham out of town and, in a circuitous manner, took him to Odean, twenty miles distant, where he planned to flag a freight train and take him to the Annison jail, The crowd anticipated this mogd—and caught the train at Sylacuaga,. When it was flagged at Odean, they attempted to leave the train but the Sheriff held them at bay with his revolver while his deputies took the priso« ner into the woods and they subsequently walked to Anniston with him, — From Anniston he was taken to the Jefferson County Jail in Birmingham — where he was held until his trial when he was returned to Talladega, tried, convicted and sentenced to be hanged, The conviction was affirmed by the Alabama Supreme Court on Appeal and the Governor de clined to intervene, On June 16, 1922, he was hanged at Talladega  and he was pronounced dead eleven minutes after the trap fell,  BIRMINGHAM AGE EERALD, Birmingham, Alabama, 2—13 and 2—1};—1921; June 15 and June 17, 1921.  #     93 Southern Lh6

big_ocr: AE; BEN and CHARLES 2—20—1835 hanged (probably Russellville, Ala.), on Feb, 20, 1835.  _ Crime in Russell‘s Valley on 1=25=1835. Datelined TUSCUMBIA NORTH _ ALABAMAAN. "It falls our lot to have to record in the columns of your journal, one of the most cold blooded and outrageous murders ever committed in a Christian land, on the person of Mr. Harvey Gholson, son—of Francis Gholson, Esq., of Russell‘s Valley, by a batch of negro fellows on the evening of last Sabbagh about I; o‘ clock PM, It appears that one of the fellows (Elijah) belonging to Mr, Lawler, a close neighbor of Mr. Gholson, had been detected by young Mr, Gholson in dis posing of money stolen from his young master, Mr, Lawler, and that in the act he took the money from him and told him he would retain it un til he saw his master about it, All this transpiring in Russellville and on a Sabbath day, gave the fellow every opportunity to collect his band of assassins, which it seems he lost no time in doing, and placed them about 2$ miles on the road from town = Elijah himself following the deceased, who was on horse—back; until they arrived at the spot destined for the murder and there in an indescribable manner, horribly mangled the person of / our much lamented friend by dakking out his  brains and cutting his throat from ear—to=ear — then dragging him abou! ten paces from the road and rifled him of some $40 with everything els they found on h&s person, and then left him a prey for the vultures and fled, Some six or seven of the band who wre supposed to have been | cancemed in this infamous deed are in custody = but the captain, — _ Elijah, is not yet taken (Wednesday night) but was seen on the sklrth of the mountain this morning, brandishing his war instruments; we | apprehend no doubt, however, but our worthy citizens will have him, as many of then are now on the scout, = Later: We understand that all — — implicate d in the murder have been apprehended, " SOUTHERN ADVOCATE, Huntsville, Ala., Feb. 3, 1835 (3—2), "Tuscumbia, Feb, 21, 1835=  Of the five negroes brought to trial last week as principal and accessories to the murder of Mr,. Gohlson, only one, Elijah, was con— victed, He was sentenced to be hung on Friday (Feb, 20, 1835)." SOUFHERN ADVORATE, March 3 1835 (25).

DANIELS, Henry, Jr., and ROBINSON, Curtis  Daniels, 19—years—old, and Robinson, 20—years=—old, were black resi— dents of Mobile, Ala., who were employed as Raborers at Turner Termi— nals in that city, On several occasions they had discussed the possi— bility of having sexual relations with a white woman,. One night around 10 o‘clock, after they had attended a meeting at the C. I. 0, meeting hall, they decided to lay in wait and Rape the first white woman who they could find. They stood at the mouth of an alley on Texas St, and when a white matron who had jeft work and was going home passed, they grabbed her from behind and dragged her about 50 feet into the alley where they took turns raping her. After theyhad completed the assault, they ran down Texas St. to Dearborn St, where they separated, The woman, who had been beaten and choked during | the assault, reported it immediately and after several innocent blacks had been taken into custody as suspects, a black woman who had seen Daniels and X&KXKKXSK Robinson running from the scene of the crime provided the police with their names and they were taken into custody. The woman who had been attacked identified both of them and they both  confessedAt their trials, which were held separately, both repudiate their confessions and sdid that they had made them out o? Ea re Both the black woman who had seen them running and the woman who had been raped identified them at their trials and evidence was offered showing that the trousers that both had worn bore evidence of sexual intercourse and carried dirt on the knees and legs that matched that found at the scene of the rape. Both were convicted and sentenced to die. Their cases were appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court which afffimed the convictions and they were electrocuted at the Alabama tate Prison on August 13, 1943. f i pot  11 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 732 * fﬁ‘iwf ec 9  11 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES 756 rX to PS _ " 2 » * U As. big_ocr: ss —  BOYINGTON, Charles R. S. —  maen fo p          Boyington, a young white Journeyman ater, was a native of Litch» field, Conn., who had made his way by Bea to Moblle, Ala., where he | was unemployed and supported largely by a friend and fellow printer, Nathaniel Frost, who, though in dellcate health, had some Financial means,. Barly on the afternoon of May 10, 183, the two friends went for a walk and the next morning, Frost‘s body was foud "cut and man» gled" in a wooded area bordering the Old Church Street Cemetery. Boyington had left Mobile and, as he was the last person seen with Frost, he became the immediate suspect. He was captured a few days later at Claiborne, Ala., on a river boat headed north and just be— fore he was takep into custody, he was seen to XHEEXKKXX throw a watch resembling one missing from "rost‘s body overboard,. He was also found to have a considerable sum of money in his possession  and he was known to be virtually penniless previously,. Returned to Mobile, he was tried, convicted and sentenced to die for having mur— dered his friend for the purpose of robbery, Though he steadfastly denied his guilt, Boyington offered very little defense and, as. he was convicted on clrcumstantlial evidence, it is gust? beliefireé by many that he was innocent,. Somsthing of a romanticlist, Boyingtoh possessed germine poetical ability s and many of the peems that he  wap WJ jfwrotce in gall as Wbll as those WBLLtfm bv him to a Mobile “ml ”730 whom ‘he was engaged were subsequently publ ished. He XK refused all mall- gilous—consolation and, on Fobs 20, 1835, dressed in a blank: “$111, and & silk hat, he was allowed to iollour behind the cart bearing his casket to the site of execution. Heo appeared to be accepting nis fate calmly, | nut after his arms ware bound, he frantically broke loose and sought ‘to flee Into the crowd that had glthwmd to witness the execution,. He Rich. easily subdued, returned to the gallows and hanged,. After the ‘trap had 11,11 he managed to loosen his hands and tore at the rope around his no 0L m a rim, perate attempt to prolong his lifs, He was buried in a pauper‘s Name in —the Old Church Strest Cemetary, a few yards from where Frost had been killed and a huge oak tree grew from his grave which is known as "The Boyington Oak." big_ocr: MITCHELL, Robert  | Mitchell, a young black man, lived with his grandmother and step» srandfather, Isabelle and Sam Hooks, on the latter‘s small farm in Bullock Co., Ala, Robert assisted the old man with the labor on the farm and, as he was the only near relative, it occurred to him that should Hooks die he would fall heir to the farm and the livestock,  On the morning of April 30, 1877, he put some arsenic into the cup  \ from which Hooks drank his morning coffee, When the old man tasted ‘of it, he complained that it was bitter and refused to drink it, Mrs, Hooks then drank the entire cup, thinking that her husband was criti=— clzing her abllity as a cook, In a short wile, both were seriously il1 and a physician was surmoned, When he arrived, he found Mrs, Hooks in a dying condition and Mr, Hooks hopelessly paralyzed, He diagnosed their illness as arsenic poisoning and Mitchell and his girl friend were both arrested and charged with the murder, At his trial, an ex—« ception was maken when the physician stated that he would not have dianosed the NMWXKKXXX death of his grandmother as being caused by arsenic had he not learned from Mr, Hooks that he kept the poison on the premises,. Mitchell was convicted and sentenced to die and his case was affirmed by the Alabama Supreme Court on appeal, Even though he had made statements both before and after the trial that indicated that he was guilty, he denied from the seaffold that he bad adminis— tered the péison in a fifteen minute speech, He was hanged before a crowd of approximately 10,000 persons at Union Springs on August 23, 1878, becoming the first person in the history of Bullock County to be executed,. He wont to his death calmly and with little show of SMO—~ tion and his last words, spoken in response to the Sherlff's query as to whether or not he was ready, were "Yes, sir,"  EENRY COUNTY REGISTER, Abbeville, Alabama, August 30, 1878 RALEIGH OBSERVER, Raleigh, N. C., August 2h, 1878 ATLANT A CONSTITUTION, Atlanta, O2, August 24, 1878  58 ALABAMA M7

RASH, Charles  Rash, a black man, was a Colbert County, Alabama, farmer, He and his wife had frequently quarreled and he was known to have threatened and otherwise mistreated her on a number of occasions, He admitted that, one morning in August, 1877, they had argued because she had taken some eggs from the hen‘s nest and prepared then for breakfast and that he had struck her with a stick before going to the fiklds to plow. Late that afternoon, a neighbor passed and Rash asked him to help. in preparing a piece of equipment, The neighbor agreed and Rash said that he would wait until he returned, When the neighbor reached his home a short distance away, he heard the report of a  gun shot from the Rash residence and rushed back there, When he entered the house, he found Rash holding his wife‘s head,from which blood was gushing from a wound through the bar,and crying, Rash claimed that he had told her he was going hunting and that she had attempted to take the gun from him by its muzzle when it accidentally discharged, Physicians who examined the body said that the wound could not have been inflicted in the manner described by Rash and  he was arrested and charged with her murder, Before his trial he and several other prisoners in the county jail escaped when they rushed and overpowered the jailer who was attempting to feed th em. | Rash remained aft large for several months before he was recaptured near the scene of his wife‘s death. At his trial, he continued to maintain that she had been accidentally killed but he was convicted and sentenced to die, The case was unsuccessfully appealed to the Alabama Supreme Court and, after received a one month‘s gubernatorial | respite, he was hanged from behind an enclosure erected in the Colbert County Jail yard at Tuscumbia on April 25, 1879, in the first North Alabama execution in a new law requiring that executions be private, Rash continued to maintain until his execution that his wife had accidentally killed herself and, after being baptized a Catholic,  he went to his death unassisted and without making any statement,  4A large and disorderly crowd gathered outside the enclosure at the —  time of the exegtuion,  EUTAW MIRROR, Eutaw, Alabama, April 29, 1879 — NATIONAL POLICE GAZETTE, April 12, 1879 (10=2) & 5—10—1879(10—1) 61 ALABAMA 89 ‘

big_ocr: DUNCAN, Henry "2 of—» 4— /S ¢fO _  Duncan, a native of Alas; was a white ordained Baptist Minister  was also employed as a laborer by a Dale County farmer, — Duncan fell in love with his employer‘s daugh— ter —and to clear the way for his marriage to her, he poisoned his wife, Dolly, with morphine. When he was arrested and charged with  the murder, Duncan claimed that his employer had purchased the morphine for him in order that he might kill his wife and be free to marry and that XK€ the daughter had actually administered the poison though he had gone along with the plan,. The jury believed the prose— cution‘s theorg that Duncan alone was responsible for the death of  his wife and he was convicted and sentenced to hang, He made a lengthy speech from the gallows to the 10,000 persons who had gathered in Ozark to witness his hanging on Fab. 21, 1890, in which he reitera— ted his story that his KMK$X employer and his daughter were responsi~ ble for the crime. Prior to his execution, a hat was passed to raise money to go into a trust fund for his three small children.  FORGOTTEN XKXXXX TRAILS, A History of Pale Cor, 4La,. ; by Fred 8,  Watson» Sanner Press, Publishery, Z#MME Birmingham, Ala. Copyri f J ; {opyright 19686 by Fred S. "atson, Pages 17—21. f

| mass, Richard R. (Dick) A— 20 —1 310  Hawes, a whlte locomotive engineer, liven in Pirmingham, Ala., with his wife and two daughters, 12—year—=old May and I—year—old Irene. On the morning of Dec. , 1888, May s body was found floatlng in East Loke near Blnmingham She. had been bludgeoned to death and evidently her body had been weighted before being thrown into the lake but the weights had come loose, Her identification was established at  the mortuary and officers went to the Hawes house which they found de— serted. There was evidence of bloodstains and Hawes was immediately suspected of having killed his family'because 1t was known that he had been courting a younger girl in clumbus, Miss, It was discovered that he and the girl had gotten married on Dec, 5 and were due to pass  thgough Birmingham that night, O,ficers met the train and took Hawes into custody. Se malntalned that he and his wife had obtained a di~ _vorce and that she had left Pirmingham after he gave her a sizeable sum of money,. He claimed that he had taken the two girls to Mobile _and placed them in a convent,. A witness came forward who stated that  he had seen Hawes and May riding to Hast Lgke toﬁethe on a in an that Hawes later returned alone. Another Sirmingham aka was agge  and the body of Mrs, Hawes, securely weighted,was found on the bottom of the lake, That night an angry mob stormed the jail, but the Sheriff of Jefferson County, anticipating tréuble, had surrounded the jail with special deputies and policemen and they fired into the mob, killing ten persons and wounding sleven others. Hawes was calm . throughout, stating that he expected to be lynched and dressing to  ‘be prepared to be baken by the mob, The lake where Mrs, Hawes‘ body was found was subsequently drained and the body of Ida Hawes was dis— covered,. Like her sister and mother, she had been bludgeoned to death, Hawes was tried and convicted of the murder of his family and sentenced to hang, The execution was delayed by a series of appeals, but he was finally hanged at the Jefferson County Jail in Birmingham on Feb, 28, 1890.  BIRMINGHAM DAILY NEWS», Birmingham, Ala., 1—13—1890  %7}Zqu¢c/./¢&‘Wm%

SPARKS, Charles H. Wa/ua/Jé: / 9 0 I1  Sparks, a black man, was a Phenix City, Ala., school teacher, He was having an affair with Lucy Ingersoll, the wife of Jack Ingersoll, a prominent black Phenix City Contractor and they plotted to kill Ingersoll, Mrs, Ingersoll procured a shotgun which she gave to Sparks and one night in the Summer of 1901 he shot Ingersoll through the head while he was eating his supper. Sparks escaped to Georgia but was captured and returned to Phenix City where, because of the high regard in which Ingersoll was held, feeling ran high, He was then taken to Opelika, Lee Co., for his protection guarded by a detachment of the Alabama National Guard and from there to the Montgomery jail, He made an effort_to escape in Montgomery by saw— ing his way through the bars of his cell window but this was thwart— ed and four small steel files were confiscated by the jail officials, Mrs, Ingersoll kmwxwwrs confessed and turned State‘s evidence, receiving a ?25—year prison sentence on her plea of guilty to second degree mur— der while Sparks, with her giving the principal testimony against  sid reneseacte sie. neh thot  would not be hanged but preferred to be shot and his life was pro        L Longed by a number of respites granted by the Governor, When he was informed that the Governor had refused to intervene further, he went * berserk and attached the death watch with a large knife which had been smuggled in to him, cutting a large gash on the chin of one member—of the watch, He was finally foroed to the wall of his cell with pluthOrkS, disarmed and bound, He was hanged at Opelika on March 5, 1904, The rope was too long and his feet touched the ground, so he was drawn back up, the rope shortened and he was then 3ronppd again, A brother of the victim was allowed to help spring the trap. TE OMAS, Clyde _,, J  Thomas, é4b ack native of Randolph, Bibb Co., Ala., was married and the father of four children, A yard man employed under John Wallace, a railroad foreman, he had always borne a good repubation and was considered peaceable, On August 9, 1921, he had been drinking when he met Wallace‘s lh=year=old daughter, Annie Lee, on a lonely road near her home about L; miles from Centreville and raped and murdered her, Thomas was captured soon afterwards and, because of the inten— sity of the local feeling, he was rushed by train to Birmingham where he was held until his trial later that month when he was returned to Centreville on a train loaded with Armed National Guardsmen for his protection, Machine guns were mounted both on the train and at the court House where he was convicted and sentenced to die before being returned to the Birmingham jail to await his execution, On Sept. 15, 1921, he was returned to Centreville again and, surrounded by armed Guardsmen, was walked to the Bibb County Jail where he was hanged in the presence of his victim‘s mother, sister and two brothers, Prior to his death, Thomas admitted that he was guilty, blaming whlskey as the carse of the crime, and said that he should be punished, He was calm throughout the ordeal and, after his death, his body was taken back to Birmingham and buried in Potter‘s Fleld. This was done at the order of the. Governor of Alabama in deference to local opinion in Bibb County which did not want him buried there, __________ ___ _. — _CGREZN, Nehemiah (aml JY I  Green, a 2l;—year—old black man, had been discharged from the Army on January 25, 1946 for lack of adaptability after psychiatrists at Northington General Hospital reported findings of "inadquacy, imma turity, irreSQOnsibility, egocentric and socially incompatible with sexual deviation,." He obtained work as a helper on an ine truck of the Southeastern Ice Company in Birmingham, Ala,, and worked for them until the advent of cold weather in 1947 resulted in his being laid off, While working with the ice company, he made deliveries to the Hill Grocery in Birmingham which was operated by Thomas C. Solomon and knew that Solomon opened the store each morning around 7 am at which time he removed the money from the safe and took it to the cash register, For several mornings prior to Dec. 13, 1947, Green waited at the store for Mr. Solomon to ppen but he was unable to rob him as he planned because of the presence of other persons. On the morning of Dec. 135 1947, he was there alone and after Mr, Solomon had opened the safe, Creen shot him in the back. He attempted to shoot him again but the pistol would not fire and he xx grabbed an ime pick and  leaving. Because of his suspicious actions in loitering around the store on mornings before the robbery, Green was XXEMZXXK an immediate suspect and when he was taken into custody, he confessed and took officers to Pratt City Park.xk __ There—_he—Rfevealed—where—he had ——— hidden the murder weapon and most kk® of the money stolen from Polomon, The remainder of the money was at his house. Green‘s de — fense was one of insanity and it was shown that he had undergone a series of electric shock treatments while in Northington Hospital,  He was sent KkK® to the State Hospital for the insane at Mount Vernon for examination and when the doctors there stated that he was able  to stand trial, he was returned to Birmingham where he was convicted and sentenced to die. &n appeal to the Alabama Supreme Court resulted in an affirmation of the conviction and septarce, A plea was then made to the Governor for a commutation of the sentence and in a personal appearance before the Governor, Green so impressed —him with the forthrightness and sensibleness of his questions and comments that the Governor decided that he was , indeed, sane and refused to interfere, Green was electrocuted at XXK the Alabama State Prison on August 12, 1949,  BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala., August 12, 1949  41 SOUTHERN REPORTER 2nd SERIES, 566  P R AT aler ae toe » Gi

— DENNISON, Earle $9 wL/J/ JET  Mrs. Dennison, a white S5h—year—old Wetumpka, Ala., widow, was a regis— tered operating room nurse, Her husband, Lemuel Dennison had died  in 1950 and two weeks. later, his two—year—dbd4d neice, FXKK Polly Ann Weldon, had died from what a physician termed "food poisoning." A  few weeks after Polly Ann‘s death, another daughter named Shirley Di— ann was born to the Weldon‘s and this child became a great favorite | of the childless Mrs, Dennison. On the afternoon of May 1, 1952, af— ter she had finished her shift at the Wetumpka hospital, Mrs, Denni son drove to rural Claud, Ala,, to visit the, Weldons, She took Shir— ley Diann to a neighborhood store where she purchased some soft drinks and candy, When they got back to the Weldon house, Mrs, Dennison went into the kitchen and prepared the sodas for ShirleyyDiann, "rs, Wel— | don and herself, carefully pouring the child‘s into a plastic cup. After the little girl drank her soda, she started crying and insist=— ed that she was sick,. Mrs, Dennison said that she only had an uﬁset stomach and that it would not be necessary to call a doctor,  She excused herself and drove to Deatsville where she paid a premium  on a policy for $5,000 that she owned on Shirley Diann and that was due to expire that night, When she returned to the Weldon home, she * roel rge gy ”(2459 £/7A2*  waaa told jhat Mr. Weldon had arrived and that he and his wife had ~~  — taken Shirley Diann, who was then unconscious, to the Wetumpka Hospi— tal, There the child died that night with her aunt in attendance. _ — The attending physician felt that the symptoms resembled those caused by arsenical pogkoning and, at his request, Mr, Weldon consented to _ an autopsy which revealed that the little girl had been administered | the poison,. An examination of the plastic cup showed traces of arse—. nic and it was found that Mrs, Dennison had purchased some arsenic in. a drug store three weeks earlier, An exhumation of Polly Ann Weldon‘s body disclosed that she two had been poisoned with arsenic and a check revealed that Mrs, Dennison had collected on an insurance policy on her life, Several days after her arrest, she confessed that she had poisoned. Shirley Diann, but she claimed that it was not tatéd, but done on an impulse, She denied that she had killed Polly Ann or her husband, Though his body was never and an autop— sy performed, it was generally believed that she had poisonedhim also, Convicted and sentenced to death, her attorneys requested a — ”aﬁnitf test whilh ruled that she was fully sane. When the ﬁbvernor ~ a mt boner in the Bates petow tobe ‘executed When she was electrocuted at Kil Prison if Sept. 1953o;  Pageé<ZL£L

_ BOWEN, Willian F., Jr.  Bowen, a 28—year—old white resident of Huntsville, 4la., had served time in a Federal Seformatory after a court martial for assault with intent to kill, and a portion of a sentence in the Alabama State Penitentiary for burglary and grand larceny. Released on parole, he was employed by a Muntsville pest control firm as a salesman,. While in the "tates Prison, Bowen had been converted to religion and had aspirations of becoming a minister., He went to various jails where he would preach‘and implore the prisoners to change their ways. On _ several occasions he had called on Mrs, Janice Thomas, wife of a _ Redstone Arsenal physicist at her house in an effort to sell her the _ services of the pest control company. Early on the afternoon of Oct. 17, 1961, he returned to the house and when Mrs, Thomas admitted him he forced her into a bedroom where he made her disrobe and f attempted to assault her but was unable to commiék the actual rape, When she started Rcreaming, he bludgeoned her unconscious with a rolling pin and then got a knife from the kitchen and stabbed her thirteen times, leaving the knife imbedded in her neck, Bowen be— came a suspect when a brochure that he had left at the house was found and a check with the pest control company revealed that he  had loft town the day following the murder stating tha he had Reep ieye 9 r pote inn emre  to go to Atlanta on personal business. The police were mkxktim — — preparing to go to Atlanta to search for him when he called and — — sald that he felt that he was being followed and would return volubgarily, Actually, he had not been located, and his conscious — was troubling him. He flew Maﬁa EHuntevill e and caught a taxi — from the airport to the police. station where he confessed that he had murdered the young housewife. Prior to his electrocution on Jane 15, 1965, bowen willed his eyes to the University of Alabama to be transplanted to give sight to a blind person,  TRUE DETECTIVE, MEKSK$JXIB8TE March, 1967. big_ocr: " _ tat sl go. /g al 7 3  Bailey, a 25—yeareold white man, was a native of Tennessee, conginerdd of low mengality, who spen 18 months in a reformatory in his native state before he escaped and made his way to Montgomery, Ala., where he joined the National Guard, After serving on the Mexican border with the Second Alabama, he went to France during World Warr II, and served with distinction, being sent several times into "No Man‘s Land" and  _ being severely gassed and shell—shocked after which he was invalided home, In July, 1919, he attempted to pass a forged check in Brewton,  , Ala., and, was sent to Speigner Prison for a term of 10 years,. In 1920, he stabbed to death Francis Sudduth, another inmate, in a prison brawl and, following his conviction of the murder in the Elmore County Circuit Court, he was sentenced to Kilby Prison for life, There he got into an altercation with James Culpepper, also a prisoner and he afterwards fashioned a prison stilleto and told several other inmates of his intention to kill Culpepper,. On Nov, 14, 1923, he carried this threat into execution, stabbing and mortally wounding Culpepper, At his trial in Montgomery the next month, he pleaded not guilty by rea— son of insanity and said that his mind hanbeen eﬁfectedtgy ﬁiilgging  ‘gassed and shell—shocked during the war, His version of the killing  was that he had attacked Culpgpper only aﬁter the lattgr hgd stigck him but other prisoners testified as to his having stated that e | planned to kill Culpepper and in accordance with law decreein a mandatory death sentence for a life prisoner who killed again, he wa convicted and sentenced to die, His conviction was affirmed on appeal. and then the American Legion and variousother veterans waged a deter— mined fight for his life, seeking clemency from the State Board of Pardons and theGovernor, Governor Brandon did grant a respite in or— der that he might be examined By doctors from the veterans‘ bureau  but when they reported to him that there was nothing wrong with him and thegt they could not help him, he declined to intervene further, Unassisted, but visibly distraught, his face wan, he went to the gallows at the Montgomery County Jail on the morning of Feb, 27, 1925. After attempting to speak twice and failing, he finally managed to say> "I appreciate everything everybody has done for me and every— thing." The last pulsations of his heart stopped thirty minutes after the trap fell and after his body was taken to the funeral home;, —ov er 5,000 persons viewed his remains whlch were surrounded by numerous  beautiful floral designs,  101 Southern 54,6 f BIRMINGHAM ACE HERALD, Dec., 5, 1923; Dec. L, 1923; Jan. 8, 1925;  Feb.. 28, 1925. yy aera as air® "  Owens, a black man, was a resident of Birmihgham, Ala., who an alien~ ist stated had the mind of a 10—year—old child, On Saturday night, May 24, 1924, he attacked a white man, Richard Warner; with an axe  as Warner passed an alley mrtar 806 Fourteenth St., bludgeoning him unconscious and robbing his pockets of a watch and money, A short time later, he attacked another white man, L, M, Watkins as Watkins passed an alley near 1515 Fourth Ave., north, in the same manner  and, after robbing him, dragged KKZXK&®X his uncosscious body into the yeard of a house, Watkins had been found and taken to the hospital when police officers noticed Owens carrying an axe and arrested him, *t the time of his arrest, Owens through the bloodstained weapon  over a fence and sought to flee, being shot and wounded in the arm, Warner was found shortly after the arrest and taken to the hospital also, A search of Owens! person revealed some bloodstained money as well as Warner‘s watck and he was charged with both assaults, He confessed late Sunday XKHX and on Monday an indictment was returned.  These were the last of a series of murderous aye attacks on white | persoms WbWyeblacks in Birmingham and, though neither Warner nor Watking  disd of their wounds, Owens was tried on the capital offense of armed robbyry (notes Those convicted of murders were not executed), At his — trial, his defense was one of insanity, but he was convicted and sen— —— tenced to dis, He tried to escape several times, attempting to dis= . arm an officer on one occasion, and prying out the bars to his cell on another, His case was affirmed on appeal by the Albama Supreme Court, Apetition for clemency was unanimously rejected by the State Board of Pardons and the Governor declined to intervene, For over a month prior to his execution, Owens, who claimed that the confession had been forced from him and that he was innocent, conducted daily prayer services in his. cell and he hoped until the very last that Governor Brandon would intervene, Shortly before his death, he was asked by a newspaper reporter if he was gullty and he re— plied» "No, I ain‘t,. But even if— I was, I don‘t think I ought to be «hung for robbery," He was hanged in the yard of the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham on Sept. 24, 1926, In the lapel of his coat he wore a negro lodge pin and beside it—rested a white rosebud, — Addi=— tionally, two white carnations protruded from his coat pockets, On the gallows, he said: "I want to thank all the good white people for what they‘ve done to save me, —I —don‘t feel that I!‘ve had a square deal, _ but that‘!‘s with the Lord,"  BIRMINGHAM AGE HERALD §5—26; 529; 6—1316=28; 12-25-192h;  XXIX BIRMINGHAN NEWS, 9-911; 9=20 and »  109 Southern 109 (Z /U€‘°‘" Ap E/ ,)

MACK, Harry  Mack, a young black transient, was employed as a laborer on the Fayette—Tuscaloosa highway in 1925 when he raped a young white girl near Stough, Fayette Co., Ala, Bloodhounds were used to— — track him and he was rapidly taken into custody, charged with  the crime and placed on trial, Convicted by a jury that delibera— ted for less than thirty minutes, he was condemned to die and, on August 21, 1925, he was hanged on a gallows constructed on the courthouse lawn and shlelded from the eyes of the general public by a fence constructed especially for that purpose.  Letter from Mrs. Marguerite .T. Callahan, 250 Crescent Ridge Road, Tuscaloosa, Ala., 35401.  The Fayette BANNER, Fayette, Ala., 1—16—1925 and 8—20—%k925  Hanged at 8+45 AM and neck broken, Trap sprung by Sheriff J, T. Chambless, In his Rast words, he attributed downfall to a patent medicine which he ‘had taken and which he said caused him to have unruly desires, He confessed to crime,. A few people admitted with officials to witness execution, but the large crowd who gathered to see it were not permitted inside the inclosure, Had been convicted by special session of circuit court on July 15 and had been captured a few days before, Was taken to Birm ingham for safe keeping because of threats of mob violence and only returned under heavy guard when the court had convened for his trial,  — BIRMINGHAM AGE EERALD, Birmingham , Ala., 8—22—1925,.  Crime on 7—3—1925, Convicted on July 15 by jury out for 30 minutes. The attack occurred near Stough while the girl was returning home from a store, After Mack‘s capture, he was taken first to Jasper and then to Birmingham for safekeeping. Aftet trial returned to B‘ham, BIRMIHGHAM AGE HERALD. Birmingham, Ala., 7—16—1925. Arrested on 7—2—1925 after assaulting 16—year—old girl as she was re— urning from Power‘s store at Stough, She was dragged several hundred yards and reported in critical condition, Madk, who —had thrown away Jumper and hat, captured 3 miles away after being tracked by blood— hounds,. He gave home as Montgomery, said he was working on state high way near there and that another black with him had attacked, AGE HE— RALD, July 3, 1925. Transferred from Jasper to Birmingham after con— fession, Girl the daughter of prominent Fayette Co. farmer, AGE  EERALD, July 4, 1925.

Williams, a black man, was a native of Georgia who was sentenced to lifeimprisonment there following conviction of a first degree murder charge, lie managed to escape from the prison farm to which he was assigned and made his way to Dothan, Alabama, where he was convicted of assault and battary following his striking a black girl on the head with a tree limb and sent to an Alabama prison farm for 90 days. Shortly after he was released, he went on a rampage and on thenight of March?, 1925, he attacked and strangled to death ablack woman, Magnolia Jones, near her home at Ramer, Montgomery County, Mrs, Jones! body was not found until Thursday, MarchS, On the preceding night, Williams had waylaid another black woman, Mattie Mae Williams, who had gone from her home near Orion, Pike County, to a well and attacked her after which he hanged her body from a tree where it was found with the neck broken shortly afterwards, On the night of March 6, he attacked a third black woman, Rose Brown, at her home near Shellhorn, also in Pike County, and, after raping ber, strangled her to death with a rope and beat  ‘ her head to a pulp with an aX, The black residents of Pike and  MOMtsomery Counties lived in perpetual fear while the manhunt for — Williams progressed and Bamilies banded together for their mubusl |     protection, He was finally captured a few days later in a saw mill near Ozark, Dale County, Williams admitted his identity and that he had killed the three wyomsn though he unsuccessfully sought to implicate another man as an accomplice dn the Brownymurder, Indic» ted in Pike County for the Brown and Williams murders, he was tried only for the Brown murder, convicted and sentenced to die, Before his trial had ended, he repudiated his confession, denying that he had killed the — women and continued to maintain.this until his death, The gallows were erected just behind the Pike County Jail at Troy, enclosed by an iron fence, When Williams heard the sounds of the scaffold being—erected, he went into a rage, tore his matress into shreds and broke a water pipe in his cell, However, he calmed  down when the Sheriff appeared, In spite of thefact that the exe— cution on July 3, 1925, was supposed to have been private and a fence had been erected to insure this, it is estimated that 5,000 people managed to witness it from various vgntag? poigts. In #" brief speech from the gallows, he again deﬁle? his guilt agd said that he had not received justice, though he did thank Sheriff Carr—  311 for his kindnesses to him during his confinement, No appeal, BIRMINGHAM ACE HERALD, Birmingham, Ala., 3—8—1925; 5=29—1925;  5=18=1925; 6=—20—19253 7—;=1925, Last words: "Goodbyes, Everybody”?

ACHELOR, Clyde Reese  [gm-75 ok [p {, [F fan Mera 10— BY —] 9 24 25—@eaac— Oole__ Bachelor, a white Elmore Co.,, Ala., planter, was married to the dau— ghter of Lamar Smith, a wealthy and prominent citizen of Wetumpka who was a former Probate Judge of Elmore County,. Bachelor, who was in financial difficulties, hired one of his black tenants, Hays Leo— nard, to kill Smith in order that Mrs. Bachelor might inherit Mikx® her part of thm his estate. On the night of August 30, 1926, Bachelor drove Leonard to the Smith home and waited in his automobile while leonard went up on the porch and fired a shotgun through the windown into the body of Judge Smith who was lying in bed reading a newspaper Mrs, Smith was also injured. Bechelor then drove Leonard batk to his home on the Bachelor plantation, Both men were arrested and when questioned Leonard made a complete ‘confession in the presence of Bachelor who refused to say angpphing,. Later, Bachelor admitted that Leonard had told the truth and said that he he promised the thnant an advance off his crops for the year and a sum of money to kill Judge Smith, Both men were indtfted, tried, convicted and sentenced to  hang for the crime. Bachelor‘s defense was one of insanity and KKHXK as proff of this it was shown that a great~grandmother. had conmitted  suicide and that several other relatives were considered crazy, He to be slectrocuted as the State had, during the course of appeal, changed the means of exscution, On the night before he was to die, Bachelor was allowed a visit by his b=—year—old son and afterwards he seemed resigned to his fate. Prior to his execution, he wrote a letter to the Governor requesting that the life of leonard, who was of low mentality, be spared, Bachelor said that he was the perpetrator of the crime and that leonard was merely his pawn, Accordingly, the Governor did commute IEEKXFH the sentence of Leonard whose life had already been prolonged by stays of execution granted pending the outcome of Bachelor‘s appeal,. Bachelor was electrocuted at Kilby rison in Alabama on duly 15, 1927.) is went to his death calmly and,  THE DOTHAN EAGLE, Dothan, Ala,, July 15, 1927 ggg ALBANY’HERALD, Albany, Ga», July 15, 1927 SOUTHERN REPORTER, Vols 113 So Published by We ishi f p t Pubi.: St. Paul, roan silk? 67—7, a St fublishing COs p  f f g f « s # g f Auge Nira) 9p I. sete F £..2 . 4 <# S * Tad F ¥ # £ & “with P neces alts o  9 a "J g § ﬁt a #

big_ocr: MILLER, Walter  Miller, a 38—year—old Huntsville, Ala., black man had served ten years in an Alabama prison fdr burglary and grand larceny, Me way— laid a Huntsville white girl, Vivian Woodward, one night as she was returning home from a movie and dragged her behind a garage where he raped her and then bludgeoned her tod&ath with a brick. Mller, who had been seen in the area, became a suspect  when he disappeared the day after the crime and he was trailed to Indiana where he was taken into custody and returned to Alabama,  He confessed that he had assaulted and killed the girl but repudiated his confession before his trial and maintained that he was innocent. le went to his death in the electric chair on Junk 19, 1936, still protesting that he was innocent. Mis last words were a request to the Warden, spoken as the mask was lowered over his face: "All right, EEEKX Cap‘n Frank, quick as possible,"  THE BIRMINGHAM NEWS, Birmingham, Ala, June 19, 1936.  bts AUL

BELSTER,, Nellie  (Not hanged.)  Bester, a 20-year-old black woman, murdered her husband, Smith Bester, at Woodstock, Alabama, in January, 1922, with an ax. She then dis- membered the corpse and threw the various por- tions into a nearby creek. - She confessed, was tried and sentenced to dis. While awaiting execution, she managed to get pregnant by a trusty and After the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that pregnamt woman could not be hanged, her sentence was commuted to life imprisonment. fource: .BLOODX BIBB, by V. Donald Elam; Center- ville, AL; Elam Enterprises, 1985, pp 91-93
